text:
Advertising is paid communication to persuade audiences to patronize the products and/or services of a business establishment. Advertisers buy radio and television airtime where their commercial messages are aired. For mainstream radio and television industries, advertisements are the main source of income that enable them to produce, distribute, and exhibit programs. The average broadcast ad often lasts for 30 seconds; many also run from 10 to 15 seconds but rarely over 30 seconds.

 

Advertisers, usually with the services of an advertising agency, prepare commercial messages using a highly developed process in order to ensure that audiences are convinced to utilize their product. The process begins by mining insights from consumers based on their perceived needs and wants to craft marketing and advertising strategies. These insights give way to the development of the product, the product benefit, and the reason that makes this benefit attractive and advantageous to the consumer. At this stage, the ideas generated in the strategies are turned into a radio or television commercial using tactics like emotional appeal and logical reasoning. Most commercials employ both tactics to draw attention to and sell the product to consumers. The Clusivol Vitamin commercials with the tag line “Bawal Magkasakit” (You Can’t Get Sick) incorporate both these tactics. The commercial warns of the difficulty of getting sick in trying and hard times, leading to the loss of income and food for the family, and advises consumption of the product. Similarly, the Bonakid Pre-School 3+’s ad strategically identifies the nutrients in the milk, while playing on parental love and concern for their growing children.

 

 

Even with all the extensive groundwork and strategic thinking that go into the crafting of advertising materials, there are commercials that fail to sell the products they promote. One of the reasons for such failure is the use of slick, clever or overly amusing executions in which the “gimmick” overshadows the brand. In these cases, the execution is remembered but not the product or the reason for purchasing it. For instance, the tagline “Ibalik ang Swerte” (Bring Back the Fortune) became popular when it aired in the 1970s but audiences tended to forget that this was for the campaign of the Philippine National Sweepstakes. Another example is the expression “Magpapatuka na lang ako sa ahas” (I’ll just let a snake bite me), which was made popular by Elizabeth Ramsey. The expression became popular but studies showed that the product that was featured, the detergent bar Superwheel, was hardly remembered by the audience. Another reason advertisements may not work is the clutter of advertisements that fill the airwaves. When the commercial on air does not stand out or capture the audience’s attention, the message is lost among the many materials aired on radio and television.

 

The produced commercials are placed in programs that provide the most number of viewers for the cheapest airtime cost. By buying airtime in programs that rate highly and provide the most number of potential consumers of the products, advertisers directly influence the quality and eventually the longevity of a radio or television program. If the program does not rate, no advertising revenues will be expected from this program, therefore leading to the program’s reformulation to attract more viewers or its cancellation from the air. This reliance on ratings results in the use of a “star system,” in which only performers with a large loyal following become the crux of creative work, and the proliferation of formulaic programs that rely on previously high-rating programs. This system does not encourage originality, innovation, and the creation of more imaginative programs on radio and television.

 

 

Advertisers and marketers point out several advantages of advertising: giving consumers choices in the products that they will consume; allowing them to select the products or services that best fit their needs; creating competition among businesses often resulting in lower costs and better products and services; fuelling the economy by encouraging the consumption of goods and services; and providing information that creates awareness on topics beneficial for consumers such as the prevention of diseases. On the other hand, advertising, as program content, is criticized because of several issues, the most prominent of which are those concerning “truth in advertising,” stealth advertising, and the creation of a consumerist society.

 

Although advertising is regulated by the Ad Standards Council (ASC), a self-regulating body composed of marketing, advertising, and media organizations in the country which is tasked with crafting and enforcing a code of ethics for advertising and marketing communications, there are questions on “truth in advertising.” For one, advertising works on highlighting a product’s sellable feature. This means that the negative aspects of the product are not presented in broadcast commercials. Advertisers promote the “refreshing” qualities of soft drinks but do not talk about the health dangers of consuming excessive amounts of sugar. Marketers have created an image that infant milk formulas are superior to breast milk and as such have discounted the inherent benefits of breastfeeding. Couched under the thin line between the truth and creative execution, another example is when pharmaceutical products are presented by performers dressed in doctor’s white coats without a nameplate. This leaves the impression that the product is endorsed by the medical community.

 

 

Another issue is stealth advertising. This is the promotion of products and services embedded in non-advertising program content. The range of types of stealth advertising can be characterized as very noticeable to almost subliminal. Brand logos and text crawling on television screens are examples of this type of advertising. Watching a sporting event like basketball exposes viewers to a whole slew of brand logos—the name of the teams, brand streamers hanging on the courtside, logos beside the team scores, and branding on the court floor. Advertisers will try to maximize exposure of their clients’ brand logos by putting these in any and every available space on the venue or on the television screen. In advertising parlance, this space where branding can be exposed is called “advertising real estate.” Another example of stealth advertising is called product placement where a product advertised is incorporated into the set of the program, such as LG television monitors that serve as backdrop to the news programs of ABS-CBN. In various episodes of the drama series I Love Betty La Fea, premiered September 2008, ABS-CBN, the products Maggi Magic Sarap seasoning, Red Ribbon cakes, Waffle Time, Zagu, Clear anti-dandruff shampoo, and 4G antioxidant food supplement were seen in various episodes. Product placement is not limited to seeing the product visually. When John Lloyd Cruz says “Ingat” (Take care) in his appearances on television shows and dramas, this utterance reminds the viewers of Biogesic, the over-the-counter brand of Paracetamol that he endorses. On radio, stealth advertising is sometimes presented in the guise of a newscast. Newscasters begin the program with announcements about the inclement weather and then subtly include a plug for a specific vitamin supplement that is supposed to help the audience prevent catching a cold due to the weather. There are times when the product is integrated into the narrative of the broadcast content. In ABS-CBN’s television drama series Bituing Walang Ningning (Star without Sparkle), 2006, the plot of the final episodes revolved around a showdown concert between the protagonists Dorina and Lavinia, played by Sarah Geronimo and Angelika Dela Cruz, respectively. Selected scenes from this concert and its rehearsals were used in the final week of the series. Entitled Himig ng Pasasalamat (Song of Thanksgiving), this concert was staged on 19 Sep 2006 at the Araneta Coliseum before a live audience and sponsored by Jollibee, a product endorsed by Sarah Geronimo.

 

Given that the local industry started out as a commercial endeavor, audiences have become used to programs interrupted by commercials. Audiences, during commercial breaks in the regular programming, have the ability to ignore or evaluate the commercial content of broadcast. Stealth advertising, being incorporated in regular programming content, often leaves the audience with no choice but to watch the advertisement. In capturing the audience this way, stealth advertising becomes a strong tool for advertisers.

 

Advertising materials carry ideologies that reinforce and influence the belief system of audiences. Marketing and advertising executives have banked on Filipino consumers’ desire to have Caucasian features like fairer skin to sell a product. This desire already exists among consumers because historically, especially from the days of colonization, the ideal of being “white” has been deeply ingrained in the consumer’s mind. This belief has been reinforced by celebrating Caucasian features as seen in the choice of models used in Camay commercials since the 1950s. Among the Camay girls were Paquita Roces, Gloria Romero, Delia Razon, Nida Blanca, the Revilla sisters Maritess and Cita, and the daughter of Maritess Revilla, Bianca Araneta—all of whom are mestizas, defining the concept of Filipina beauty.

 

Embedded in messages of advertising materials are ideas that are “naturalized” and thereby shape the way audiences think and behave. San Miguel Beer’s radio jingle, “Tuloy ang Aguinaldo” (Carry on with Gift-giving), aired during the economic crisis of 1985, underscores the Filipino’s capacity to endure bad times as it espoused “Tuloy ang aguinaldo. Tuloy ang simbang gabi. Tuloy ang caroling. Tuloy ang Pasko. Tuloy ang San Miguel Beer.” (Carry on with gift-giving. Carry on with midnight mass. Carry on with caroling. Carry on Christmas. Carry on San Miguel Beer.) This radio commercial also implies that San Miguel Beer is part of the Filipino’s traditions and way of life that should be upheld even in times of crisis. Another San Miguel Beer commercial, “Bilmoko” (Buy Me), 1988, naturalizes a gender bias against women. In this television commercial, the lead actor buys his fantasy girlfriend everything that she wants—jewelry, clothes, food, and San Miguel Beer—as a sign of his affection. This scenario promotes the idea that men are providers, and women’s love can be bought. It also reinforces the concept of women as frivolous and shallow.

 

Aside from these specific values, the overarching ideology that advertising promotes is consumerism. In simple terms, this is the belief system that promotes consumption of goods as a way of life. Consumerism sways audiences to believe that acquiring material goods is needed to improve lives. Advertisements that herald “the best,” “new,” “improved,” and other similar superlatives are equated with “intelligent” consumers who make better choices to enhance their lives. Advertisers also make products integral to the viewers’ daily living. McDonald’s “Hooray for Today,” 2012, with the line “Hooray for mornings and things that make them good,” insinuates that having a good day begins with a coffee and breakfast at McDonald’s. Also, commercial messages are sometimes equated with personal and institutional ideals resulting in the belief that these values exist with the products and services. Del Monte Tomato Sauce’s television commercial, “Come Home to Del Monte,” 2012, has the line “Once a week, come home to Mom’s cooking, come home to Del Monte Tomato Sauce… Bringing Filipino families closer for generations… Surely you would be closer…” which equates close family ties with the product. The same value of family togetherness is the message of Jollibee’s “I Love You Sabado” ad, which shows a family eating together on a school holiday. A look at some of the taglines of Coca-Cola in the Philippines demonstrates how Coke is positioned as an integral part of life, well-being, and happiness: “Can’t Beat the Feeling,” 1989; “Kasama ka, Coke” (You Belong, Coke), 2005; “Share a Coke sa Saya,” (Share Coke in Happy Times), 2014. Written by Fernando A. Austria Jr

 

Sources

Ad Standard Council 2011; Alfanza 2011; Austria 1996, 2012a, 2012b; Duncan 2002; Honasan 1995; Horkheimer and Adorno 2001; Levinson 1990; Lo 2012; Peter and Olson 1999; Schultz, Tannenbaum, and Allison 1995.

text:
Ratings are the measure of audiences: how many are listening or viewing a specific broadcast at a given time. The numbers obtained from this audience count inform broadcasters and advertisers of a program’s audience share versus its competitors as well as projections of the number of future viewers of the program. More sophisticated analyses of the results of ratings research can also reveal the socio-psycho-demographic profiles of audiences as well as their listening and viewing habits. Ratings indicate the popularity of a radio or television program and, as such, are used by marketers in determining the most efficient way of placing advertisements in broadcast programs by an analysis of the cost per thousand listeners or viewers of their commercials.

 

Given the dependence of the Philippine broadcast industry on advertising, programs live and die on ratings. The program format of the station is both the creative output of the station as well as the basic product that it sells to draw audiences and thus attract advertisers. Focused targeting of audiences lures commercial spot placements (Aseron 2011, 34, 145-47). To illustrate the shift from music programming characterized by stations devoted to specific music genres on FM radio to the AM format of talk was due to the former’s poor ratings (Aseron 2011, 154-57). An example of this shift can be seen in DZMB, on 90.7 kHz on the FM band nicknamed Love Radio 90.7. The demise of its playlist of love songs gave birth to a talk format that appropriates the humor of stand-up comedians in sing-along bars and the risque tones of the so-called shock-jocks on American radio, targeting a mass-based audience from the C, D, and E socio-economic groups. This humor is illustrated by program titles like Tambalang Balasubas at Balahura (A Swindler and a Filthy Tandem) and the station’s slogan—“Kailangan Pa Bang I-memorize ‘Yan?” (Do we need to memorize that?)—and the aliases of its disc jockeys like Chris Tsuper, Nicole Hyala, and Papa Jack. Love Radio has joined the bandwagon of FM stations shifting programming to gain a spot in the ratings chart high enough to attract advertising.

 

 

Creative directions in the production of programs are thus heavily influenced by ratings. A director of a television drama for instance considers not only the creative and technical aspects of production but also its commercial potential. In handling the business aspect, the director has to continuously adjust and modify the creative aspects of the production, such as storyline and casting, to ensure that audiences of the program and fans of the performers in the drama continue to watch the series and guarantee its high ratings. In the teleserye My Binondo Girl, the character of actor Kim Chiu was originally written to end up with one of her suitors, the character of actor Jolo Revilla. The storyline was abandoned because the Chiu-Revilla love team was not positively received by the show’s audiences (Marmol 2012, 77).

 

The quantitative or numerical data generated in ratings research tend to indicate the preferences, taste, and gratifications sought by audiences from programs (Webster et al. 2006, 175-203). The managers of the mainstream broadcast industry as well as advertisers insist on this conventional wisdom. Ratings therefore are seen as a reflection of creative successes. Hence, imitations of successful programs are produced, and consequently, formulas and conventions in production are established.

 

 

Shifts in programming and storytelling conventions show that ratings do not accurately provide a comprehensive picture of what audiences look for in their broadcast fare. For instance, the storytelling conventions of soap operas that rated well prior to the airing of the Mexican telenovela Marimar in 1994 on the former RPN-9 can be characterized as slow, implausible, and simple as they usually followed a single plot. This contrasted with the faster-paced action, several multi-dimensional characters, and multiple and more believable storylines of Marimar. In spite of the differences, Marimar topped the rating charts, demonstrating a change in taste and preferences that was not indicated nor predicted by the high ratings of soap operas prior to 1994. Written by Fernando A. Austria Jr

 

Sources: Aseron 2011; Marmol 2012; Webster, Phalen, and Lichty 2006.

text:
Aside from audience ratings, audience research for program concepts or concept testing is conducted by the broadcast industry to gather insights on the appeal and acceptability of program concepts, plot development, and even pairing of performers in a program. Audience research includes testing a concept or the pilot and any program episode (Eastman and Ferguson, 2012). Here the reaction of the audience is taken prior to the actual scripting of the show, after the shooting of a pilot episode, or during the course of the airing of the program. This type of research is conducted to ensure the success of a program in terms of viewership or in garnering high ratings.

 

Both qualitative and quantitative methods are used in this kind of audience research. In qualitative research, focus group discussions are used to mine ideas from audiences in building or refining program concepts. In quantitative methods, surveys are used to see the acceptability of a program concept to a sizeable number of its target audience, the results of which are used to inform decisions made by program producers. Quantitative methods are also used to project the number of audiences targeted to patronize the program.

 

 

Audience research for program concepts is relatively new in the local broadcast industry. Executives and producers still tend to rely more on their gut feel and experiences of success to decide on the viability of a new program. Also, the representativeness of the sample target audience used in the research sometimes comes into question, especially in quantitative research where scientific sampling methods cannot be properly implemented due to budget constraints. On the other hand, in qualitative methods, interviewees or discussants are usually recruited from a pool of subjects who are so used to participating in research that their inputs are sometimes biased towards what the producers want to hear. Written by Fernando A. Austria Jr

text:
Broadcast audiences are defined as the groups of people who are the intended recipients of media content. In understanding broadcast audiences, it is important to look at the power relationship between the medium and its audience. The questions asked are: (1) What power do the media have over audiences?; (2) What is the power of audiences over the media? Media, specifically radio and television, have an impact, effect, and influence on their audiences, but audiences also impact on, affect, and influence broadcast texts.

 

Impact refers to the immediate and initial reactions of audiences to broadcast text, which may be in terms of emotions and identification. While listening to or watching a broadcast program, audiences feel emotions which usually correspond to the context of the program text. The way audiences demonstrate their emotions ranges from the physical to the verbal. For example, some audiences have tears welling up in their eyes during dramatic moments or they laugh out loud at comical scenes in a sitcom. In the excitement brought about by the broadcast text, the audience roots for the protagonist of the program and even instructs him or her on how to avoid the antagonist. Often, these emotions are cathartic, giving audiences pleasure and gratification. There are also emotions that are counter-text which give pleasure. For instance, some audiences obtain pleasure in finding faults in the characters they see or enjoy the failure or misery of others, the classic example of which is when audiences laugh at a performer who slips on a banana peel.

 

Pleasure and gratification also come from identification. Audiences identify with the characters, situations, and stories that are presented in a broadcast program. Audiences find themselves sharing the same identity and experience of the characters in the text. They may also know somebody with the same characteristics. This allows the audience to sympathize with the character. Some begin to feel like the leading character in a drama because of shared trials. Identification can also be aspirational, where audiences wish and hope to become the character they listen to or watch, or to be situated in the context of the program. For example, while watching a game show, audiences want to experience winning the million-peso prize, and therefore root for the contestant.

 

Pleasure is the product of satisfying expectations from the broadcast program. It is in this pleasure that the media has power over its audiences. When audiences are emotionally hooked on a program or when they identify and share the trials and triumphs of media characters and personalities, audiences tend to patronize and continuously support the media product from where they derive pleasure and gratification. This leads to building viewership and developing higher ratings which are the goals of commercial broadcast. This partly explains the popular reception by audiences of long-running programs like the soaps Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), 1949-56, DZRH, and 1977-85, BBC 2, Flordeluna, 1979-84, RPN 9, and Anna Liza, 1980-85, GMA; the anthologies in which letter senders’ life are featured, such as Kahapon Lamang (Only Yesterday), 1976-86, and Lovingly Yours, Helen, 1980-96, both on GMA, and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), 1991 and still running, ABS-CBN; the comedy John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-90, RPN 9; and Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!), beginning in 1979 on RPN 9 until its present run on GMA, especially its 2015 monstrous hit, the AlDub phenomenon in the segment “Kalyeserye” (Street Series). Aldub stands for the split-screen love team of young star Alden Richards and dubsmash sensation Maine Mendoza.

 

Identification may lead to modeling. Although modeling does not directly benefit broadcast institutions, imitating the identity and behavior of the idols which audiences create and look up to speaks of the influence that media has on society and its values. Also, this predilection of commercial broadcast industries for providing pleasures and gratifications has been criticized as creating an escapist society where audiences run away from the realities of life instead of taking action to improve their conditions.

 

The beginnings of media research focused on the effects of media on audiences. Given that the context of this research is the scientific paradigm, early media researchers looked for direct effects of media on audiences, where media is the cause and audience behavior is the effect. Early assumptions using this paradigm gave rise to the “magic bullet theory” or the “hypodermic needle model” of media. This assumption suggests that the intended media messages are directly received and believed by audiences leading to direct response or behavioral changes. A common example of this model is the relationship between broadcast programs and social norms. For instance, the model indicates that exposure to crime and violence leads audiences to a similar lifestyle. Or exposure to a political advertisement prompts audiences to vote for the candidate promoted in the advertisement.

 

More empirical studies, however, negated the powerful effects of media. Through more scientific research, the “two-step flow model” of communication was developed. This model points to the intervention of an opinion leader before audiences directly accept a media message. In political campaigns, audiences are inclined to seek out opinion leaders or persons whose views they trust before deciding on which candidate to vote. Even in terms of lifestyle, audiences tend to seek insights from opinion leaders before buying clothes, appliances, and the like.

 

Later studies have weakened the cause-and-effect models of the power of media on audiences. For example, the agenda-setting theory argues that media does not have direct power to change audience opinion. Instead, media just has the power to set the issues that are in the minds of audiences. Even in marketing, media messages are not expected to directly affect buying behavior. Other selling strategies that do not necessarily employ the media are now used to sell products like direct marketing, guerrilla marketing, events, activation, public relations, and similar approaches. What is clear is the power of media to provide audiences with information. For example, announcements of suspension of classes and work due to impending typhoons directly lead to an audience response: students do not go to their schools and workers do not go to their offices.

 

The shift from the scientific to the cultural-critical paradigms of research moves away from fully accepting the direct outcomes of the media audience effects models. In the cultural-critical paradigm, the power of media lies in its role to contribute to other factors that influence audiences. These other factors include institutions and social structures like the church, government, and the family. Even individual persons or peer groups contribute to influence an audience’s beliefs and behavior. Given this point of view, media is only one among these institutions that play a vital and important role in reinforcing and altering beliefs and prompting or changing behavior. The audience’s meaning structures, cultural and social influences, and their capacity to evaluate and make choices greatly weaken the capacity of media’s direct effects.

 

Media can reinforce audiences’ lifestyles, view of the world, and ideologies. For instance, wearing the latest trends in fashion is a lifestyle-changing decision that is made by audiences because of their aspiration to be like their idols as well as what they see in stores and the opinions of their friends. Audiences may have a preconceived view of Paris as the city of love based on what other people say and not from their actual experience. Watching the Koreanovela Lovers in Paris, 2003, ABS-CBN, brings this notion to life, reinforcing an imagining of Paris as a place for romance. The belief that women are the “weaker sex” or that homosexuals are “sex-crazed” may have been learned from the family and the church, but media can make these beliefs seem natural or God-given through the stereotyping of these genders on broadcast programs. One may become environment-friendly and limit one’s carbon footprints as a result of environmental campaigns aired on radio and television, as well as efforts initiated by civil society groups, the government, and schools.

 

Audiences, on the other hand, also inform broadcast texts. The power of the audience comes from being an active audience, which comes in a variety of conceptions. This power allows the audience to impose norms or standards that they expect from media, alter broadcast programming, resist meanings intended by the producers of the show, create programs as alternative to mainstream media, and apply new meanings in media and text in their daily lives.

 

Giving feedback is an audience activity that pre-dates the actual conception of the active audience. Feedback reaches broadcast institutions in a variety of ways–from audiences directly writing to stations or through the social media to formal research results. The power of feedback through a concerted effort of audiences, advertising stakeholders, and other institutions was seen in the case of an episode of Willing Willie, aired on TV5 on 12 Mar 2011, in which host Willie Revillame prodded a six-year-old boy to gyrate to sexually provocative music like a “macho dancer” in his variety show. The intense response by the public forced TV5 to suspend Revillame and has resulted in sanctions against the program and the imposition of new norms or standards in the treatment of children in media, particularly the amendment to Article 17 (Quiz Shows, Contests, Public Participation Programs, and Promotions) of the Broadcast Code of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP).

 

The active audience, according to the uses and gratification theory, selects media and programs that provide them with satisfaction based on their socio-cultural and psychological wants and needs. This activity results in their choosing programs of their preference. Programs that are patronized by audiences gain and retain high ratings and therefore remain on air. Non-rating programs are forced to reformat, shift programming schedules or eventually sign out.

 

The encoding/decoding model of communication states that audiences interpret media messages according to their cultural background, economic status, and personal experiences. This gives the audience the power to resist the embedded meaning of a text that can influence their belief system. Moreover, this resistance can bring about collective action against the broadcast industries. In broadcasting, audiences are capable of participating in the creation of program content.

 

Even in the early days of radio, Dely Magpayo aka Tiya Dely, in her drama program Ito ang Inyong Tiya Dely (This is Your Aunt Dely), 1953, DZRH, asked her listeners to write her their experiences. In turn, the lives of selected letter senders are dramatized. Radio disc jockeys indulge radio listeners with their music requests. With the advent of short message services, audiences are asked to text in the endings they prefer for the dramas they patronize. With the Internet, audiences are capable of “produsage,” portmanteau of the words “production” and “usage.” Here, users of the medium create and exhibit their productions, providing an alternative programming to mainstream media. At times, these productions are picked up by the industry and incorporated into their programming. Also growing more common is the rise of internet stars, like Charmaine Clarice Relucio Pempengco, better known as Charice, who successfully transitioned to the mainstream media.

 

Audiences also have the power to find meaning in their everyday interaction with broadcast media and their content and, at times, subvert their intended and embedded meanings: the sound of a radio broadcast may provide companionship for somebody who is alone; commercial breaks that come almost regularly after 15 minutes of programming serve as a timekeeper; earplugs create a private space that suggests that the listener does not want to be disturbed; and parents have used the twists and turns of drama plot as teaching moments. Written by Fernando A. Austria Jr, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

 

Sources: Bull 2009; Carey 1989; Cohen 2001; Fiske 2003; Gauntlett 1995; Hall 2001; Hermes 2009; Jenkins 2004; Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas 2010; Kitzinger 2009; Lazarsfeld, Berelson, and Guadet 2003; Morley 2009; Mulvey 1973; Rayburn 1996; Signorielli and Morgan 1996; Stern 2010; Wirth and Schramm 2005.

text:
An award is a form of recognition bestowed on an exemplary work and an appreciation of artistic excellence of an individual, group, network or organization given by peers, an association or an institution. It is a measure of standards and values promoted by a group giving out the reward for outstanding achievements in the profession.

 

The first awards for meritorious works in broadcasting were the Citizens Awards for Television (CAT), initiated in 1964 by the Citizens Council for Mass Media (CCMM), formerly called the Citizens’ Council for Better Motion Pictures Television Committee, a civic organization that helped promote the improvement of mass media in the country. The first CAT awards were given in 1965 at the PhilAm Life Auditorium, with University of the Philippines (UP) President Carlos P. Romulo as its guest speaker. The first year of the CAT was assisted by the Asia Foundation (The Manila Chronicle Entertainment Guide 1965). CAT ended in 1972, when martial law was declared (Cinko 1983).

 

 

The first CAT awardees were Dakilang Panata (Noble Oath), Channel 9, best dramatic presentation in a continuing series; An Evening with Pilita, Channel 3, best variety program; Hamon sa Kampeon (Challenge to the Champion), Channel 3, best variety show for encouraging local talents; The Big News, Channel 5, best straight news reporting; Coffee with Valencia, Channel 5, best commentary; Fistorama, Channel 11, best sports program; Gemma Commentary, Channel 5, best special events; Sylvia La Torre, Channels 3 and 9, best performer; and DZAQ-TV Channel 3, station with best programming (The Manila Chronicle Entertainment Guide 1965).

 

Subsequent years included categories for TV director, news interview, scriptwriter, children’s program, business program, educational quiz show, documentary, art production, educational show, special events, public entertainment, public service, and supporting TV female and male performers (The Manila Chronicle Entertainment Guide 1967). Winners in subsequent years were the drama anthologies Salamisim (Reflections), Panagimpan (Dream), Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), and Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), the musical-variety shows Carmen on Camera, The Nida-Nestor Show, Lollipop Party, Hamon sa Kampeon, and Etsetera, Etsetera (Etcetera, Etcetera); directors Mitos Villareal and Lupita Aquino-Concio; actors and performers Marlene Dauden, Chichay, Pugo, Nida Blanca, Nestor de Villa, Bert Delfino, Rebecca Gonzales, Dely Magpayo, Pepe Pimentel; writers Marita Manuel, Virgilio Flores, Ading Fernando; and commentators Raul Manglapus, JV Cruz, Teodoro Valencia, and Maximo Soliven (The Manila Chronicle Entertainment Guide 1968).

 

The Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining (PATAS), also called the Philippine Academy for Television Arts and Sciences, gave the Sinag Awards from 1975 to 1978. PATAS was composed of members of the organizations Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) and the Broadcast Media Council (BMC), both headed by presidential spokesperson Teodoro Valencia. The KBP and BMC were composed of some members of the academe. The aim of PATAS was to boost excellence in the art and craft of television. It formed guilds of television artists like camera persons and technicians, but the project did not progress well. Internal disputes contributed to its demise in 1978, with the KBP and the BMC pulling out from PATAS (Fleras 1982).

 

First PATAS awardees included Nora Aunor and Maryo J. de los Reyes as most outstanding television actress and director, respectively, for Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora); Dolphy, Nida Blanca, and Ading Fernando, most outstanding comedy series actor, actress, and scriptwriter, respectively, for John en Marsha (John and Marsha), which also won the award for the most outstanding comedy series; Maan Hontiveros, Yogi Dominguez-Zaragosa, and Tina Revilla, most outstanding hosts for Ms. Ellaneous (Belen 2015; Mariano 1977; Pareja 1994). Winners in subsequent years included comedian actors Patsy, Pugo, and Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, and the comedy shows Baltic & Co. and My Son, My Son. The last of the awards handed out in 1978 included the Kalinangan Award, which went to Armida Siguion-Reyna (Fleras 1982).

The Archdiocese of Manila, through Archbishop Jaime Cardinal Sin, created in 1978 the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) to instill values that include love for and service to God, respect for the environment, positive Filipino values, and love for life. Outstanding men and women and their works in mass media are chosen by a body of more than 50 jurors appointed by the Archbishop of Manila. The jurors include academicians, civic and religious leaders, and the clergy. Winners are awarded a trophy called The Rock, a one-kilogram stone held on a wooden base with the staff of St Peter inscribed on it.

 

 

The first CMMA awardees for radio in 1978 were In Unum Deum (In One God), DZRH, best program; Err Ramos as best director for the drama program Kahapon Lamang (Only Yesterday); and Ric T. Santos, best writer for the drama episode “Buhay Pa Si Plato” (Plato Lives On), DWRV. The first awardees for television in 1978 were Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), BBC 2, best program in value formation; Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (My Fellow, My Compassion), GMA, best public service program; and Concert at the Park, PTV 4, best program for cultural development. New categories were introduced in 1979. The award for best TV program for human development and value formation went to the drama anthologies Fort Santiago, RPN 9, Pananagutan (Responsibility), GMA, Gulong ng Palad and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), both from BBC 2. Best children’s program went to Mario O’Hara’s Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro? (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), BBC 2. In 1980, new categories were added. Outstanding instructional series program was Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), PTV 4; outstanding documentary program was Bagong Sibol ang Gubat (The Forest is Budding), produced by the Bureau of Forest Development; outstanding TV magazine program was given to Metro Magazine; and the award for Metro Manila Commission Outstanding TV Program was given to Uncle Bob & Friends, GMA. In 1981, new awards were given. The outstanding variety program award went to Champoy, RPN 9, and the outstanding drama award was given to Panagimpan for its episode “The Neglected Mother,” PTV 4. In 2012, ABS-CBN’s Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) received the Hall of Fame Award for Best TV Drama Program.

 

 

A unique award for radio was the Lira Awards in 1982. It was the brainchild of RPN 9 general manager Felipe Medina Jr and chair of the awards committee Ray Pedroche. Its objective was to encourage excellence in the work of DWWW people on a network-wide basis and who themselves voted for their peers. Awards were classified into 18 categories. The first and last of the awards were handed out on 29 Dec 1982 at the Embassy Ballroom of Holiday Inn. Selected winners and the categories in which they won included Errol Dionisio, actor; Mely Mallari, actress; Emil Cruz, scriptwriter; Sabatini Fernandez, narrator/host and supporting actor; Lennie Santos, supporting actress; Mario O’Hara, director; Boy de Guzman, musical scorer; Jake Tagasa, sound effects; Primo Monteroso, recording technician; Filipinas Ballesteros, promising talent; Dely Magpayo, personality of the year; Haraya (Imagination) hosted by Tina Loy, program; Lennie, Sweet 16, unit drama; Flordeluna directed by Luz Fernandez, top billing drama; Mr. Lonely, top-rated drama; and Rod Marable, Salvio Lumagbas, Cencio de la Cruz, Vic Dy Echo, Alfred de Leon, and Dennis Abrilla, top account executives (Luarca 1983).

 

 

The Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) has been handing out the Star Awards for Television since 1987. The PMPC is composed of entertainment scribes coming mainly from the print medium, but has grown through the years to include writers from the broadcast industry. The PMPC was first headed by Danny Villanueva. The first awards were given to 31 categories, including the highest award, the Ading Fernando Memorial Award which went to Pilita Corrales. Best station with balanced programming went to GMA. Its first awardees were TV Patrol, best newscast; Noli de Castro and Tina Monzon-Palma, best male and female newscasters, respectively; Public Forum, best public affairs program; Dong Puno of Viewpoint, best public affairs program host; Batibot, best children’s show; Bodjie Pascua of Batibot, best children’s show host; Princess Punzalan, best new TV personality; Isip Pinoy (Filipino Psyche), best magazine show; Loren Legarda of PEP Talk, best magazine show host; Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (My Fellow, My Compassion), best public service program; Orly Mercado and Cielito del Mundo of Damayan (Helping One Another), best public service program hosts; See-True and Inday Badiday, best movie talk show and movie talk show host; Pilita Corrales and Bert Marcelo of Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion), best talent show hosts; Hapi House (Happy House), best comedy series; Dolphy of John en Marsha, best comedy actor; Nova Villa of Chicka, Chicka Chicks, best comedy actress; Lovingly Yours, Helen, best drama series; Helen Vela, best drama series host; Verdadero, best drama serial; Ronaldo Valdez of Maynila Ngayon (Manila Today), best drama actor; Coney Reyes of Coney Reyes on Camera, best drama actress; Dolphy: 25 Years Lang Ba? (Dolphy: Good for Only 25 Years?), best musical special; Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), best variety show; GMA Supershow, best musical variety show; Edu Manzano of Not So Late Night with Edu, best male variety show host; and Vilma Santos for Vilma! and Nora Aunor for Superstar, best female variety show hosts.

 

 

A significant award beginning in 1987 until 1999 came from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo at Telebisyon, or simply the Gawad, took the focus away from individual celebrities and programs; instead, it evaluated the integrity of programs in their entirety. It paid tribute to broadcast production companies and artists whose works reflect Filipino values, ways of life, arts, and culture. Every year, it honored 10 outstanding television works, and gave awards to outstanding radio documentaries, drama, cultural programs, and musicals.

 

Each year, different respected artists designed and sculpted the trophies for the Gawad. The trophy for the first Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon for 1987 was sculpted by Julie Lluch. The first trophy for the first Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo for 1989 was a bronze and wood sculpture by Abdulmari Asia Imao, patterned after the Ibong Adarna. Sculptors whose works served as trophies for the Gawad were Ramon Orlina, Solomon Saprid, Agnes Arellano, Napoleon Abueva, Peter de Guzman, Roberto Villanueva, Imelda Pilapil, Charlie Co, Ed Castrillo, Edwin Wilwayco, and Arturo Luz.

 

The 10 outstanding television programs in the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon for 1987, handed out in 1988, were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing for You), RPN 9, and Kuh By Special Arrangement, IBC 13; the educational show Ating Alamin (Let’s Find Out), PTV 4; the children’s program Batibot, PTV 4 and RPN 9; the documentary magazine programs Isip Pinoy, RPN 9, and PEP Talk, ABS-CBN; the talk-public service shows Public Forum, IBC 13, and Straight from the Shoulder and Viewpoint, both on GMA; and the gag comedy show Sic O’Clock News, IBC 13. Best TV specials were People-Powered Presidency and Inside Congress. Tina Monzon-Palma was the first recipient of the Significant Individual Contribution to Television.

 

The first Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo awardees for 1989, given out in 1990, were Parangal (Honor), documentary, DZRM-Philippine Broadcasting System; Drama Filipina, drama, DZEC-Eagle Broadcasting Corporation; and the musical magazine Yukbo sa Musika (In Praise of Music), DYMR-Radyo ng Bayan Cebu, and Salamin sa Kaliwat (Mirror of Generations), DXWG-IBC Mindanao. Francisco “Koko” Trinidad received the first Natatanging Parangal sa Radyo. The first recipients of the Gawad para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon sa Radyo were Norma Balaoro Remo of DZRM, the Arts Research and Training Institute in Southern Tagalog, the cultural magazine Filipiniana from DWLC Radyo ng Bayan in Lucena City, and radio stations DZRM Philippine Broadcasting Service, DYRP Radyo Tagring of Allied Broadcasting Center in Iloilo City, and DYFM Radyo Bombo of Consolidated Broadcasting Corporation in Iloilo City.

 

Winners in the subsequent years of the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon were the drama shows Balintataw, PTV 4, Lovingly Yours, Helen, GMA, Dear Teacher, Islands TV 13, Spotlight, GMA, Handog ng PETA (Offering of PETA), RPN 9, and Bayani (Hero) and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), both on ABS-CBN; the talk show Mel & Jay, ABS-CBN; the musical program Ryan Ryan Musikahan (Music with Ryan), ABS-CBN; the documentary magazine The Probe Team, GMA; the public service programs Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), Hoy! Gising (Hey! Wake Up), both on ABS-CBN, Action 9, RPN 9, and Dong Puno Live, GMA; the news program The World Tonight, ABS-CBN; the cultural magazine-talk programs Travel Time, IBC 13 and GMA, For Art’s Sake, PTV 4, Tatak Pilipino (Filipino Trademark), ABS-CBN, By Design, ABC 5, and Teysi ng Tahanan (Tessie, The Home Buddy), ABS-CBN; the education programs Negosiyete (Business at Seven), GMA, Business Today, GMA, and Usapang Business (Business Talk), ABS-CBN; the children’s shows Pin Pin, PTV 4, 5 and Up, ABC 5, and Sineskwela (School on Air) and Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), both on ABS-CBN; the comedy shows Mongolian Barbecue, IBC 13 and RPN 9, Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), ABS-CBN, and Buddy en Sol, RPN 9; and the musical variety Sa Linggo nAPO Sila (They Will Be Here Sunday), ABS-CBN.

 

 

Individuals who were honored by the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon for their contributions to broadcast arts were Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Al Quinn, Gus Cabrera, Randy David, Gerry Geronimo, Hilda Kornel, Ricardo Puno, Rosa Rosal, Jessica Soho, Jun Mabborang, Ric Villegas, Lydia Brown, Ryan Cayabyab, Menardo Jimenez, Rene Villanueva, John Noseñas, Ben Aniceto, Fr James Reuter, SJ, Helen Vela, Antonio C. Barreiro, Amparo Custodio Moya aka Chichay, Cecilia L. Lazaro, Lupita Aquino- Kashiwahara, and Feny de los Angeles-Bautista.

 

The KBP began honoring its member organizations with an award called the Golden Dove Awards beginning in 1991. It aimed to set high professional standards in the broadcast media and to promote more responsible broadcasting. GMA has been ineligible for the awards since having withdrawn its membership from KBP in 2003. The first awardees of the Golden Dove were GMA, best television station in Metro Manila; DZRH Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC), best AM radio station in Metro Manila; DYHP Radio Mindanao Network, best provincial AM radio station; The World Tonight, ABS-CBN, best TV news program in Metro Manila; Balitang Bayan Numero Uno (National News First Edition), DZRH, best radio news program in Metro Manila; Damdaming Bayan (National Sentiment), DZBR Kumintang Broadcasting System, best provincial radio news program; Viewpoint, GMA, best TV public affairs program in Metro Manila; Liberty in Action, DZRH, best radio public affairs program in Metro Manila; Kapihan sa Sugarland (Coffee Shop in Sugarland), DYRL Radyo Pilipino Corporation, best provincial radio public affairs program; Batibot, PTV 4, best TV children’s program; Inang Bayan (Mother Country), ABS-CBN, best TV developmental information plug; and Manang Rose (Sister Rose), GMA, best radio developmental information plug. Categories for various types of programs were included beginning in the second Golden Dove Awards.

 

The first winner of the Golden Dove Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year was Jessica Soho, GMA. Subsequent Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year awardees included Jose Mari Velez, GMA; Ricardo Dong Puno Jr, GMA; Francisco “Koko” Trinidad; Abelardo L. Yabut Sr; Loren Legarda, ABS-CBN; Cheche Lazaro, GMA; Mel Tiangco, GMA; Solita Monsod, GMA; Luchi Cruz-Valdes, GMA and TV 5; Tina Monzon-Palma, ABS-CBN; Reynante “Rey” Langit, DWIZ Aliw Broadcasting Corporation; Angelo Castro, ABS-CBN; Joe Taruc, DZRH; Korina Sanchez, ABS-CBN; Ces Drilon, ABS-CBN; Noli de Castro, ABS-CBN; Ted Failon, ABS-CBN; and Angelo Palmones, MBC.

 

The KBP conferred the first Lifetime Achievement Award in 1996 to Abelardo L. Yabut Sr. Other recipients of the award were Henry Canoy, Radio Mindanao Network; Menardo R. Jimenez, GMA; Eugenio Lopez Jr, ABS-CBN; Federico M. Garcia, ABS-CBN; Fred J. Elizalde, Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC); Emmanuel Galang, GV Broadcasting System; Fidela Magpayo aka Tiya Dely, DZRH-MBC; Francisco “Ka Kiko” Evangelista, DZMM/ABS-CBN; Jorge Bayona, PBN Broadcasting Network; Arcadio M. Carandang, Molave Broadcasting Network; Rogelio Florete, Bombo Radyo Philippines; Antonio Barreiro (posthumous); Guillermo Torres Sr (posthumous), UM Broadcasting Network; Fernando Ma. Alberto (posthumous), KBP legal counsel; Rino M. Basilio, ABC 5; Q. Rebueno Hodreal (posthumous), United Broadcasting Network; Bob Stewart (posthumous), GMA; Fr James B. Reuter, SJ, Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines; Cerge M. Remondo (posthumous); Manuel Galvez, Vanguard Radio Network; Eduardo Montilla (posthumous); Charo Santos-Concio, ABS-CBN; Eugenio “Gabby” Lopez III, ABS-CBN; Larry Henares, Progressive Broadcasting Corporation; and Antonio L. Cabangon, Aliw Broadcasting Corporation.

 

In 1996, the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children and Television, which became popularly known as the Anak TV Group, was formed, with Gina Lopez of ABS-CBN as its first president. It is an advocacy organization that promotes TV literacy and pushes for child-sensitive and family-friendly television programs in the Philippines. It started giving out the Anak TV Seal Awards in 2000. Programs are judged based on moral slant, artistic merit, educational content, and cultural relevance. The screening process is multitiered and done in different regions of the country. The jury, numbering about 2000, is composed of representatives from different sectors who are also considered stakeholders of TV programming: parents, educators, business and media people, government, nongovernment organizations, the religious sector, psychologists, mass media and literary scholars, and the youth (Manila Standard 2002; Adobo Magazine 2011; Anak TV Web 2015). It conferred honors to 15 awardees in 2000 and has grown to 109 in 2014 (Anak TV Web 2015).

 

In 2004, a faction of the PMPC, dissatisfied with the organization’s leadership and choices for its awards, broke away from the organization and formed a new group. Calling itself the Entertainment Press Society, this new group of entertainment writers from the print medium created the Golden Screen TV Awards, also in the same year (kikayjack 2004). For its first seven years, it gave recognition to 29 categories of entertainment shows and personalities only (Lo 2004). In 2011, it included recognitions for news programs and anchors. It now has 50 awards for different categories of television programs and artists. The highest honor, called the Helen Vela Lifetime Achievement Award, named after radio drama announcer and TV host Helen Vela, is given to distinguished achievements of personalities in drama, comedy, and news program. The first recipients of the Helen Vela Lifetime Achievement Award were Nora Aunor for drama, Harry Gasser for news broadcasting, and Joey de Leon for comedy (Lo 2004).

 

Annual student awards for works in radio and television broadcast sprung up like mushrooms in the mid-2000s, beginning with the University of Santos Tomas USTV Students Choice Awards, 2005. This was followed by the Gandingan Awards: The University of the Philippines at Los Baños Isko’t Iska Broadcast Choice Awards, 2007; the Northwest Samar State University Students Choice Awards, 2009; the Paragala Central Luzon Media Awards of the Holy Angel University in Pampanga, 2014; the Mabini Awards of the Polytechnic University of the Philippines, 2014; the UmalohokJuan! Awards from the Lyceum of the Philippines, 2014; and the Gawad Kamalayan Awards from the Mapua Institute of Technology.

 

The academe has honored excellent works in the broadcast media. The Gawad Tanglaw began giving out awards in the field; Tanglaw stands for Tagapuring mga Akademisyan ng Aninong Gumagalaw, a group of media teachers from Jose Rizal University, the Philippine Women’s University, the University of Perpetual Help System, and the Colegio de San Juan de Letran.

 

The most prestigious academe-based awards are the Gawad Plaridel of the UP System through the College of Mass Communication in UP Diliman and the Hildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communication of St Scholastica’s College. Gawad Plaridel is an annual award given by UP to outstanding practitioners in print, film, radio, television, community media, and transmedia who have performed with the highest level of professional integrity in the interest of public service. Awardees deliver the Plaridel Lecture. The recognition comes with a trophy sculpted by National Artist Napoleon V. Abueva. Plaridel is the nom-de-plume of propagandist Marcelo H. del Pilar. Awardees for radio were Fidela Mendoza-Magpayo aka Tiya Dely, 2006, and radio drama talent, director, and writer Eloisa Cruz-Canlas, 2011. Awardees for television were producer and investigative journalist Cecilia “Cheche” Lazaro, 2007, and public servant and actor Florence Danon-Gayda aka Rosa Rosal, 2012. The awardee for transmedia (film, music, and television) was Nora Aunor, 2014.

 

The Hildegarde Awards, named after Saint Hildegarde of the Order of Saint Benedictine, honors excellent media works about women, which St Scholastica’s College handed out beginning in 2007. First awardees included QTV Channel 11 for its women-centered programs like Women’s Desk and Moms, Feny Bautista for educational children’s programs, Nora Quebral for development communication, and radio scriptwriter Genoveva “Lola Bebang” Matute. Each year, different women artists sculpt the trophy of the awards. Examples included the trophies called Ina-Anga (Mother and Child) by Elsie “Inday” Cadapan and The Goddess at Sunrise by Agnes Arellano.

 

International award-giving bodies have recognized excellent works in radio and television from the Philippines. The George Foster Peabody Awards, established in 1940 and considered the Pulitzer Prize for recognizing excellence in electronic media, are administered by the University of Georgia’s Henry W. Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication. Winning requires a unanimous vote from the 16-member board composed of media industry professionals, media scholars, critics, and journalists. GMA is the only network from the Philippines to have received this award. It has won four times: the Institutional Award for Investigative Reporting for the network’s programs i-Witness for its episode “Kidneys for Sale” and Brigada Siete (News Brigade on Seven) for its episode “Kamao” (Fist), 1999; i-Witness for its episode “Ambulansyang de Paa” (Ambulance on Foot), 2009; Reel Time for its episode “Salat” (Famished), 2012; and for the coverage of super typhoon Yolanda by its news programs 24 Oras (24 Hours), 24 Oras Weekend (24 Hours on Weekend), Saksi (Witness), State of the Nation, and Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho), 2013 (The Peabody Awards Website).

 

Philippine radio and television programs have also won in The New York Festivals, an international competition for best works in radio, television, film, advertising, and marketing from broadcast stations, networks, film producers, and independent artists and producers from around the globe. Two Filipino radio programs have won the New York Festivals for Radio. The drama-talk program Pitlag! Kuwento ng Buhay, Isyu ng Bayan (Jolt! Stories of Life, Issues of the Nation), first on Radio Veritas, then on RMN, won the Bronze in 2003 for the episode “Giyera sa Dibdib ni Nana Dolor” (War in Nana Dolor’s Heart), 2003. DZMM Radyo Patrol 630 bagged the Silver in the Breaking News Story category, 2008, for its special coverage of the Luneta hostage drama (Dimaculangan 2008).

 

The New York Festivals for Television has been won by GMA and ABS-CBN. The Grand Award and the UNESCO Prize Silver Medal was Minsan Lang Sila Bata (Children Only Once aka No Time for Play), GMA, 1999. GMA has won the Gold World Medal for Minsan Lang Sila Bata, 1999; i-Witness for the episode “Boy Pusit” (Boy Squid), 2007; Reporter’s Notebook for “Batang Kalakal” (Child for Sale), 2008; 24 Oras for “Corporal Abeto,” 2009; Tunay na Buhay (Real Life) for “Mga Sanggol at Langaw” (Infants and Flies), 2014; and Front Row for “Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis,” 2015. The Silver World Medal has been received by i-Witness for “Mental,” 1999, “Dreams of Shelter,” 2000, “Unggoy” (Monkey), 2006, “Sa Mata ni Ekang” (Through Ekang’s Eyes), 2007, “Iskul Ko, No. 1” (My School, No. 1), 2008, “Huling Hala Bira” (The Last Ati-Atihan Dance), 2008, and “Lapnos” (Scald), 2012; 24 Oras for “Lanao del Norte Attacks,” 2009; Biyaheng Totoo (Real Journey), 2011; Front Row for “Bente Dos” (Twenty Two) and “Yaman sa Basura” (Wealth in Garbage aka Child Urban Miners), both in 2012; Reel Time for “Salat,” 2013, and “Silang Wala sa Mapa” (Off the Grid), 2014; and the children’s program Tropang Potchi (The Potchi Troop) and Brigada (Brigade) for the episode “Gintong Krudo at Sipa ng Pag-asa,” (Golden Diesel and the Kick of Hope) both in 2014. GMA has won the Bronze World Medal for Reporter’s Notebook for “Pinays for Export: The Asian Sex Trafficking Trail,” 2009; Planet Philippines, 2010; i-Witness for “Paraisong Uhaw” (A Parched Paradise) and the MTV Lupang Hinirang (The Philippine National Anthem), 2011; Front Row for “Lusong Dunong” (The School in the Swamps), the MTV Dapat Tama (Do It Right), and News TV Quick Response Team for the Zamboanga crisis coverage, all in 2014; and Motorcycle Diaries for “Karapatan ng Bata” (Rights of a Child), Reporter’s Notebook for “Burak at Pangarap” (Dregs and Dreams), and the station ID May Pag-asa (There is Hope), all in 2015. (New York Festivals Website)

 

ABS-CBN won the Gold World Medal of the New York Festivals for Bantay Bata 10th Anniversary Special, 2009, and its station ID A Call to Arms, 2013. It won the Silver World Medal for the promotion spot Halalan and the news magazine The Correspondents for the episode “Palobo Boys” (Rugby Boys), 2008; Bandila (Flag) for its report on substandard food supplements and the talk show Boy and Kris, 2009; the promotional material of Pagpag (Leftovers), 2010; Storyline, 2011; Johnny: The Juan Ponce Enrile Story, 2013; and the graphic design of Agosto Beinte-Uno: Ang Pagpatay kay Ninoy Aquino (August 21: The Killing of Ninoy Aquino), 2014. It won the Bronze World Medal for Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1992; the MTV Boto Mo, iPatrol Mo: Ako ang Simula (Patrol Your Vote: I am the Beginning), 2010; Storyline, 2011; Failon Ngayon (Failon Now) for the episode “Tagas ng Minahan” (Mine Leaks), 2014; and for cinematography for its coverage of typhoon Yolanda, 2015 (New York Festivals Website).

 

Two other groups have won the Gold World Awards of New York Festivals, both in 2009: QTV Channel 11 won for Inno Sotto: A Special Fashion Documentary, and the Power to Unite Catholic Family Bible Group won for Filipino through Music and Arts.

 

Another important award is the Asian Television Awards, which reward programming and production excellence in the television industry among Asian countries. It was first organized by the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation from 1987 to 1993. Beginning in 1994, the Television Asia Plus Magazine has been organizing the awards. It confers honors on 30 categories of television productions coming from free-to-air TV stations, pay-TV channels, and independent production houses in Asia. Chin Chin Gutierrez and Cherry Pie Picache were the first awardees from the Philippines, having won in the First Asian Television Awards for best drama actress and best supporting actress, respectively, for Melinda, 1996. Gutierrez won again, this time as best supporting actress for Desaparacido (Missing), 1998. In 2000, winners from the Philippines were Saksi (Witness), GMA, best news program, and Roderick Paulate for best performance by an actor for the episode “Wristwatch” of Maalaala Mo Kaya/MMK (Will You Remember), ABS-CBN. In 2001, winners were MMK, best single drama program, Raymond Bagatsing for the episode “Wedding Ring” of MMK, best drama performance by an actor, and A Christmas Special, best entertainment special, all from ABS-CBN; Saksi sa Kasaysayan (Witness to History), GMA, best news or current affairs special, and 5 and Up for its episode “Tulay ng Kulay” (Bridges of Color), best youth program, both from GMA; and Boy Iñiguez, best director of photography for Spring, Unitel Productions. In 2002, awardees were One Night with Regine, best music program, and Aiza Seguerra for the episode “Songbook” from MMK, best drama performance by an actress, both from ABS-CBN; and Donita Rose, MTV Southeast Asia, best light entertainment presenter. In 2003, Back-to-Back Christmas, GMA, won best entertainment special. In 2004, honors were conferred on Bubble Gang, best comedy program, and Michael V for Bubble Gang, best comedy performance by an actor, both from GMA; and Eula Valdez for the episode “Eatery” from MMK, ABS-CBN, best drama performance by an actress. In 2005, GMA programs won in various categories: i-Witness for its episode “Buto’t Balat” (Skin and Bones), best social awareness program; Eat Bulaga! Silver Anniversary Special (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!), best entertainment special; Nonie Buencamino for Magpakailanman (Forever) for its episode “Sa Kabila ng Karamdaman” (Beyond Illness: An AIDS Victim Story), best drama performance by an actor; Michael V for Bubble Gang, best comedy performance by an actor; and GMA for best terrestrial channel. In 2006. Michael V, for Bubble Gang, GMA, won again for best comedy performance by an actor. In 2007, awardees were Reporter’s Notebook for its episode “Giyera sa Lebanon” (War in Lebanon), GMA, best current affairs program; Bandila (Flag) for its report on the Subic rape case promulgation, ABS-CBN, best news program; and Gina Pareño for the episode “Rehas” (Prison) from MMK, ABS-CBN, best drama performance by an actress. In 2011, winners included The Bottomline with Boy Abunda, ABS-CBN, best talk show; and Christopher Ramos for best theme song of Star Confessions: Ito ang Buhay Ko (Star Confessions: This is My Life), TV5. In 2012, Chef vs. Mom, ABC/TV5, received the best lifestyle program.

 

Philippine broadcast works and personalities have won in other prestigious international award-giving bodies. The drama Lucia won the London Environmental Film Festival; the best developing country production award in the Ökomedia Filmfestival, an international environment film festival in Germany; and the premier award from One World Broadcasting Trust, all in 1992. The experimental film Kamada (State of Being), shown on national television, won in the Southeast Asian Television Awards in Singapore, 1997. Batibot and 5 and Up both won the Japan Prize in 1998. The Prix Jeunesse International was won by Lyka Benitez-Brown, 1990; and the educational children’s shows 5 and Up, GMA, 2001, Sineskwela (School on Air), ABS-CBN, 2003, and Salam (Peace), The Knowledge Channel, 2014. The Grand Prix Toutes Categories at the Festival International du Film Independant in Brussels went to the documentary Minsan Lang Sila Bata, GMA, 1998. The episode of The Correspondents, “Mt. Cook Chronicles: The Road to Everest,” won the Special Jury Prize at the Moscow International Festival of Mountaineering and Adventure Films in 2005. The UNICEF Asia-Pacific Child Rights Award was won by the documentary magazine i-Witness, GMA, for the episodes “Selda Inosente” (Innocent Prison), 2003, “Mga Batang Kalabaw” (Carabao Children), 2008, and “Alkansya” (Piggy Bank), 2012; the investigative documentary The Correspondents, ABS-CBN, for “Batang Preso” (Child Prisoner), 2005; the documentary show Reel Time, GMA News TV, for “Salat,” 2013; and the documentary program Front Row, GMA News TV, for “Ulilang Lubos” (Orphaned), 2014. The episode “Huling Hala Bira” (The Last Ati-Atihan Dance) of the documentary magazine i-Witness, 2007, won the UN Asia-Pacific Millennium Development Goals Media Awards. The telenovela Lobo (Werewolf), ABS-CBN, won the Rockie Award for the Telenovela in the Banff World Television Festival in Canada in 2009. The Population Development Media Awards for best TV documentary was given to Abner Mercado and his broadcast team in The Correspondents in 2009. The environmental documentary Planet Philippines, GMA, won the Telly Awards in 2011. Boy Abunda’s hosting of The Bottomline with Boy Abunda won for him the Asia Radio-TV Awards, 2014.

 

Significant institutions have recognized outstanding contributions by Filipino artists and personalities who have connections or have worked in the broadcast industry. The Rotary Club of Manila and International conferred awards for broadcast journalists and personalities like Cheche Lazaro, 1988, Jessica Soho, 2003, Kara David, 2004; Howie Severino, 2003, 2006-2008, Katrina Legarda, 2011, Maria Ressa, 2014. The Titus Brandsma Leadership in Journalism Award was given to Howie Severino, 2009, and Kara David, 2011.

 

Recipients of the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award of the Philippines who worked with the broadcast industry were Alberto Florentino, 1960; Max Soliven, 1960; Rodolfo Reyes, 1961; Francisco Trinidad, 1965; Carlos Arnaldo, 1971; Lino Brocka, 1975; Orly Mercado, 1978; Ryan Cayabyab, 1978; Manuel V. Broadcast artists, personalities, and journalists who have received The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service (TOWNS) Award were Boots Anson-Roa, 1974; Rosa Rosal, 1974; Nora Aunor, 1983; Jullie Yap Daza, 1983; Maria Montelibano, 1986; Lydia Brown, 1989; Cheche Lazaro, 1989; Mel Tiangco, 1992; Loren Legarda, 1995, Jessica Soho, 2001; Ces Drilon, 2004; Chin Chin Gutierrez, 2004; Maria Ressa, 2007; Kara David, 2010; Maria Ressa, 2007; and Karen Davila, 2013.

 

Howie Severino received the Davis-Latch Memorial Award, given annually in Bangkok to one young journalist in the Asia Pacific region, in 1991. Jessica Soho received the Fleet Award for Investigative Journalism by the British Embassy in Manila, 1998. The drama Bayan Ko (My Country), GMA, received the 12th Quill Award for Excellence from the International Business Communicators Philippines, 2013. Recipients of the Marshall McLuhan Fellowship of the Embassy of Canada in the Philippines, given to someone who embodies outstanding qualities in investigative journalism, who have worked in the broadcast industry were Luz Rimban, 2003; Gerry Lirio, 2006; Inday Espina Varona, 2007; Glenda Gloria, 2008; Ed Lingao, 2010; Malou Mangahas, 2013; Lynda Jumilla, 2014; Cheche Lazaro, 2014; and Joseph Morong, 2015.

 

The Ramon Magsaysay Award, the Asian equivalent of the Nobel Peace Prize, honors individuals who have excelled in their fields. Personalities and institutions that have received the award for their work in communication, with close links to broadcast are Cecille Guidote, 1972; Lino Brocka, 1985; Radio Veritas, 1986; Fr James Reuter SJ, 1989; Bienvenido Lumbera, 1993; Nick Joaquin, 1996; Rosa Rosal, 1999; and Grace Padaca, 2008. article.value: An award is a form of recognition bestowed on an exemplary work and an appreciation of artistic excellence of an individual, group, network or organization given by peers, an association or an institution. It is a measure of standards and values promoted by a group giving out the reward for outstanding achievements in the profession.

The first awards for meritorious works in broadcasting were the Citizens Awards for Television (CAT), initiated in 1964 by the Citizens Council for Mass Media (CCMM), formerly called the Citizens’ Council for Better Motion Pictures Television Committee, a civic organization that helped promote the improvement of mass media in the country. The first CAT awards were given in 1965 at the PhilAm Life Auditorium, with University of the Philippines (UP) President Carlos P. Romulo as its guest speaker. The first year of the CAT was assisted by the Asia Foundation (The Manila Chronicle Entertainment Guide 1965). CAT ended in 1972, when martial law was declared (Cinko 1983).

article.value: The Pambansang Akademya ng Telebisyon sa Agham at Sining (PATAS), also called the Philippine Academy for Television Arts and Sciences, gave the Sinag Awards from 1975 to 1978. PATAS was composed of members of the organizations Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) and the Broadcast Media Council (BMC), both headed by presidential spokesperson Teodoro Valencia. The KBP and BMC were composed of some members of the academe. The aim of PATAS was to boost excellence in the art and craft of television. It formed guilds of television artists like camera persons and technicians, but the project did not progress well. Internal disputes contributed to its demise in 1978, with the KBP and the BMC pulling out from PATAS (Fleras 1982).

First PATAS awardees included Nora Aunor and Maryo J. de los Reyes as most outstanding television actress and director, respectively, for Ang Makulay na Daigdig ni Nora (The Colorful World of Nora); Dolphy, Nida Blanca, and Ading Fernando, most outstanding comedy series actor, actress, and scriptwriter, respectively, for John en Marsha (John and Marsha), which also won the award for the most outstanding comedy series; Maan Hontiveros, Yogi Dominguez-Zaragosa, and Tina Revilla, most outstanding hosts for Ms. Ellaneous (Belen 2015; Mariano 1977; Pareja 1994). Winners in subsequent years included comedian actors Patsy, Pugo, and Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, and the comedy shows Baltic & Co. and My Son, My Son. The last of the awards handed out in 1978 included the Kalinangan Award, which went to Armida Siguion-Reyna (Fleras 1982).

The Archdiocese of Manila, through Archbishop Jaime Cardinal Sin, created in 1978 the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) to instill values that include love for and service to God, respect for the environment, positive Filipino values, and love for life. Outstanding men and women and their works in mass media are chosen by a body of more than 50 jurors appointed by the Archbishop of Manila. The jurors include academicians, civic and religious leaders, and the clergy. Winners are awarded a trophy called The Rock, a one-kilogram stone held on a wooden base with the staff of St Peter inscribed on it.

article.value: The first CMMA awardees for radio in 1978 were In Unum Deum (In One God), DZRH, best program; Err Ramos as best director for the drama program Kahapon Lamang (Only Yesterday); and Ric T. Santos, best writer for the drama episode “Buhay Pa Si Plato” (Plato Lives On), DWRV. The first awardees for television in 1978 were Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), BBC 2, best program in value formation; Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (My Fellow, My Compassion), GMA, best public service program; and Concert at the Park, PTV 4, best program for cultural development. New categories were introduced in 1979. The award for best TV program for human development and value formation went to the drama anthologies Fort Santiago, RPN 9, Pananagutan (Responsibility), GMA, Gulong ng Palad and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home), both from BBC 2. Best children’s program went to Mario O’Hara’s Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro? (Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?), BBC 2. In 1980, new categories were added. Outstanding instructional series program was Tele-Aralan ng Kakayahan (Knowledge Educational TV), PTV 4; outstanding documentary program was Bagong Sibol ang Gubat (The Forest is Budding), produced by the Bureau of Forest Development; outstanding TV magazine program was given to Metro Magazine; and the award for Metro Manila Commission Outstanding TV Program was given to Uncle Bob & Friends, GMA. In 1981, new awards were given. The outstanding variety program award went to Champoy, RPN 9, and the outstanding drama award was given to Panagimpan for its episode “The Neglected Mother,” PTV 4. In 2012, ABS-CBN’s Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) received the Hall of Fame Award for Best TV Drama Program.

article.value: A unique award for radio was the Lira Awards in 1982. It was the brainchild of RPN 9 general manager Felipe Medina Jr and chair of the awards committee Ray Pedroche. Its objective was to encourage excellence in the work of DWWW people on a network-wide basis and who themselves voted for their peers. Awards were classified into 18 categories. The first and last of the awards were handed out on 29 Dec 1982 at the Embassy Ballroom of Holiday Inn. Selected winners and the categories in which they won included Errol Dionisio, actor; Mely Mallari, actress; Emil Cruz, scriptwriter; Sabatini Fernandez, narrator/host and supporting actor; Lennie Santos, supporting actress; Mario O’Hara, director; Boy de Guzman, musical scorer; Jake Tagasa, sound effects; Primo Monteroso, recording technician; Filipinas Ballesteros, promising talent; Dely Magpayo, personality of the year; Haraya (Imagination) hosted by Tina Loy, program; Lennie, Sweet 16, unit drama; Flordeluna directed by Luz Fernandez, top billing drama; Mr. Lonely, top-rated drama; and Rod Marable, Salvio Lumagbas, Cencio de la Cruz, Vic Dy Echo, Alfred de Leon, and Dennis Abrilla, top account executives (Luarca 1983).

article.value: The Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) has been handing out the Star Awards for Television since 1987. The PMPC is composed of entertainment scribes coming mainly from the print medium, but has grown through the years to include writers from the broadcast industry. The PMPC was first headed by Danny Villanueva. The first awards were given to 31 categories, including the highest award, the Ading Fernando Memorial Award which went to Pilita Corrales. Best station with balanced programming went to GMA. Its first awardees were TV Patrol, best newscast; Noli de Castro and Tina Monzon-Palma, best male and female newscasters, respectively; Public Forum, best public affairs program; Dong Puno of Viewpoint, best public affairs program host; Batibot, best children’s show; Bodjie Pascua of Batibot, best children’s show host; Princess Punzalan, best new TV personality; Isip Pinoy (Filipino Psyche), best magazine show; Loren Legarda of PEP Talk, best magazine show host; Kapwa Ko, Mahal Ko (My Fellow, My Compassion), best public service program; Orly Mercado and Cielito del Mundo of Damayan (Helping One Another), best public service program hosts; See-True and Inday Badiday, best movie talk show and movie talk show host; Pilita Corrales and Bert Marcelo of Ang Bagong Kampeon (The New Champion), best talent show hosts; Hapi House (Happy House), best comedy series; Dolphy of John en Marsha, best comedy actor; Nova Villa of Chicka, Chicka Chicks, best comedy actress; Lovingly Yours, Helen, best drama series; Helen Vela, best drama series host; Verdadero, best drama serial; Ronaldo Valdez of Maynila Ngayon (Manila Today), best drama actor; Coney Reyes of Coney Reyes on Camera, best drama actress; Dolphy: 25 Years Lang Ba? (Dolphy: Good for Only 25 Years?), best musical special; Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!), best variety show; GMA Supershow, best musical variety show; Edu Manzano of Not So Late Night with Edu, best male variety show host; and Vilma Santos for Vilma! and Nora Aunor for Superstar, best female variety show hosts.
