article.value: A significant award beginning in 1987 until 1999 came from the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo at Telebisyon, or simply the Gawad, took the focus away from individual celebrities and programs; instead, it evaluated the integrity of programs in their entirety. It paid tribute to broadcast production companies and artists whose works reflect Filipino values, ways of life, arts, and culture. Every year, it honored 10 outstanding television works, and gave awards to outstanding radio documentaries, drama, cultural programs, and musicals.

Each year, different respected artists designed and sculpted the trophies for the Gawad. The trophy for the first Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon for 1987 was sculpted by Julie Lluch. The first trophy for the first Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo for 1989 was a bronze and wood sculpture by Abdulmari Asia Imao, patterned after the Ibong Adarna. Sculptors whose works served as trophies for the Gawad were Ramon Orlina, Solomon Saprid, Agnes Arellano, Napoleon Abueva, Peter de Guzman, Roberto Villanueva, Imelda Pilapil, Charlie Co, Ed Castrillo, Edwin Wilwayco, and Arturo Luz.

The 10 outstanding television programs in the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon for 1987, handed out in 1988, were the musicals Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing for You), RPN 9, and Kuh By Special Arrangement, IBC 13; the educational show Ating Alamin (Let’s Find Out), PTV 4; the children’s program Batibot, PTV 4 and RPN 9; the documentary magazine programs Isip Pinoy, RPN 9, and PEP Talk, ABS-CBN; the talk-public service shows Public Forum, IBC 13, and Straight from the Shoulder and Viewpoint, both on GMA; and the gag comedy show Sic O’Clock News, IBC 13. Best TV specials were People-Powered Presidency and Inside Congress. Tina Monzon-Palma was the first recipient of the Significant Individual Contribution to Television.

The first Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo awardees for 1989, given out in 1990, were Parangal (Honor), documentary, DZRM-Philippine Broadcasting System; Drama Filipina, drama, DZEC-Eagle Broadcasting Corporation; and the musical magazine Yukbo sa Musika (In Praise of Music), DYMR-Radyo ng Bayan Cebu, and Salamin sa Kaliwat (Mirror of Generations), DXWG-IBC Mindanao. Francisco “Koko” Trinidad received the first Natatanging Parangal sa Radyo. The first recipients of the Gawad para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon sa Radyo were Norma Balaoro Remo of DZRM, the Arts Research and Training Institute in Southern Tagalog, the cultural magazine Filipiniana from DWLC Radyo ng Bayan in Lucena City, and radio stations DZRM Philippine Broadcasting Service, DYRP Radyo Tagring of Allied Broadcasting Center in Iloilo City, and DYFM Radyo Bombo of Consolidated Broadcasting Corporation in Iloilo City.

Winners in the subsequent years of the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon were the drama shows Balintataw, PTV 4, Lovingly Yours, Helen, GMA, Dear Teacher, Islands TV 13, Spotlight, GMA, Handog ng PETA (Offering of PETA), RPN 9, and Bayani (Hero) and Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), both on ABS-CBN; the talk show Mel & Jay, ABS-CBN; the musical program Ryan Ryan Musikahan (Music with Ryan), ABS-CBN; the documentary magazine The Probe Team, GMA; the public service programs Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation), Hoy! Gising (Hey! Wake Up), both on ABS-CBN, Action 9, RPN 9, and Dong Puno Live, GMA; the news program The World Tonight, ABS-CBN; the cultural magazine-talk programs Travel Time, IBC 13 and GMA, For Art’s Sake, PTV 4, Tatak Pilipino (Filipino Trademark), ABS-CBN, By Design, ABC 5, and Teysi ng Tahanan (Tessie, The Home Buddy), ABS-CBN; the education programs Negosiyete (Business at Seven), GMA, Business Today, GMA, and Usapang Business (Business Talk), ABS-CBN; the children’s shows Pin Pin, PTV 4, 5 and Up, ABC 5, and Sineskwela (School on Air) and Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), both on ABS-CBN; the comedy shows Mongolian Barbecue, IBC 13 and RPN 9, Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), ABS-CBN, and Buddy en Sol, RPN 9; and the musical variety Sa Linggo nAPO Sila (They Will Be Here Sunday), ABS-CBN.

Individuals who were honored by the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon for their contributions to broadcast arts were Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Al Quinn, Gus Cabrera, Randy David, Gerry Geronimo, Hilda Kornel, Ricardo Puno, Rosa Rosal, Jessica Soho, Jun Mabborang, Ric Villegas, Lydia Brown, Ryan Cayabyab, Menardo Jimenez, Rene Villanueva, John Noseñas, Ben Aniceto, Fr James Reuter, SJ, Helen Vela, Antonio C. Barreiro, Amparo Custodio Moya aka Chichay, Cecilia L. Lazaro, Lupita Aquino- Kashiwahara, and Feny de los Angeles-Bautista.

The KBP began honoring its member organizations with an award called the Golden Dove Awards beginning in 1991. It aimed to set high professional standards in the broadcast media and to promote more responsible broadcasting. GMA has been ineligible for the awards since having withdrawn its membership from KBP in 2003. The first awardees of the Golden Dove were GMA, best television station in Metro Manila; DZRH Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC), best AM radio station in Metro Manila; DYHP Radio Mindanao Network, best provincial AM radio station; The World Tonight, ABS-CBN, best TV news program in Metro Manila; Balitang Bayan Numero Uno (National News First Edition), DZRH, best radio news program in Metro Manila; Damdaming Bayan (National Sentiment), DZBR Kumintang Broadcasting System, best provincial radio news program; Viewpoint, GMA, best TV public affairs program in Metro Manila; Liberty in Action, DZRH, best radio public affairs program in Metro Manila; Kapihan sa Sugarland (Coffee Shop in Sugarland), DYRL Radyo Pilipino Corporation, best provincial radio public affairs program; Batibot, PTV 4, best TV children’s program; Inang Bayan (Mother Country), ABS-CBN, best TV developmental information plug; and Manang Rose (Sister Rose), GMA, best radio developmental information plug. Categories for various types of programs were included beginning in the second Golden Dove Awards.

The first winner of the Golden Dove Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year was Jessica Soho, GMA. Subsequent Ka Doroy Broadcaster of the Year awardees included Jose Mari Velez, GMA; Ricardo Dong Puno Jr, GMA; Francisco “Koko” Trinidad; Abelardo L. Yabut Sr; Loren Legarda, ABS-CBN; Cheche Lazaro, GMA; Mel Tiangco, GMA; Solita Monsod, GMA; Luchi Cruz-Valdes, GMA and TV 5; Tina Monzon-Palma, ABS-CBN; Reynante “Rey” Langit, DWIZ Aliw Broadcasting Corporation; Angelo Castro, ABS-CBN; Joe Taruc, DZRH; Korina Sanchez, ABS-CBN; Ces Drilon, ABS-CBN; Noli de Castro, ABS-CBN; Ted Failon, ABS-CBN; and Angelo Palmones, MBC.

The KBP conferred the first Lifetime Achievement Award in 1996 to Abelardo L. Yabut Sr. Other recipients of the award were Henry Canoy, Radio Mindanao Network; Menardo R. Jimenez, GMA; Eugenio Lopez Jr, ABS-CBN; Federico M. Garcia, ABS-CBN; Fred J. Elizalde, Manila Broadcasting Company (MBC); Emmanuel Galang, GV Broadcasting System; Fidela Magpayo aka Tiya Dely, DZRH-MBC; Francisco “Ka Kiko” Evangelista, DZMM/ABS-CBN; Jorge Bayona, PBN Broadcasting Network; Arcadio M. Carandang, Molave Broadcasting Network; Rogelio Florete, Bombo Radyo Philippines; Antonio Barreiro (posthumous); Guillermo Torres Sr (posthumous), UM Broadcasting Network; Fernando Ma. Alberto (posthumous), KBP legal counsel; Rino M. Basilio, ABC 5; Q. Rebueno Hodreal (posthumous), United Broadcasting Network; Bob Stewart (posthumous), GMA; Fr James B. Reuter, SJ, Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines; Cerge M. Remondo (posthumous); Manuel Galvez, Vanguard Radio Network; Eduardo Montilla (posthumous); Charo Santos-Concio, ABS-CBN; Eugenio “Gabby” Lopez III, ABS-CBN; Larry Henares, Progressive Broadcasting Corporation; and Antonio L. Cabangon, Aliw Broadcasting Corporation.

In 1996, the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children and Television, which became popularly known as the Anak TV Group, was formed, with Gina Lopez of ABS-CBN as its first president. It is an advocacy organization that promotes TV literacy and pushes for child-sensitive and family-friendly television programs in the Philippines. It started giving out the Anak TV Seal Awards in 2000. Programs are judged based on moral slant, artistic merit, educational content, and cultural relevance. The screening process is multitiered and done in different regions of the country. The jury, numbering about 2000, is composed of representatives from different sectors who are also considered stakeholders of TV programming: parents, educators, business and media people, government, nongovernment organizations, the religious sector, psychologists, mass media and literary scholars, and the youth (Manila Standard 2002; Adobo Magazine 2011; Anak TV Web 2015). It conferred honors to 15 awardees in 2000 and has grown to 109 in 2014 (Anak TV Web 2015).

In 2004, a faction of the PMPC, dissatisfied with the organization’s leadership and choices for its awards, broke away from the organization and formed a new group. Calling itself the Entertainment Press Society, this new group of entertainment writers from the print medium created the Golden Screen TV Awards, also in the same year (kikayjack 2004). For its first seven years, it gave recognition to 29 categories of entertainment shows and personalities only (Lo 2004). In 2011, it included recognitions for news programs and anchors. It now has 50 awards for different categories of television programs and artists. The highest honor, called the Helen Vela Lifetime Achievement Award, named after radio drama announcer and TV host Helen Vela, is given to distinguished achievements of personalities in drama, comedy, and news program. The first recipients of the Helen Vela Lifetime Achievement Award were Nora Aunor for drama, Harry Gasser for news broadcasting, and Joey de Leon for comedy (Lo 2004).

Annual student awards for works in radio and television broadcast sprung up like mushrooms in the mid-2000s, beginning with the University of Santos Tomas USTV Students Choice Awards, 2005. This was followed by the Gandingan Awards: The University of the Philippines at Los Baños Isko’t Iska Broadcast Choice Awards, 2007; the Northwest Samar State University Students Choice Awards, 2009; the Paragala Central Luzon Media Awards of the Holy Angel University in Pampanga, 2014; the Mabini Awards of the Polytechnic University of the Philippines, 2014; the UmalohokJuan! Awards from the Lyceum of the Philippines, 2014; and the Gawad Kamalayan Awards from the Mapua Institute of Technology.

The academe has honored excellent works in the broadcast media. The Gawad Tanglaw began giving out awards in the field; Tanglaw stands for Tagapuring mga Akademisyan ng Aninong Gumagalaw, a group of media teachers from Jose Rizal University, the Philippine Women’s University, the University of Perpetual Help System, and the Colegio de San Juan de Letran.

The most prestigious academe-based awards are the Gawad Plaridel of the UP System through the College of Mass Communication in UP Diliman and the Hildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communication of St Scholastica’s College. Gawad Plaridel is an annual award given by UP to outstanding practitioners in print, film, radio, television, community media, and transmedia who have performed with the highest level of professional integrity in the interest of public service. Awardees deliver the Plaridel Lecture. The recognition comes with a trophy sculpted by National Artist Napoleon V. Abueva. Plaridel is the nom-de-plume of propagandist Marcelo H. del Pilar. Awardees for radio were Fidela Mendoza-Magpayo aka Tiya Dely, 2006, and radio drama talent, director, and writer Eloisa Cruz-Canlas, 2011. Awardees for television were producer and investigative journalist Cecilia “Cheche” Lazaro, 2007, and public servant and actor Florence Danon-Gayda aka Rosa Rosal, 2012. The awardee for transmedia (film, music, and television) was Nora Aunor, 2014.

The Hildegarde Awards, named after Saint Hildegarde of the Order of Saint Benedictine, honors excellent media works about women, which St Scholastica’s College handed out beginning in 2007. First awardees included QTV Channel 11 for its women-centered programs like Women’s Desk and Moms, Feny Bautista for educational children’s programs, Nora Quebral for development communication, and radio scriptwriter Genoveva “Lola Bebang” Matute. Each year, different women artists sculpt the trophy of the awards. Examples included the trophies called Ina-Anga (Mother and Child) by Elsie “Inday” Cadapan and The Goddess at Sunrise by Agnes Arellano.

International award-giving bodies have recognized excellent works in radio and television from the Philippines. The George Foster Peabody Awards, established in 1940 and considered the Pulitzer Prize for recognizing excellence in electronic media, are administered by the University of Georgia’s Henry W. Grady College of Journalism and Mass Communication. Winning requires a unanimous vote from the 16-member board composed of media industry professionals, media scholars, critics, and journalists. GMA is the only network from the Philippines to have received this award. It has won four times: the Institutional Award for Investigative Reporting for the network’s programs i-Witness for its episode “Kidneys for Sale” and Brigada Siete (News Brigade on Seven) for its episode “Kamao” (Fist), 1999; i-Witness for its episode “Ambulansyang de Paa” (Ambulance on Foot), 2009; Reel Time for its episode “Salat” (Famished), 2012; and for the coverage of super typhoon Yolanda by its news programs 24 Oras (24 Hours), 24 Oras Weekend (24 Hours on Weekend), Saksi (Witness), State of the Nation, and Kapuso Mo, Jessica Soho (One with You at Heart, Jessica Soho), 2013 (The Peabody Awards Website).

Philippine radio and television programs have also won in The New York Festivals, an international competition for best works in radio, television, film, advertising, and marketing from broadcast stations, networks, film producers, and independent artists and producers from around the globe. Two Filipino radio programs have won the New York Festivals for Radio. The drama-talk program Pitlag! Kuwento ng Buhay, Isyu ng Bayan (Jolt! Stories of Life, Issues of the Nation), first on Radio Veritas, then on RMN, won the Bronze in 2003 for the episode “Giyera sa Dibdib ni Nana Dolor” (War in Nana Dolor’s Heart), 2003. DZMM Radyo Patrol 630 bagged the Silver in the Breaking News Story category, 2008, for its special coverage of the Luneta hostage drama (Dimaculangan 2008).

The New York Festivals for Television has been won by GMA and ABS-CBN. The Grand Award and the UNESCO Prize Silver Medal was Minsan Lang Sila Bata (Children Only Once aka No Time for Play), GMA, 1999. GMA has won the Gold World Medal for Minsan Lang Sila Bata, 1999; i-Witness for the episode “Boy Pusit” (Boy Squid), 2007; Reporter’s Notebook for “Batang Kalakal” (Child for Sale), 2008; 24 Oras for “Corporal Abeto,” 2009; Tunay na Buhay (Real Life) for “Mga Sanggol at Langaw” (Infants and Flies), 2014; and Front Row for “Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis,” 2015. The Silver World Medal has been received by i-Witness for “Mental,” 1999, “Dreams of Shelter,” 2000, “Unggoy” (Monkey), 2006, “Sa Mata ni Ekang” (Through Ekang’s Eyes), 2007, “Iskul Ko, No. 1” (My School, No. 1), 2008, “Huling Hala Bira” (The Last Ati-Atihan Dance), 2008, and “Lapnos” (Scald), 2012; 24 Oras for “Lanao del Norte Attacks,” 2009; Biyaheng Totoo (Real Journey), 2011; Front Row for “Bente Dos” (Twenty Two) and “Yaman sa Basura” (Wealth in Garbage aka Child Urban Miners), both in 2012; Reel Time for “Salat,” 2013, and “Silang Wala sa Mapa” (Off the Grid), 2014; and the children’s program Tropang Potchi (The Potchi Troop) and Brigada (Brigade) for the episode “Gintong Krudo at Sipa ng Pag-asa,” (Golden Diesel and the Kick of Hope) both in 2014. GMA has won the Bronze World Medal for Reporter’s Notebook for “Pinays for Export: The Asian Sex Trafficking Trail,” 2009; Planet Philippines, 2010; i-Witness for “Paraisong Uhaw” (A Parched Paradise) and the MTV Lupang Hinirang (The Philippine National Anthem), 2011; Front Row for “Lusong Dunong” (The School in the Swamps), the MTV Dapat Tama (Do It Right), and News TV Quick Response Team for the Zamboanga crisis coverage, all in 2014; and Motorcycle Diaries for “Karapatan ng Bata” (Rights of a Child), Reporter’s Notebook for “Burak at Pangarap” (Dregs and Dreams), and the station ID May Pag-asa (There is Hope), all in 2015. (New York Festivals Website)

ABS-CBN won the Gold World Medal of the New York Festivals for Bantay Bata 10th Anniversary Special, 2009, and its station ID A Call to Arms, 2013. It won the Silver World Medal for the promotion spot Halalan and the news magazine The Correspondents for the episode “Palobo Boys” (Rugby Boys), 2008; Bandila (Flag) for its report on substandard food supplements and the talk show Boy and Kris, 2009; the promotional material of Pagpag (Leftovers), 2010; Storyline, 2011; Johnny: The Juan Ponce Enrile Story, 2013; and the graphic design of Agosto Beinte-Uno: Ang Pagpatay kay Ninoy Aquino (August 21: The Killing of Ninoy Aquino), 2014. It won the Bronze World Medal for Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1992; the MTV Boto Mo, iPatrol Mo: Ako ang Simula (Patrol Your Vote: I am the Beginning), 2010; Storyline, 2011; Failon Ngayon (Failon Now) for the episode “Tagas ng Minahan” (Mine Leaks), 2014; and for cinematography for its coverage of typhoon Yolanda, 2015 (New York Festivals Website).

Two other groups have won the Gold World Awards of New York Festivals, both in 2009: QTV Channel 11 won for Inno Sotto: A Special Fashion Documentary, and the Power to Unite Catholic Family Bible Group won for Filipino through Music and Arts.

Another important award is the Asian Television Awards, which reward programming and production excellence in the television industry among Asian countries. It was first organized by the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation from 1987 to 1993. Beginning in 1994, the Television Asia Plus Magazine has been organizing the awards. It confers honors on 30 categories of television productions coming from free-to-air TV stations, pay-TV channels, and independent production houses in Asia. Chin Chin Gutierrez and Cherry Pie Picache were the first awardees from the Philippines, having won in the First Asian Television Awards for best drama actress and best supporting actress, respectively, for Melinda, 1996. Gutierrez won again, this time as best supporting actress for Desaparacido (Missing), 1998. In 2000, winners from the Philippines were Saksi (Witness), GMA, best news program, and Roderick Paulate for best performance by an actor for the episode “Wristwatch” of Maalaala Mo Kaya/MMK (Will You Remember), ABS-CBN. In 2001, winners were MMK, best single drama program, Raymond Bagatsing for the episode “Wedding Ring” of MMK, best drama performance by an actor, and A Christmas Special, best entertainment special, all from ABS-CBN; Saksi sa Kasaysayan (Witness to History), GMA, best news or current affairs special, and 5 and Up for its episode “Tulay ng Kulay” (Bridges of Color), best youth program, both from GMA; and Boy Iñiguez, best director of photography for Spring, Unitel Productions. In 2002, awardees were One Night with Regine, best music program, and Aiza Seguerra for the episode “Songbook” from MMK, best drama performance by an actress, both from ABS-CBN; and Donita Rose, MTV Southeast Asia, best light entertainment presenter. In 2003, Back-to-Back Christmas, GMA, won best entertainment special. In 2004, honors were conferred on Bubble Gang, best comedy program, and Michael V for Bubble Gang, best comedy performance by an actor, both from GMA; and Eula Valdez for the episode “Eatery” from MMK, ABS-CBN, best drama performance by an actress. In 2005, GMA programs won in various categories: i-Witness for its episode “Buto’t Balat” (Skin and Bones), best social awareness program; Eat Bulaga! Silver Anniversary Special (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!), best entertainment special; Nonie Buencamino for Magpakailanman (Forever) for its episode “Sa Kabila ng Karamdaman” (Beyond Illness: An AIDS Victim Story), best drama performance by an actor; Michael V for Bubble Gang, best comedy performance by an actor; and GMA for best terrestrial channel. In 2006. Michael V, for Bubble Gang, GMA, won again for best comedy performance by an actor. In 2007, awardees were Reporter’s Notebook for its episode “Giyera sa Lebanon” (War in Lebanon), GMA, best current affairs program; Bandila (Flag) for its report on the Subic rape case promulgation, ABS-CBN, best news program; and Gina Pareño for the episode “Rehas” (Prison) from MMK, ABS-CBN, best drama performance by an actress. In 2011, winners included The Bottomline with Boy Abunda, ABS-CBN, best talk show; and Christopher Ramos for best theme song of Star Confessions: Ito ang Buhay Ko (Star Confessions: This is My Life), TV5. In 2012, Chef vs. Mom, ABC/TV5, received the best lifestyle program.

Philippine broadcast works and personalities have won in other prestigious international award-giving bodies. The drama Lucia won the London Environmental Film Festival; the best developing country production award in the Ökomedia Filmfestival, an international environment film festival in Germany; and the premier award from One World Broadcasting Trust, all in 1992. The experimental film Kamada (State of Being), shown on national television, won in the Southeast Asian Television Awards in Singapore, 1997. Batibot and 5 and Up both won the Japan Prize in 1998. The Prix Jeunesse International was won by Lyka Benitez-Brown, 1990; and the educational children’s shows 5 and Up, GMA, 2001, Sineskwela (School on Air), ABS-CBN, 2003, and Salam (Peace), The Knowledge Channel, 2014. The Grand Prix Toutes Categories at the Festival International du Film Independant in Brussels went to the documentary Minsan Lang Sila Bata, GMA, 1998. The episode of The Correspondents, “Mt. Cook Chronicles: The Road to Everest,” won the Special Jury Prize at the Moscow International Festival of Mountaineering and Adventure Films in 2005. The UNICEF Asia-Pacific Child Rights Award was won by the documentary magazine i-Witness, GMA, for the episodes “Selda Inosente” (Innocent Prison), 2003, “Mga Batang Kalabaw” (Carabao Children), 2008, and “Alkansya” (Piggy Bank), 2012; the investigative documentary The Correspondents, ABS-CBN, for “Batang Preso” (Child Prisoner), 2005; the documentary show Reel Time, GMA News TV, for “Salat,” 2013; and the documentary program Front Row, GMA News TV, for “Ulilang Lubos” (Orphaned), 2014. The episode “Huling Hala Bira” (The Last Ati-Atihan Dance) of the documentary magazine i-Witness, 2007, won the UN Asia-Pacific Millennium Development Goals Media Awards. The telenovela Lobo (Werewolf), ABS-CBN, won the Rockie Award for the Telenovela in the Banff World Television Festival in Canada in 2009. The Population Development Media Awards for best TV documentary was given to Abner Mercado and his broadcast team in The Correspondents in 2009. The environmental documentary Planet Philippines, GMA, won the Telly Awards in 2011. Boy Abunda’s hosting of The Bottomline with Boy Abunda won for him the Asia Radio-TV Awards, 2014.

Significant institutions have recognized outstanding contributions by Filipino artists and personalities who have connections or have worked in the broadcast industry. The Rotary Club of Manila and International conferred awards for broadcast journalists and personalities like Cheche Lazaro, 1988, Jessica Soho, 2003, Kara David, 2004; Howie Severino, 2003, 2006-2008, Katrina Legarda, 2011, Maria Ressa, 2014. The Titus Brandsma Leadership in Journalism Award was given to Howie Severino, 2009, and Kara David, 2011.

Recipients of the Ten Outstanding Young Men (TOYM) Award of the Philippines who worked with the broadcast industry were Alberto Florentino, 1960; Max Soliven, 1960; Rodolfo Reyes, 1961; Francisco Trinidad, 1965; Carlos Arnaldo, 1971; Lino Brocka, 1975; Orly Mercado, 1978; Ryan Cayabyab, 1978; Manuel V. Pangilinan, 1983; Ricardo “Dong” Puno, 1985; Maria Montelibano, 1986; Oscar Orbos, 1988; Rene Villanueva, 1989; Lea Salonga, 1990; Loren Legarda, 1992; Jessica Soho, 1993; Feny de los Angeles Bautista, 1993; Malou Mangahas, 1994; Carlos Siguion-Reyna, 1995; Menardo Jimenez Jr, 1998; Gary Valenciano, 2001; Maria Ressa, 2002; Marissa Flores, 2004; Sharon Cuneta, 2004; Michael V, 2005; Rico Hizon, 2006; Kara David, 2007; Karen Davila; 2008; Vicky Morales, 2009; and Jiggy Manicad, 2012.

Broadcast artists, personalities, and journalists who have received The Outstanding Women in the Nation’s Service (TOWNS) Award were Boots Anson-Roa, 1974; Rosa Rosal, 1974; Nora Aunor, 1983; Jullie Yap Daza, 1983; Maria Montelibano, 1986; Lydia Brown, 1989; Cheche Lazaro, 1989; Mel Tiangco, 1992; Loren Legarda, 1995, Jessica Soho, 2001; Ces Drilon, 2004; Chin Chin Gutierrez, 2004; Maria Ressa, 2007; Kara David, 2010; Maria Ressa, 2007; and Karen Davila, 2013.

Howie Severino received the Davis-Latch Memorial Award, given annually in Bangkok to one young journalist in the Asia Pacific region, in 1991. Jessica Soho received the Fleet Award for Investigative Journalism by the British Embassy in Manila, 1998. The drama Bayan Ko (My Country), GMA, received the 12th Quill Award for Excellence from the International Business Communicators Philippines, 2013. Recipients of the Marshall McLuhan Fellowship of the Embassy of Canada in the Philippines, given to someone who embodies outstanding qualities in investigative journalism, who have worked in the broadcast industry were Luz Rimban, 2003; Gerry Lirio, 2006; Inday Espina Varona, 2007; Glenda Gloria, 2008; Ed Lingao, 2010; Malou Mangahas, 2013; Lynda Jumilla, 2014; Cheche Lazaro, 2014; and Joseph Morong, 2015.

The Ramon Magsaysay Award, the Asian equivalent of the Nobel Peace Prize, honors individuals who have excelled in their fields. Personalities and institutions that have received the award for their work in communication, with close links to broadcast are Cecille Guidote, 1972; Lino Brocka, 1985; Radio Veritas, 1986; Fr James Reuter SJ, 1989; Bienvenido Lumbera, 1993; Nick Joaquin, 1996; Rosa Rosal, 1999; and Grace Padaca, 2008.  (Elizabeth Enriquez Collection)

text:
Blocktime is measured airtime, handled or considered as a single unit. Blocktiming is the network practice of selling airtime to individuals or groups. A blocktimer is an individual or group that broadcasts programs over radio or television through airtime bought from broadcast networks. The blocktimer may be a journalist, an artist, a politician, a business group, a church organization, or any interest group. The blocktimer may sell advertising spots to sponsors in order to gain profit. Blocktimers play a significant social, economic, political, and cultural role in Philippine broadcasting.

 

Radio stations in the early 1930s earned revenues without the trouble of producing radio programs through blocktiming. Radio companies partitioned their airtime into 15-minute blocks which were opened up to interested buyers or blocktimers. Successful blocktimers then were performers or artists from the bodabil (vaudeville) or the komedya who knew the taste of the listening public. However, artistic talent must be combined with business acumen to succeed in blocktiming. Those who flourished in the early years had the flair to produce radio shows and to sell advertising spots to small enterprises. Such was the story of Ubaldo Andres, aka Conde Ubaldo, a moniker from his role in the komedya. Andres bought many 15-minute blocks of airtime in three radio stations that broadcast the variety programs he created. He also wrote, performed, and produced the ad spots of his clients who wanted to promote their products and services over radio. In contrast to big American multinational companies that sponsored network programs, his clients included a family-owned restaurant, a hardware, a local cosmetic brand, and a transport company. Another successful blocktimer in the 1930s was the couple Alejandro Villegas and Adela Fernando, more popularly known as Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan.

 

 

Blocktiming was the lifeblood of early Philippine television when networks did not produce their own TV programs but were mere keepers of airtime. Earnings came from advertising companies that sponsored specific time slots to air programs that fit the endorsement of their products. From the 1950s to the 1960s, such programs ran on Bolinao Electronics Corporation, later to become Alto Broadcasting Corporation (ABS) Channel 3. Examples were the drama program Flordeluna and the variety show Mahiwagang Kahon (Magic Box). Under ABS were game shows and variety programs like Pistang Caltex (Caltex Fiesta), Unahan sa Kampana (Rush to the Bell), Kualta Na (Money Now), Vi-Milk Party, and Your Show of Shows. In the 1960s, income from blocktiming supported the early years of Republic Broadcasting System Channel 7. Its owner, Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart, diligently approached small businessmen and modest companies, persuading them to buy blocktime with affordable advertising packages. Thus, it was a common practice for Stewart to cheerfully endorse various products and services in the children’s show Uncle Bob’s Lucky Seven Club.

 

Blocktimers during the martial law period were regulated by the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP), a body established by the government’s Department of Public Information. Successful blocktimers then were businessmen or individuals who had connections with the government. Blocktimers produced variety shows, drama anthologies, sitcoms, and sports programs.

 

In 1979, Television and Production Exponents, Inc, headed by Tony Tuviera, with the aid of politician Romy Jalosjos, produced the longest running noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!) on Kanlaon Broadcasting Station (KBS) Channel 9. Broadcast executive Salvador “Buddy” Tan also became a blocktimer after he resigned as general manager of KBS. He brought in foreign programs from the US and Japan like Twilight Zone, Voltron, Moonlighting, Transformers, G.I. Joe, Six Million Dollar Man, Wonder Woman, and Takeshi’s Castle.

 

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, blocktimers produced progressive talk shows and magazine programs that tackled political, social, and economic issues. Examples of such shows were Probe, hosted by Cheche Lazaro and produced by her group, The Probe Team; Isip Pinoy (Filipino Psyche), hosted by Charo Santos and Vic Sumulong, and produced by Lahing Kayumanggi Productions; and Womanwatch, hosted by Nikki Coseteng and produced by the Women’s Media Circle. There was the revival of pre-martial law shows like the drama program Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye) and the airing of the socially oriented drama anthology Handog ng PETA (Offering of PETA) produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association. On radio, the Citizens’ Alliance for Consumer Protection produced the weekly drama Pintig ng Konsyumer (Consumer Pulse) aired on DWXI-AM; the Philippine Peasant Institute produced the weekly talk-drama program Punlaan sa Himpapawid (Planting Seeds on Air) aired on DWAN-AM; the Tambuyog Development Center produced the daily talk program Radyo Lundayan (Lundayan Radio) aired on DZEC-AM, with Saturdays devoted to the radio adaptation of stories about issues of fishers, the environment, and other social issues written by noted and emerging writers; and the Pan-Philippine News and Information Network and Pathways Productions produced the daily drama program Pitlag! Kuwento ng Buhay, Isyu ng Bayan (Jolt! Stories of Life, Issues of the Nation), with a forum segment during Saturdays, aired on Radio Veritas, then on RMN radio stations nationwide.

 

In the mid-1990s, ABS-CBN, as the leading television network, started to consolidate capital by luring big advertisers to support station-produced programs on primetime TV slots. This move pushed blocktimers to early morning or late evening time slots. Programs on prime time were required to be station produced. The policy compelled ABS-CBN blocktimer Eat Bulaga! to move to GMA Network in 1995. Eat Bulaga! remained with GMA Network in the 2010s but the relationship is impermanent because TAPE Inc had to periodically sign blocktiming contracts with GMA.

 

Most blocktimers at the time bought airtime in sequestered stations, such as RPN Channel 9 and IBC Channel 13, or in the newly revived Associated Broadcasting Corporation Channel 5. But small TV entrepreneurs were forced to terminate their shows because of the shrinking advertising budget. The wider national and international reach of leading television networks like ABS-CBN and GMA Network attracted the support of big advertisers. In 2001, 66 percent of the 27 billion pesos spent by the ad agency Campaigns and Grey went to television, eight percent went to radio, and 16 percent to print. As advertising budget continued to shrink in the succeeding years, the big players got the biggest share while small media organizations suffered.

 

Even print media resort to blocktiming as a cost-effective way of expanding its reach. By the 2000s, the highly circulated Philippine Daily Inquirer (PDI) found itself on a crossroad, confronted by the TV medium’s popularity and the advent of online media. In response to this challenge, the PDI was relaunched as a multimedia organization backed up by a wide news-gathering network and reliable editorial support. In 2010, PDI created its online news and inaugurated Radyo Inquirer (Inquirer Radio) by purchasing the blocktime of DWRT-AM 990 kHz. Initially called DZIQ Radyo, it changed its name to Inquirer Radio 990 AM in 2013. The radio station has worldwide reach through live audio webcast.

 

Through blocktiming, a church group may effectively position itself in the media landscape. Ang Dating Daan (The Former Path) hosted by Eliseo Soriano started as a religious radio program in 1980 on DWWA. Soon, it expanded to other radio stations like DWAR, DZME, DZMB, DWAD, DZRD, DWAN, and DZXQ. Produced by members of the Church of God International, the program bought TV airtime on IBC Channel 13 in 1983. The show transferred to RJTV 29 in 1997 and to SBN 21 in 2000, the same year when the program was simulcast over RMN, DZRH, and 100 Radyo Natin radio stations. Ang Dating Daan moved to its own station, UNTV 37, in 2004.

 

Outside Metro Manila, blocktiming and blocktimers play conflicting roles in local society and politics. Blocktiming in the regions become brisk business before elections. Politicians favor buying blocks of airtime to broadcast their own sponsored programs hosted by paid media personalities. This media strategy is more effective than placing short political ads that cannot guarantee name recall and sufficient exposure. Economic control on blocktiming by powerful politicians affects the integrity of information which voters receive during the campaign period.

 

In Cebu, blocktimers on radio were a potent presence in the 1970s and the 1980s, the most popular of which was DYLA’s talk and public affairs program Saksak Sinagol (Pound, Push, and Mix), hosted by lawyers Miguel “Migs” Enriquez and Vic Villordon, with a huge listenership base in Cebu, Bohol, Samar, Leyte, Northern and Western Mindanao, Negros Oriental, and the Cebuano-speaking areas of Negros Occidental.

Meanwhile, the local Catholic station explained its decision to sell 17 hours of daily airtime because of limited manpower and lack of resources. The city government of Davao also has blocktime programs like Atoni Bay (This is Ours, Friend) in Radyo Ukay and Radyo Rapido. These blocktime programs utilize local government funds to allow people to ventilate their views and to educate citizens about government policies. At the same time, the programs also serve to strengthen the political influence of the Dutertes in Davao City.

 

Provincial radio stations experienced diminishing returns in advertising with the competition from television and the rise of new media. This situation opened the gates for the entry of new blocktimers, not only from the traditional politicians but also from civil society. These blocktimers produce shows that tackle peace building, alternative health, livelihood, and services to various sectors like women, children, elderly, peasants, workers, and overseas Filipino workers.

 

A grave concern is the killing of blocktimers who are advocates of human rights, activists for the environment, and promoters of good governance. The victims are determined media workers who use their blocktime programs to expose illegal loggers, human traffickers, politicians linked with corruption, and perpetrators of human rights violations. The Center for Media Freedom and Responsibility recorded 57 persons, excluding those killed in the Maguindanao massacre, who were slain from Jan 2002 to Jan 2013. Nearly 50 percent of the victims had blocktime programs on radio or television

Historically, blocktimers have been catalysts that carry new ideas, initiatives, and resources which fuel the development of radio and television in new directions. Written by Rosalie S. article.value: Blocktime is measured airtime, handled or considered as a single unit. Blocktiming is the network practice of selling airtime to individuals or groups. A blocktimer is an individual or group that broadcasts programs over radio or television through airtime bought from broadcast networks. The blocktimer may be a journalist, an artist, a politician, a business group, a church organization, or any interest group. The blocktimer may sell advertising spots to sponsors in order to gain profit. Blocktimers play a significant social, economic, political, and cultural role in Philippine broadcasting.

Radio stations in the early 1930s earned revenues without the trouble of producing radio programs through blocktiming. Radio companies partitioned their airtime into 15-minute blocks which were opened up to interested buyers or blocktimers. Successful blocktimers then were performers or artists from the bodabil (vaudeville) or the komedya who knew the taste of the listening public. However, artistic talent must be combined with business acumen to succeed in blocktiming. Those who flourished in the early years had the flair to produce radio shows and to sell advertising spots to small enterprises. Such was the story of Ubaldo Andres, aka Conde Ubaldo, a moniker from his role in the komedya. Andres bought many 15-minute blocks of airtime in three radio stations that broadcast the variety programs he created. He also wrote, performed, and produced the ad spots of his clients who wanted to promote their products and services over radio. In contrast to big American multinational companies that sponsored network programs, his clients included a family-owned restaurant, a hardware, a local cosmetic brand, and a transport company. Another successful blocktimer in the 1930s was the couple Alejandro Villegas and Adela Fernando, more popularly known as Andoy Balun-balunan and Dely Atay-atayan.

article.value: Blocktiming was the lifeblood of early Philippine television when networks did not produce their own TV programs but were mere keepers of airtime. Earnings came from advertising companies that sponsored specific time slots to air programs that fit the endorsement of their products. From the 1950s to the 1960s, such programs ran on Bolinao Electronics Corporation, later to become Alto Broadcasting Corporation (ABS) Channel 3. Examples were the drama program Flordeluna and the variety show Mahiwagang Kahon (Magic Box). Under ABS were game shows and variety programs like Pistang Caltex (Caltex Fiesta), Unahan sa Kampana (Rush to the Bell), Kualta Na (Money Now), Vi-Milk Party, and Your Show of Shows. In the 1960s, income from blocktiming supported the early years of Republic Broadcasting System Channel 7. Its owner, Robert “Uncle Bob” Stewart, diligently approached small businessmen and modest companies, persuading them to buy blocktime with affordable advertising packages. Thus, it was a common practice for Stewart to cheerfully endorse various products and services in the children’s show Uncle Bob’s Lucky Seven Club.

Blocktimers during the martial law period were regulated by the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP), a body established by the government’s Department of Public Information. Successful blocktimers then were businessmen or individuals who had connections with the government. Blocktimers produced variety shows, drama anthologies, sitcoms, and sports programs.

In 1979, Television and Production Exponents, Inc, headed by Tony Tuviera, with the aid of politician Romy Jalosjos, produced the longest running noontime show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!) on Kanlaon Broadcasting Station (KBS) Channel 9. Broadcast executive Salvador “Buddy” Tan also became a blocktimer after he resigned as general manager of KBS. He brought in foreign programs from the US and Japan like Twilight Zone, Voltron, Moonlighting, Transformers, G.I. Joe, Six Million Dollar Man, Wonder Woman, and Takeshi’s Castle.

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, blocktimers produced progressive talk shows and magazine programs that tackled political, social, and economic issues. Examples of such shows were Probe, hosted by Cheche Lazaro and produced by her group, The Probe Team; Isip Pinoy (Filipino Psyche), hosted by Charo Santos and Vic Sumulong, and produced by Lahing Kayumanggi Productions; and Womanwatch, hosted by Nikki Coseteng and produced by the Women’s Media Circle. In the mid-1990s, ABS-CBN, as the leading television network, started to consolidate capital by luring big advertisers to support station-produced programs on primetime TV slots. The policy compelled ABS-CBN blocktimer Eat Bulaga! to move to GMA Network in 1995. Eat Bulaga! remained with GMA Network in the 2010s but the relationship is impermanent because TAPE Inc had to periodically sign blocktiming contracts with GMA.

The wider national and international reach of leading television networks like ABS-CBN and GMA Network attracted the support of big advertisers. text:
Censorship is defined as “placing restrictions on publication and the presentation of books, plays, films, etc. to the public” (Black’s Law Dictionary 1999). It may be done by a number of persons or groups, including the government, mass media, or the author in the case of self-censorship. Government usually censors programs that contain messages that are deemed to be a serious threat to the existing political, social, or moral order. The government’s act of censorship against the media, or any form of expression, before actual publication or dissemination to the public, is called “prior restraint.” Mass media organizations may regulate the media products of their members to make sure that they follow standards of professionalism and rules collectively established for the common welfare of broadcast professionals. Lastly, radio and television producers, directors, marketers, and other managers may decide to edit their programs and products to avoid censorship or to get a more general rating for their shows. In this essay, only the first type of censorship will be discussed.

 

Broadcasting in the country, as well as all media, has experienced two distinct periods of censorship: Japanese Occupation during World War II and martial law. During the war, the Japanese took over all media to disseminate propaganda as well as to restrict the flow of information. Radio was particularly guarded as broadcast signals were deemed deadlier than bullets. [See Radio Broadcasting in the Philippines (1941-45).] During the martial law years, the Marcos government closed or took over privately-owned newspapers, magazines, radio and television stations, and other forms of media communications. Several prominent journalists across all mass media platforms were imprisoned on the basis of the perceived “aid and comfort” they gave political opponents. [See Radio and Television Broadcasting in the Philippines (1972-86).]

 

 

The closure and control of all forms of mass media, including broadcast, effectively denied to journalists and broadcasters the right to free speech, expression, and the press. The chilling effect on the remaining media workers in the field severely hampered the production of media content because of the power of the Secretary of Public Information to screen and clear publications and broadcasts prior to public dissemination. The Bureau of Standards for Mass Media was created, which required media organizations to obtain a certificate of authorization prior to their operations from the Bureau chiefs: the Press Secretary and the Secretary of National Defense. As a result, broadcasters made sure that no programs were produced that could offend, insult, or otherwise raise the ire of the government. They were crippled in the exercise of their profession and were unable to truly contribute to the advancement of truth, arts, morals, education, and a responsible government. Gone were programs that made it a point to nudge or shame the government towards doing what is right and best for its constituency.

 

Marcos’s ouster in 1986 restored the freedom of speech, of expression, and of the press, which are protected by the Constitution. However, such protection does not extend to certain classes of speech and expression, including those considered defamatory, obscene, constituting a clear and present danger to the government, or a threat of imminent lawless action. The libel and slander laws allow the government to legally punish someone who utters defamatory speech. Similarly, obscene speech and expression, defined as the use of vulgar terms without any literary, artistic, political, or scientific value, are not protected because of their offensive and sexual nature. Speech and expression deemed to constitute a clear and present danger to the government, or pose as a threat leading to imminent lawless action, can be restricted or punished by virtue of the state’s right to self-preservation and protection.

 

 

Even if speech and expression were protected by the Constitution, the broadcast medium enjoys a lesser scope of protection compared to other forms of mass media. For example, the government may not give much attention to a certain literary article printed in a newspaper, but the same article, if broadcast through the airwaves, may be deemed powerful enough to incite rebellion and cause unrest. Also, the government may view as permissible an exercise of expression in a film to a certain segment of the audience, while also declaring it to be unfit for broadcast. The stricter standard for broadcast is due to its nature as a medium. Radio and television have a pervasive presence in the public’s lives, with a radio or television set found in every household as well as business establishments, public transportation, and other places of public utility and enjoyment. It is easy to receive broadcast signals, intentionally or not, unlike newspapers that have to be bought and read or a film for which one has to line up for a ticket and sit through the film. The power of broadcast trumps those of other media forms when it comes to disseminating information to a large audience almost instantaneously. Moreover, broadcast producers are reminded that children, whose innocence the law protects, have easy access to radio and television.

 

The government exercises its censorship powers over television as well as film through the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB), which classifies motion pictures, television programs, and related materials, such as promotional materials, applying as general standard contemporary Filipino cultural values, and by considering the treatment of factors including theme, violence, language, nudity, sex, horror, and illegal drugs. For television, there are four classifications: G for “General Patronage,” when the MTRCB deems that the material does not contain anything unsuitable for children; PG for “Parental Guidance,” when the MTRCB finds that the program may contain adult material that may be permissible for children to watch under adult supervision; SPG for “Strict Parental Guidance,” for programs that the MTRCB considers unsuitable for children unless more vigilant parental supervision is present; and X for “Disapproved for Airing on Television,” for programs that the MTRCB regards as immoral, indecent, contrary to law and/or good customs, injurious to the prestige of the Philippines or its people, or with a tendency to encourage violence and the commission of a crime (MTRCB 2004). An example of a program given the X classification due to what the MTRCB judged as a sensitive rape scene is the episode “Manika” (Doll) in ABS-CBN’s drama anthology Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember) in Jun 2012. The episode was allowed to air only after it was edited, with a rating of SPG.

 

In the case of live television programs where the MTRCB cannot exercise prior restraint, a violation is meted a suspension of the program or its host or both. Among the well-publicized examples of such suspensions is the 20-day suspension of the religious program Ang Dating Daan (The Former Path) in Aug 2004 due to the use of what the MTRCB ruled as slanderous and offensive language by its host Eliseo Soriano. Consequently, to avoid suspensions or, worse, libel suits, which can be costly, media organizations and workers sometimes resort to self-censorship.

 

In spite of this, broadcast practitioners since 1986 generally seem to have not been afraid of government censorship and prior restraint. Many lived through the martial law years and are jealously guarding the constitutionally guaranteed freedom of the press and pushing the limits of the law. Written by Roland Antonio O. Guia Jr

text:
Criticism refers to short essays that examine the artistic value and socio-political implications of broadcast texts, which pertain to programs, genres, personalities, audiences, production aspects and processes, distribution or circulation, ownership, industry structures, mediation platforms, technologies, and various socio-cultural contexts that inform the mediation process. Studies pertain to researches that cover a wide scope, often about history, which situate broadcasting in a particular period, within bigger networks of capital and governance, or in the context of nation formation.

 

Broadcast Criticism. Early criticism articles about broadcasting were largely about the state of the industry and features of personalities in entertainment sections of dailies and magazines. Mainly in English and some in Filipino, these articles were published in the 1950s to the 1960s in Kislap, Tagumpay, The Philippines Herald, Mirror, The Manila Chronicle, The Chronicle Magazine, The Manila Times, and Pitak ng mga Artista sa Pelikula, Radyo, Tanghalan at Telebisyon (Features of Artists in Cinema, Radio, Stage and Television). Pilipino Magazine featured the lives of radio and television artists in a series that ran from 1969 until martial law was declared in 1972. An annual assessment of the industry was a regular feature in The Fookien Times from the 1960s until the 1990s. During the martial law period, reviews of broadcast programs and issues appeared in several issues of the Philippine Daily Express, Weekend, Expressweek, and Who Magazine. This type of writings would be the main character of broadcast criticism in the form of articles in magazines and dailies during the early years of the post-EDSA revolt period and on through the 2000s.

 

 

Exceptional works of this type of writings appeared in regular columns of writers in these periodicals. In the late 1960s, Edmund Sicam’s column, “On Radio,” and that of Nestor Torre Jr, “On Television,” both in The Manila Chronicle, provided critical analyses of broadcast programs and in-depth assessment of the industry. Torre’s sharp-witted observations of blunders by television personalities would see print in his regular column “Boob-Tube Booboos,” which first appeared in The Philippine Daily Express in the 1970s and now occasionally appears in the Philippine Daily Inquirer, where he also regularly releases reviews of television shows.

 

The first to have taken a serious look at broadcasting as popular culture are literary and film critics in essays that form part of their anthologies of criticisms. Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, in “Ang Radio: Aliwan o Propaganda?” (Radio: Entertainment or Propaganda?) in his book Mula sa Parolang Ginto (From the Golden Lighthouse), 1969, appraises radio programs, in general, as lacking the merits to be considered art forms. Bienvendio Lumbera, in brief notes about radio in the essay “Popular Culture as Politics” that first appeared in the first issue of International Popular Culture, 1980, and later in Revaluation: Essays on Philippine Literature, Cinema and Popular Culture, 1984, and selected critical reviews of television programs in his collection of essays on culture and Philippine society, Abot-Tanaw: Sulyap at Suri sa Nagbabagong Kultura at Lipunan (Within Reach: Glimpse and Analysis of Changing Culture and Society), 1987, call attention to radio soaps, television comedies, and music programming on radio as cultural forms packaged primarily for colonial rule by administrators and profit making by businesses.

 

 

Among magazines that came out during the martial law period, Sagisag (Emblem), 1975-79, under the editorship of Lumbera, best exemplifies the significant turn in the appraisal of broadcasting through the prism of cultural studies. While still only a handful compared to film reviews, ground-breaking essays that scrutinized the form and narrative of television drama soaps, variety shows, and advertisements were “Mga Salamangka sa Patalastas sa Telebisyon” (Magic in Television Advertisements), 1976, and “Bentanilyang Kikisap-kisap, Buhay na Aandap-andap: Mga Luha at Pag-ibig sa Dulang Pantelebisyon” (Flickering Lamp, Wavering Life: Tears and Love in Television Drama), 1979, both by Valerio Nofuente; “Ambrosia ng mga Superstars” (Ambrosia of the superstars) and “Sarsuwela sa Tanghalang De-Kahon” (Sarsuwela on Theater in the Box), both in 1975 by Victor Abelardo aka Virgilio Almario; and “Dilim at Liwanag ng Dulang Pantelebisyon” (Darkness and Illumination in Television Drama), 1976, by Marcial Sanson. Essays about the artistic valuation of broadcast works under this tradition remain scattered and can be found in occasional reviews in selected magazines and books beginning in the 1980s. Fundador Soriano lamented the state of radio drama writing, particularly its lack of literary qualities in the tradition of the classics, in “Naghihingalo nga ba ang mga radio dramas?”(Are radio dramas dying?), Artista Magazine, 1981. Nofuente wrote “Portrayals of Life and Reality in Radio and Television Drama” that appeared in Philippine World-view, 1986, edited by Virgilio G. Enriquez. Midweek Magazine, edited by Pete Lacaba, 1985-91, had regular columns by critics Patrick Flores, Mike Feria, Juaniyo Arcellana, Luis Teodoro, and Marra PL. Lanot who, on top of their opinion pieces that reflect their keen observation of several cultural issues during the Aquino administration, produced incisive analyses of television programs and practices in the broadcast industry. Flores collected his reviews of broadcast programs, together with film reviews, in his book Sites of Review: Critical Practice in Media, 1996. Resil B. Mojares explored some aspects of political talk on radio in light of cultural politics and the formation of the nation in “Talking Politics: Political Commentaries On Cebuano Radio” in Reading Popular Culture, 1991, and “Talking Politics” in Waiting for Mariang Makiling: Essays in Philippine Cultural History, 2002.

 

During the waning years of the Marcos dictatorship and up to the early years of the Aquino administration, there emerged a new approach in the critical understanding of broadcast media in the Philippines. Diverging from the formalist analysis of media texts, a new set of writings began to shed light on the political economy of Philippine broadcasting, its global networks, owners’ interlocking interests in transnational corporations, and infrastructures that integrated the nation into the globalized world system. Highly influenced by the world systems theory of Immanuel Wallerstein and Marxist theories of cultural imperialism, pioneering works and essays that employed this approach in the study of broadcasting in the Philippines include Gerald Sussman’s Telecommunications Transfers: Transnational Corporations, the Philippines and Structures of Domination, 1981, and “The World Bank and Philippines Telecommunications” that appeared in a 1987 issue of the journal Philippine Studies; Orlando Mercado’s “Media Imperialism in Television” that appeared in The Politics of Culture: The Philippine Experience, 1984, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson; and Renato Constantino’s two-part piece entitled “The Transnationalization of Communications: Implications on Culture and Development,” that appeared in the 1985 issues of The Diliman Review.

 

 

Recent works using these paradigms, but with a close examination of kinship ties, economic rent-seeking strategies of acquiring wealth and power, the formation of the state, and the growth of civil society groups under specific historico-political contexts are Alfred McCoy’s “Rent-seeking Families and the Philippine State: A History of the Lopez Family” in his book Anarchy of Families: State and Family in the Philippines, 1994, and Josefina C. Santos’s “Out of Reach: Television, the Public Sphere and Civil Society in the Philippines” in Television, Regulation and Civil Society in Asia, 2003, edited by Philip Kitley. Two major books by the Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism that provided trenchant critiques of the capitalist nature of the Philippine broadcast industry and the impact of politics and economics on contemporary broadcast journalism are News for Sale: The Corruption of the Philippine Media, 1998, by Chay Florentino Hofileña and From Loren to Marimar: The Philippine Media in the 1990s, 1999, edited by Sheila Coronel, with sharp investigative reports about the broadcast industry by print journalists like Coronel, Luz Rimban, Stella Tirol, and Alex Pabico. The magazine Newsbreak, in its print issues from 2001 to 2006, edited by Marites Dañguilan-Vitug, had short articles about broadcast issues by writers like Charlson Ong, Jaileen Jimeno, Gemma Bagayaua, and Jo-Ann Maglipon.

 

Broadcast Studies. Studies about the history of Philippine broadcasting come from different orientations and move towards different directions. Ramona Bautista documented the growth of the radio industry in her article “Radio in the Philippines,” The Sunday Times, Sep 1947. Luis Ma. Trinidad wrote “The Role of Radio in Philippine Entertainment” in The Chronicle Magazine in its 24 Nov 1964 issue. The Marcos government in 1968 came out with the monograph series Presidential Policy Statement that contained transcripts of audio recordings of President Ferdinand Marcos aired on Pakinggan ang Pangulo: Radio-Television Chat (Listen to the President: Radio-Television Chat) that contained the government’s policy issues, including those about broadcast. In the mid-1970s, during the height of the martial law period, the government came out with the magazine called The Broadcaster which discussed the radio and television thrusts of the Marcos government and other issues faced by the industry. A few notes about broadcast history are included in the books Philippine Mass Communications: 1811-1966, 1973, by John A. Lent, Mass Communication in Asia: A Brief History, 1978, by Charles Moses and Crispin Maslog, and Philippine Mass Communication: A Mini-History, 1990, by Maslog. Stay Tuned: The Golden Years of Philippine Radio, A Historical Perspective of Philippine Radio, 2007, by Benjamin Aniceto is a compendium of data about early radio personalities and events. Florangel Rosario-Braid and Ramon Tuazon identified historical shifts and developments in “Post-EDSA Communication Media,” which appeared in an issue of the journal Philippine Studies in 2000. The Cultural Center of the Philippines released in 2003 two important monographs that sketched a critical history of broadcasting: Radyo: An Essay on Philippine Radio by Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Telebisyon: An Essay on Philippine Television by Clodualdo del Mundo Jr. Recent historical studies that appeared in learned journals are “Shooting the Messenger: Why Radio Broadcasting is a Deadly Profession in the Philippines,” in Journal of Radio Studies, 2009, by Rey Rosales; and “The Development of News as a Viable Format in Philippine Radio, 1960s to Present: A Study of DZRH and DZBB,” in Journal of Radio and Audio Media, 2011, by Melba Estonilo. A pioneering study that frames broadcast history within the lens of post-colonialism and political economy is Appropriation of Colonial Broadcasting: A History of Early Radio in the Philippines, 1922-1946, 2008, by Elizabeth Enriquez.

 

Personality-based histories, in the format of coffee table books, were produced by commercial broadcast networks, such as Pinoy Television: The Story of ABS-CBN, 1999, edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan, GMA Gold: Fifty Years of Broadcast History, 2001, edited by Chelo Banal-Formoso, Kapitan:Geny Lopez and the Making of ABS-CBN, 2006, by Raul Rodrigo, and Passing the Torch: The Lopez Group at Eighty, 1928-2008, 2008, by Rodrigo.

 

Refereed local journals of international stature offer occasional essays about all aspects of Philippine broadcasting. These are Philippine Studies and Kritika Kultura from the Ateneo de Manila University, and Humanities Diliman, Social Science Diliman, Philippine Humanities Review, and Third World Studies from the University of the Philippines (UP). The journal that has a specific focus on media studies is Plaridel from the UP College of Mass Communication. Exceptional works about a wide range of contemporary issues in broadcasting examined from diverse theoretical frames came from scholars like Fernando Austria Jr, Jose Duke Bagulaya, Christine Bellen, Elizabeth Enriquez, Rosa Maria Feliciano, JPaul Manzanilla, Jema Pamintuan, Maria Portia O. Placino, Johnathan Rondina, Aleli Quirante, Elyrah Salanga, Joseph Salazar, Victorio Sugbo, and Alvin Yapan. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

article.value: Criticism refers to short essays that examine the artistic value and socio-political implications of broadcast texts, which pertain to programs, genres, personalities, audiences, production aspects and processes, distribution or circulation, ownership, industry structures, mediation platforms, technologies, and various socio-cultural contexts that inform the mediation process. Studies pertain to researches that cover a wide scope, often about history, which situate broadcasting in a particular period, within bigger networks of capital and governance, or in the context of nation formation.

Broadcast Criticism. Early criticism articles about broadcasting were largely about the state of the industry and features of personalities in entertainment sections of dailies and magazines. Mainly in English and some in Filipino, these articles were published in the 1950s to the 1960s in Kislap, Tagumpay, The Philippines Herald, Mirror, The Manila Chronicle, The Chronicle Magazine, The Manila Times, and Pitak ng mga Artista sa Pelikula, Radyo, Tanghalan at Telebisyon (Features of Artists in Cinema, Radio, Stage and Television). Pilipino Magazine featured the lives of radio and television artists in a series that ran from 1969 until martial law was declared in 1972. An annual assessment of the industry was a regular feature in The Fookien Times from the 1960s until the 1990s. During the martial law period, reviews of broadcast programs and issues appeared in several issues of the Philippine Daily Express, Weekend, Expressweek, and Who Magazine. This type of writings would be the main character of broadcast criticism in the form of articles in magazines and dailies during the early years of the post-EDSA revolt period and on through the 2000s.

text:
Directing is the artistic vision to a creative work on radio and television provided by a director. This is done by instructing and motivating the members of the production team to perform their tasks according to this vision. Hence, the director has the final say with regards to the quality of each member’s output. In practice, the role of the director varies between radio and television and the genres within each medium. There are cases when the artistic vision is provided by the producer of the program.

 

In genres like talk shows, music programs, and commercials that air on mainstream radio, there are no persons designated as directors. The role of the director for talk shows is taken on by the talk show host or the producer of the program who provide both the flow of the content and the artistic tenor of the production. Prior to the airing of an episode of the program, the producer and talk show host agree on the topic for discussion. The producer then gathers materials like music, sound effects, and voice inserts to be aired for the episode. The producer also invites guests, conducts research, and prepares a guide questionnaire for the interview. Armed with these materials, the talk show host directs the flow of the program through the sequence of questions that he or she asks. In music programs, the music director and disc jockey take on the role of the director as they create the playlist. In Citi Lite 88.3 FM, which aired an eclectic mix of contemporary and mainstream jazz, pop, R&B, and New Age musical selections for easy listening, the creation of the playlist begins with the music programming team composed of the music director and disc jockeys auditioning old and new materials from compact disc albums sourced from both here and abroad. While auditioning the music, the team selects and then classifies songs based on genre and year of release. The selection is then approved by the program director for inclusion in the master playlist. Disc jockeys play music from the master list and rotate the airing of the selections based on a number of factors like how old or new the song is and its popularity (Aseron 2015). With the advent of digital playlist technologies, the sequencing and rotation of songs are done automatically. The creative input is limited to the selection of songs.

 

 

In radio commercials, the producer of the material collaborates with a sound designer or jingle composer to achieve the goals set by the creative team of the advertising agency that commissioned the work. The production of radio commercials begins with a feasibility meeting during which the producer presents the objectives of the advertisement, the mood and tone of the material, voice samples, music pegs, and other materials to be used in the production for approval by the creative team of the agency. Once approved, these materials are presented to the client in a preproduction meeting. In this meeting, the creative direction of the production is agreed upon and a go signal is given to proceed with the production. During the production of the commercial, the producer’s main role is to guide those involved in the production to ensure that all the creative agreements are met. The produced material is then presented to the agency and then the client for approval for airing.

 

This is different for radio dramas in which a director is hired to ensure the quality of the production. The director’s work is mostly limited to assigning roles to performers, giving instructions to correct mistakes in the words read, and remedy technical errors. In the recording of a radio drama, each member of the production team and the voice talents are guided by instructions detailed in the drama script. During the recording of the drama, the director listens to the delivery of the talents and sound effects incorporated in the program. The director just interrupts the production to correct the errors in voice delivery, timing, and audio levels made during the recording. This is because the production of radio dramas is already strongly anchored on traditions and conventions that performers and other members of the production team replicate. In the production of a radio drama, the performers and crew perform like a well-oiled machine needing very little direction. For example, if the role of the performer is that of a heroine, tradition dictates that her performancce be coy and sweet-sounding. The sound effects person conveniently follows the script. The music scorer selects canned or original music available in his or her file and uses these selections that fit the general emotion of the scene during the live production or the editing phase. The director guides the technical director during the editing in assembling together all these elements to complete the drama.

 

 

On mainstream television, genres like talk, game, musical, and variety shows that are either pre-recorded or aired live using multiple cameras and real-time editing have a repetitive look and styling. The opening sequences and segments of the same program have the same camera work, lighting, production design, graphics, and other elements. The overall vision for these genres is initially generated by the producer of the program. Upon getting a nod to produce the initial program concept, the producer brings together a creative team that includes a director and writers. At this stage, the director contributes his vision for the look and style of the program. The director fine tunes this look and style during the initial taping or broadcast of the program. Subsequent episodes follow the creative patterns created in the initial episode. For this reason, the role of a director in the following episodes is basically to frame the cameras and provide the rhythm of the real-time editing of the show. In ABS-CBN’s variety show It’s Showtime, 2009, the opening sequence starts with the theme music and graphics of the title of the program. It is followed by an intercut of images of the hosts in the audience area singing the theme music of the program with the audience. Subtitles of the lyrics of the theme song are also flashed during this opening number. This is what viewers regularly see every episode of the program.

 

The direction of segments in these programs is usually done by a segment producer and quality-approved by the producer of the show. At times, the director contributes ideas to new segments of the program. In the event when the program suffers in ratings, the creative team is usually asked to come up with new and creative ways to change or add to the content and treatment of the program with the hopes of generating a stronger audience appeal.

 

The more theoretical role of a director can be observed in television dramas—soap operas, teleplays for anthologies, fantasy dramas, and similar genres. In these types of programs, the director interprets the script and conceptualizes a treatment based on his/her vision. The role of a director as a visual storyteller of television dramas in a commercial industry is complicated by the business side of the production. The director’s work is expected by management to receive high audience ratings. This then puts pressure on the creativity of the director. The pressure may lead the director to revert to formulaic storytelling, change performers and/or plotlines in the middle of a series, utilize performers with a huge fan base, and other similar strategies to work toward an increase in the viewership of the drama. In the ABS-CBN drama series My Binondo Girl, 2011, the lead character played by Kim Chiu was supposed to end up marrying the character played by Jolo Revilla. Due to the unfavorable audience reception to the Revilla-Chiu love team, which could have eventually resulted in lower ratings, the plot of the story had to be changed in favor of an ending that saw the elaborate Chinese wedding of the characters that Kim Chiu and Xian Lim portrayed (Marmol 2011). Other pressures include compromising on aspects of the production design like sets and props, rushing the recording of sequences, and other measures to cut the cost of the production.

 

 

Popular radio drama directors are also often voice talents. These include Eloisa Cruz Canlas, Luz Fernandez, Mely Tagasa, Fred Gonzales, Err Ramos, Fundador Soriano, Teddy Valdemor, Ruben de Leon, Art de Guzman, Nanding Ocampo, Vic Otyeza, Domingo Principe, Augusto Victa, Rolly Papasin, Froilan Villegas, Lucio Maylas, Demet Velasquez, Gil Soriano, and Tony Angeles. Eli Rueda Guieb III, Alfredo Lazarte, and Don Pagusara directed socially relevant and politically conscious radio dramas produced by civil society groups. Noteworthy TV drama directors, who also worked in film and theater, include Ishmael Bernal, Lino Brocka, Mario O’Hara, Lupita Aquino-Kashiwahara, Fr James Reuter, SJ, Romy Suzara, Soxie Topacio, Peque Gallaga, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Joel Lamangan, Joven Velasco, Nick Lizaso, Jose Mari Avellana, Jose Gruta, Angel Cruz, Argel Joseph, Gene Palomo, Jose Miranda Cruz, Marcial Samson, Olivia Lamasan, and Jeffrey Jeturian. Younger TV drama directors include Dominic Zapata, Mark Reyes, Jerome Pobocan, Malu Sevilla, Jojo Saguin, Erick Salud, Don Cuaresma, and Wenn Deramas. Recently, independent filmmakers like Alvin Yapan, Francis Pasion, and Adolf Alix Jr have directed significant television dramas. Significant comedy directors, some of whom are writers as well, include Manuel Conde, Ading Fernando, Jun Urbano, Bibeth Orteza, Jose Javier Reyes, Leo Martinez, Uro dela Cruz, and Edgar Mortiz. Marilou Diaz-Abaya directed excellent talk programs and comedies. Maria Montelibano is noted for her talk programs. Among directors of children’s and educational programs are Lito Tiongson, Khryss Adalia, Noel Balmaseda, Noel Añonuevo, Kokoy Jimenez, and Clodualdo del Mundo Jr. Noteworthy directors of musical and variety programs on television are Mitos Villareal, Al Quinn, Fritz Ynfante, Carlos Siguion-Reyna, Menchu Dalusong, Johnny Manahan, Dick Zamora, Arnel Natividad, Louie Ignacio, and Rico Gutierrez. Written by Fernando A. Austria Jr

article.value: Directing is the artistic vision to a creative work on radio and television provided by a director. This is done by instructing and motivating the members of the production team to perform their tasks according to this vision. Hence, the director has the final say with regards to the quality of each member’s output. In practice, the role of the director varies between radio and television and the genres within each medium. There are cases when the artistic vision is provided by the producer of the program.

In genres like talk shows, music programs, and commercials that air on mainstream radio, there are no persons designated as directors. The role of the director for talk shows is taken on by the talk show host or the producer of the program who provide both the flow of the content and the artistic tenor of the production. Prior to the airing of an episode of the program, the producer and talk show host agree on the topic for discussion. The producer then gathers materials like music, sound effects, and voice inserts to be aired for the episode. The producer also invites guests, conducts research, and prepares a guide questionnaire for the interview. Armed with these materials, the talk show host directs the flow of the program through the sequence of questions that he or she asks. In music programs, the music director and disc jockey take on the role of the director as they create the playlist. In Citi Lite 88.3 FM, which aired an eclectic mix of contemporary and mainstream jazz, pop, R&B, and New Age musical selections for easy listening, the creation of the playlist begins with the music programming team composed of the music director and disc jockeys auditioning old and new materials from compact disc albums sourced from both here and abroad. While auditioning the music, the team selects and then classifies songs based on genre and year of release. The selection is then approved by the program director for inclusion in the master playlist. Disc jockeys play music from the master list and rotate the airing of the selections based on a number of factors like how old or new the song is and its popularity (Aseron 2015). With the advent of digital playlist technologies, the sequencing and rotation of songs are done automatically. The creative input is limited to the selection of songs.

article.value: In radio commercials, the producer of the material collaborates with a sound designer or jingle composer to achieve the goals set by the creative team of the advertising agency that commissioned the work. The production of radio commercials begins with a feasibility meeting during which the producer presents the objectives of the advertisement, the mood and tone of the material, voice samples, music pegs, and other materials to be used in the production for approval by the creative team of the agency. Once approved, these materials are presented to the client in a preproduction meeting. In this meeting, the creative direction of the production is agreed upon and a go signal is given to proceed with the production. During the production of the commercial, the producer’s main role is to guide those involved in the production to ensure that all the creative agreements are met. The produced material is then presented to the agency and then the client for approval for airing.

This is different for radio dramas in which a director is hired to ensure the quality of the production. The director’s work is mostly limited to assigning roles to performers, giving instructions to correct mistakes in the words read, and remedy technical errors. In the recording of a radio drama, each member of the production team and the voice talents are guided by instructions detailed in the drama script. During the recording of the drama, the director listens to the delivery of the talents and sound effects incorporated in the program. The director just interrupts the production to correct the errors in voice delivery, timing, and audio levels made during the recording. This is because the production of radio dramas is already strongly anchored on traditions and conventions that performers and other members of the production team replicate. In the production of a radio drama, the performers and crew perform like a well-oiled machine needing very little direction. For example, if the role of the performer is that of a heroine, tradition dictates that her performancce be coy and sweet-sounding. The sound effects person conveniently follows the script. The music scorer selects canned or original music available in his or her file and uses these selections that fit the general emotion of the scene during the live production or the editing phase. The director guides the technical director during the editing in assembling together all these elements to complete the drama.
