text:
Editing is the art and craft of compressing or expanding time and space. It involves tying sounds and images together to provide shifts and transitions in a specific order of sequences to create continuity, rhythm, and narrative. Editing helps listeners or viewers follow the meaning intended by the program producer and keep them glued to the radio or television.

 

Two types of editing emerged in terms of changes in broadcast technology in the Philippines: linear analog editing, from the late 1940s until the early 2000s, and nonlinear digital editing, which began in the late 1980s. Before World War II, recordings were basically mechanical and electrical in character, and amplified or sent to stations via electric signals. Elsewhere in the world, the magnetic era in audio recording began in 1945. Advances in technology led to a wide range of developments until the digital era crept into the picture sometime in the mid-1970s, and gained traction in the Philippines in the late 1980s.

 

All radio productions in the Philippines before and after World War II and television productions beginning in the 1950s were done live in a studio. News reports in the Philippines during the period were feeds from international broadcasts; a few were live coverage of local events. Drama soaps, variety programs, and commercials, in both radio and television, were also aired live.

 

In radio, there was no editing done in the beginning as everything was aired live. If there were any mistakes, there was no way to edit them out. This was why a 15-minute program was carefully scripted and typically rehearsed for three hours. In the USA and Europe, there were early recording instruments that used wires or discs, which looked like giant long-playing records, but there was no editing involved. The discs were called transcriptions. Programs were recorded live and then sent out to other stations for re-broadcast. Some of these recordings were aired on Philippine radio before World War II, but especially towards the end of the war when MacArthur’s signal corps brought with them transcriptions of American radio programs to flood the Philippines with, to make it clear they had returned to re-take the country from the Japanese.

 

In the late 1940s, the technology of what were called open-reel tape recorders and the magnetic tape was developed. Analog audio editing became possible, but it was manual and involved a slow and tedious process. The editor basically trims unwanted sound by finding the two points between which the sound to be eliminated is found, physically splicing the tape at said points on an editing block, then taping the remaining tape together with a splicing adhesive tape. The angle of the spliced ends of the tape determines the kind of sound transition possible, such as a crossfade or a cut. To add sound involved layering of sounds with a multi-track tape recorder and magnetic tape, which was laborious and time-consuming.

 

In the Philippines, such editing was reserved only for commercials to avoid the lengthy and labor-intensive process that would increase production cost. When the practice of pre-recording soaps was adopted, everything was rehearsed, including music scoring and sound effects that were physically produced using an SFX box or sound effects box, then taped as though the program was live. If there was an error, a re-take was done. Minimal editing was involved.

 

Television shows were generally shot using a single camera, and with no special effects. For example, Fr James Reuter’s production of Cyrano de Bergerac was broadcast live from a studio of ABS Channel 3 on 16 Nov 1953, making it the first drama aired on Philippine TV. Like newscasts and entertainment programs of the period, “cameras would get entangled in wires and not be able to track; actors who had been murdered got up and walked off in full view of the TV audience. Many actors went blank in the middle of scenes” (Rodrigo 2006, 40). Newscasters and performers committed mistakes, and they “burned in white” when cameras were kept on too long (Rodrigo 2006).

 

In April 1956, a company called AMPEX unveiled a recording device called the Quadruplex during the assembly of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters in Chicago. It was a huge machine that looked like a refrigerator. All three television networks in the USA owned video recorders by 1957 and began experimenting with ways to edit videotape. Unlike the film material which could be held up against the light to see the image on it, the two-inch tape on an Ampex recorder was viewed on a machine, which had to be stopped at the edit points, marked with a Pentel pen, then cut physically. On television, the first beneficiary of this machine in the Philippines was the music program An Evening with Pilita, 1964-71, ABS Channel 3. The network bought two units of this equipment in 1964. Each machine costs US $80,000, and each tape costs about Php1,000; indeed, a very expensive investment (Rodrigo 2006).

 

In the USA, television engineers played around with pulse tones to mark the video tapes to achieve accuracy in the editing frame. In the Philippines, pioneer editors had to rely on their physical pulse to feel the rhythm on which to mark the cutting points. In the mid-1960s, Dick Hill, a CBS technician, stumbled on a piece of Defense Department technology that allowed electronic recording of a time clock on magnetic tape. The technology was used by the military to record missile launch data. This led to the application of timecodes to video tape. The timecode made modern video editing possible and eventually led to the creation of nonlinear editing systems. Director Mitos Villareal, using the Ampex recorder, explored the many possibilities of editing for taped episodes of An Evening with Pilita, such as the split-screen effect in which “three Pilitas,” a Visayan Pilita, an English Pilita, and a Spanish Pilita, spoke to one another. It was an editing technique first seen on local television at a time of analog broadcast production. A one-hour show then required 24 hours of editing (Rodrigo 2006).

 

In other countries, the first disk-based nonlinear editing system, the CMX600, was introduced in 1970. Laserdiscs were used as storage devices. Various approximations of nonlinear editing systems were built in the 1980s using computers, multiple laser discs or video cassette recorders using different formats. The most common tape was the Umatic. In under a century, a lot of technological advancements were made in the editing of video. With linear editing, editors had to deal with loss of video quality and challenging ways to produce graphics. The popularity of the nonlinear editing system made editors produce work faster; cutting and inserting footage has become easier, and compositing is less of a challenge with filters and software plug-ins. Ordinary people can buy a nonlinear editing software, install it in their computers, then learn to use it at home. “Self-taught” has evolved from tinkering with an editing machine to watching instructional videos on YouTube and reading postproduction forums. Just several decades ago, one needed to be apprenticed before learning how to edit.

 

The ease of producing a desired output with just a click of a button somehow limits the editors’ creativity, unlike before when editors were challenged to think of ways to achieve a certain look by experimenting and compositing. The accessibility of the editing software gave way to “mere technicians”—people who only know how to operate the software but who have no knowledge of the principles of editing.

 

Sound effects person Manuel Salas, audio editor Froilan Malimban, and video editors Nonoy Regalado, Ricardo Paras, Mel Bacani III, and Paul Ticzon have observed some disturbing effects of nonlinear editing technology to production as a whole. Paras, head of the video editing section of GMA, says it succinctly: “Ever since the shift from analog tape-based formats to tapeless file-based formats, I noticed a decline in the efficiency of production units when it comes to the acquisition of materials. When tapes (Umatic/Betacam/DVC) were used for acquisition, production teams tended to limit the number of takes, shooting days, etc., with the goal of using up only the allotted or less-than-the-allotted tape stock since these were very expensive. Nowadays, with the lower cost of drives, production units can shoot multiple takes and cure shots since these only translate to files and drive space. Clients also have this “fix it in postproduction” attitude, thinking that anything can be achieved by the “high-tech” machines used by the editors. With this attitude, they sometimes forego proper lighting and other production values” (Paras 2015).

 

Different broadcast programs employ varied editing principles, all derived from film theory. These principles depend on the nature of the subject, the intended impact of the production, and the treatment of the work. Terms for editing principles vary or overlap, depending on the classification formulated by different schools of thought and scholars. The most common principles in broadcast are narrative editing, which can be linear, inverted, or parallel; the ellipses, which can create parallelism, synchronism, and anti-thesis; rhythmic editing, which is the creation of cadence; and expressive editing, which involves the fusion of nonrelated images and sound to create meanings or evocations not identified with the same images or sounds if taken individually (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966, Wollen 1969).

 

Rhythmic editing is derived but has deviated from Eisenstein’s principle of metric editing, which is the cutting of sequences based on an absolute measurement of shots, counted in frames, to create a mathematical formulation that characterizes the film’s formal aesthetics (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966). Metric editing is similar to the creation of the cadence or rhyme of a poem, which is dependent on its number of syllables and lines; the measured rhythm is its formal character. Current usage of rhythmic editing in broadcast is not dictated by a fixed number of frames or shots, but by multiple factors, such as the beat of the music, the movement of the images, the composition of shots, and the interest raised and held by these audio and visual elements. Fritz Ynfante’s editing style in the dance show Penthouse 7, 1974-81, GMA, and that of Johnny Manahan’s in the music variety program ASAP, which has been running on ABS-CBN since 1995, can be considered rhythmic, dependent mainly on the tempo of the music. The combination of rhythm and a clearly articulated ideological position is best exemplified in the music video HLMX Trilogy, 2015, three videos-in-one that present the decades-long struggles of peasants to achieve genuine agrarian reform in the country. Combining the videos together is a little girl traversing the sugarcane field, interspersed with real documentary footage of the struggle for land, and concluding with raised red flags in Hacienda Luisita as a way of paying tribute to the martyrs of the peasantry. An abuse of rhythmic editing is that employed in the coverage of ABS-CBN News Channel, and later ABS-CBN Sports and Action Channel, of the annual Cheerdance Competition of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines. Viewers have rightly commented that the cutting of video shots for performances in this kind of a show is less about the rhythm of the music than the tempo of the movements and geometry of lines created by the performers, the level of difficulty of the stunts, and the execution of the transitions, which a simple, long, steady full shot of the performances, with minimal cuts to medium or close shots, could provide.

 

Narrative editing is simply putting together different shots to tell a story. Linear editing is the simplest and most common. It involves the composition of shots or sounds that forward a story in chronological order to achieve temporal and spatial continuity. All genres and formats of local broadcast programs generally follow a chronological sequence of events or activities that are divided into segments. Inverted editing begins at a particular point in the present, leaves this point to flashback a past or jumps to the future through the device of flash forwards, then returns to the present. Inverted editing is generally employed in drama programs and children’s fantasy stories. Parallel editing shows two or more separate actions taking place, generally but not necessarily, in different places or times. The actions either converge at a particular sequence or continue their separate movements until a certain pattern of the narrative is produced. The fast-paced parallel cuts in the Mexican telenovela Marimar, 1996, RPN 9, has greatly influenced the extensive use of this editing technique in local telenovelas like Pangako sa ‘Yo (The Promise), 2000, and Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009, both on ABS-CBN.

 

Editing involves the compression or expansion of time and space using the principle of ellipses. An ellipse can be explicit, such as the use of dissolves of the same object, place or image in a different time or setting. An ellipse can be implicit, which is a parallel cut of the same object, place or image in a different time or setting but with other audio-visual elements altered to imply the change. The opening sequence of Katipunan, a drama series about the life of national hero Andres Bonifacio, 2013, GMA, written by Ian Victoriano and directed by King Marc Baco, is an excellent example of the use of implicit ellipses, such as light and darkness, innocence and violence, and body movements of sprightliness and fear, which are assembled from scenes of various times and spaces into a montage to simultaneously create parallelism, synchronism, and anti-theses, which are types of editing treatment seen in works by Soviet filmmakers Sergei Eisenstein and Vsevolid Pudovkin (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966). The melancholic tone of the hero’s narration and the naiveté of a young woman running innocently in the sun-drenched virgin forest are marred and negated by inserted sequences of the massacre of revolting men and women peasants in the dead of night and that of a young woman, the same woman in the opening shots, now in pain, molested, running aimlessly in the dark, desecrated forest, until she reaches the edge of the earth and plunges herself into the deep void. Implicit time-space ellipses are extended to shots of bodies of the massacred peasants that are abruptly cut to the young woman’s body on a boulder, in another place and time, now dead, lying face down, her eyes staring at the camera.

 

Some programs use expressive editing, labeled by some scholars as Eisenstein’s intellectual montage editing to create a collision of ideas (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966). Expressive editing juxtaposes nonrelated images, dialogue, and sounds to establish meanings or create feelings that would not have been evoked had these elements not been linked together. The meanings or feelings arise not in the individual shot or sound, but in the fusing together of these elements. Some radio dramas of UP Nating Mahal (University of the Philippines, Our Beloved), 2015, DZUP 1602, employed this approach. An example is the episode “Sinapupunan” (Womb), about a fetus deciding to abort herself or continue the bloody birthing process to face the uncertainties of life in the Third World. Each stage of the process is punctuated by lines from the works of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Victor Jara, Pablo Neruda, Lu Xun, Otto Rene Castillo, Joi Barrios, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, Fidel Rillo, and Emmanuel Lacaba, with each excerpt sneaking in and out of the sequences. The final sequence is a montage of multiple tracks of simultaneous sounds of shivering human flesh, splintering bones, bubbling blood of capillaries, the rising vapor of body heat, and the simmering fluid of slimy internal organs, while the uneven soft thuds of a baby’s movement is heard, slowly creeping out of her mother’s womb. Embedded in this multi-layered mix is the guitar music of “Jocelynang Baliuag,” the theme song of the Philippine revolution of 1896. The cacophony of sounds ends in a burst of contracting muscles, a deep sigh, and a triumphant cry of a baby. To punctuate the notion of birthing a just society, the guitar music engulfs all the remaining uncertainties invoked by the sound effects of the drama.

 

On television, expressive editing was applied by Lupita Concio in Malikmata (Phantasm), 1972, ABC 5, and Lino Brocka in Guni-guni (Imagination), 1979, GMA, correlating an object with an unrelated image to charge the sequences with intimations of the unknown and the macabre. Marcial Sanson’s historical drama The Life of Emilio Aguinaldo, 1975, BBC 2, had parallel cuts of objects, symbols, and human characters set in limbo to impress a sense of ambiguity on the character of the hero. Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s satirical gag show Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89, IBC 13, embedded movie excerpts or real-life news clips on to narratives of current events, both fictional and real, to create incongruity and relatedness. Adolf Alix Jr’s “The Flora and Harry Gasser Story,” an episode in the drama anthology Wagas (Pure) 2014, GMA News TV, about the life of popular newscaster Harry Gasser and his wife, actor Flora Gasser, intelligently assembled or disaggregated sequences to jar the lines that divide Flora’s spoken narrative and private thoughts, the shifting worlds of the dead and the living, and the fluidity of the past and the present in times of mourning. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III,  with notes from Hazel Gulmatico Hernandez and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

In radio, there was no editing done in the beginning as everything was aired live. If there were any mistakes, there was no way to edit them out. This was why a 15-minute program was carefully scripted and typically rehearsed for three hours. In the USA and Europe, there were early recording instruments that used wires or discs, which looked like giant long-playing records, but there was no editing involved. The discs were called transcriptions. Programs were recorded live and then sent out to other stations for re-broadcast. Some of these recordings were aired on Philippine radio before World War II, but especially towards the end of the war when MacArthur’s signal corps brought with them transcriptions of American radio programs to flood the Philippines with, to make it clear they had returned to re-take the country from the Japanese.

In the late 1940s, the technology of what were called open-reel tape recorders and the magnetic tape was developed. Analog audio editing became possible, but it was manual and involved a slow and tedious process. The editor basically trims unwanted sound by finding the two points between which the sound to be eliminated is found, physically splicing the tape at said points on an editing block, then taping the remaining tape together with a splicing adhesive tape. The angle of the spliced ends of the tape determines the kind of sound transition possible, such as a crossfade or a cut. To add sound involved layering of sounds with a multi-track tape recorder and magnetic tape, which was laborious and time-consuming.

In the Philippines, such editing was reserved only for commercials to avoid the lengthy and labor-intensive process that would increase production cost. When the practice of pre-recording soaps was adopted, everything was rehearsed, including music scoring and sound effects that were physically produced using an SFX box or sound effects box, then taped as though the program was live. If there was an error, a re-take was done. Minimal editing was involved.

Television shows were generally shot using a single camera, and with no special effects. For example, Fr James Reuter’s production of Cyrano de Bergerac was broadcast live from a studio of ABS Channel 3 on 16 Nov 1953, making it the first drama aired on Philippine TV. Like newscasts and entertainment programs of the period, “cameras would get entangled in wires and not be able to track; actors who had been murdered got up and walked off in full view of the TV audience. Many actors went blank in the middle of scenes” (Rodrigo 2006, 40). Newscasters and performers committed mistakes, and they “burned in white” when cameras were kept on too long (Rodrigo 2006).

In April 1956, a company called AMPEX unveiled a recording device called the Quadruplex during the assembly of the National Association of Radio and Television Broadcasters in Chicago. It was a huge machine that looked like a refrigerator. All three television networks in the USA owned video recorders by 1957 and began experimenting with ways to edit videotape. Unlike the film material which could be held up against the light to see the image on it, the two-inch tape on an Ampex recorder was viewed on a machine, which had to be stopped at the edit points, marked with a Pentel pen, then cut physically. On television, the first beneficiary of this machine in the Philippines was the music program An Evening with Pilita, 1964-71, ABS Channel 3. The network bought two units of this equipment in 1964. Each machine costs US $80,000, and each tape costs about Php1,000; indeed, a very expensive investment (Rodrigo 2006).

In the USA, television engineers played around with pulse tones to mark the video tapes to achieve accuracy in the editing frame. In the Philippines, pioneer editors had to rely on their physical pulse to feel the rhythm on which to mark the cutting points. In the mid-1960s, Dick Hill, a CBS technician, stumbled on a piece of Defense Department technology that allowed electronic recording of a time clock on magnetic tape. The technology was used by the military to record missile launch data. This led to the application of timecodes to video tape. The timecode made modern video editing possible and eventually led to the creation of nonlinear editing systems. Director Mitos Villareal, using the Ampex recorder, explored the many possibilities of editing for taped episodes of An Evening with Pilita, such as the split-screen effect in which “three Pilitas,” a Visayan Pilita, an English Pilita, and a Spanish Pilita, spoke to one another. It was an editing technique first seen on local television at a time of analog broadcast production. A one-hour show then required 24 hours of editing (Rodrigo 2006).

In other countries, the first disk-based nonlinear editing system, the CMX600, was introduced in 1970. Laserdiscs were used as storage devices. Various approximations of nonlinear editing systems were built in the 1980s using computers, multiple laser discs or video cassette recorders using different formats. The most common tape was the Umatic. In under a century, a lot of technological advancements were made in the editing of video. With linear editing, editors had to deal with loss of video quality and challenging ways to produce graphics. The popularity of the nonlinear editing system made editors produce work faster; cutting and inserting footage has become easier, and compositing is less of a challenge with filters and software plug-ins. Ordinary people can buy a nonlinear editing software, install it in their computers, then learn to use it at home. “Self-taught” has evolved from tinkering with an editing machine to watching instructional videos on YouTube and reading postproduction forums. Just several decades ago, one needed to be apprenticed before learning how to edit.

The ease of producing a desired output with just a click of a button somehow limits the editors’ creativity, unlike before when editors were challenged to think of ways to achieve a certain look by experimenting and compositing. The accessibility of the editing software gave way to “mere technicians”—people who only know how to operate the software but who have no knowledge of the principles of editing.

Sound effects person Manuel Salas, audio editor Froilan Malimban, and video editors Nonoy Regalado, Ricardo Paras, Mel Bacani III, and Paul Ticzon have observed some disturbing effects of nonlinear editing technology to production as a whole. Paras, head of the video editing section of GMA, says it succinctly: “Ever since the shift from analog tape-based formats to tapeless file-based formats, I noticed a decline in the efficiency of production units when it comes to the acquisition of materials. When tapes (Umatic/Betacam/DVC) were used for acquisition, production teams tended to limit the number of takes, shooting days, etc., with the goal of using up only the allotted or less-than-the-allotted tape stock since these were very expensive. Nowadays, with the lower cost of drives, production units can shoot multiple takes and cure shots since these only translate to files and drive space. Clients also have this “fix it in postproduction” attitude, thinking that anything can be achieved by the “high-tech” machines used by the editors. With this attitude, they sometimes forego proper lighting and other production values” (Paras 2015).

Different broadcast programs employ varied editing principles, all derived from film theory. These principles depend on the nature of the subject, the intended impact of the production, and the treatment of the work. Terms for editing principles vary or overlap, depending on the classification formulated by different schools of thought and scholars. The most common principles in broadcast are narrative editing, which can be linear, inverted, or parallel; the ellipses, which can create parallelism, synchronism, and anti-thesis; rhythmic editing, which is the creation of cadence; and expressive editing, which involves the fusion of nonrelated images and sound to create meanings or evocations not identified with the same images or sounds if taken individually (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966, Wollen 1969).

Rhythmic editing is derived but has deviated from Eisenstein’s principle of metric editing, which is the cutting of sequences based on an absolute measurement of shots, counted in frames, to create a mathematical formulation that characterizes the film’s formal aesthetics (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966). Metric editing is similar to the creation of the cadence or rhyme of a poem, which is dependent on its number of syllables and lines; the measured rhythm is its formal character. Current usage of rhythmic editing in broadcast is not dictated by a fixed number of frames or shots, but by multiple factors, such as the beat of the music, the movement of the images, the composition of shots, and the interest raised and held by these audio and visual elements. Fritz Ynfante’s editing style in the dance show Penthouse 7, 1974-81, GMA, and that of Johnny Manahan’s in the music variety program ASAP, which has been running on ABS-CBN since 1995, can be considered rhythmic, dependent mainly on the tempo of the music. The combination of rhythm and a clearly articulated ideological position is best exemplified in the music video HLMX Trilogy, 2015, three videos-in-one that present the decades-long struggles of peasants to achieve genuine agrarian reform in the country. Combining the videos together is a little girl traversing the sugarcane field, interspersed with real documentary footage of the struggle for land, and concluding with raised red flags in Hacienda Luisita as a way of paying tribute to the martyrs of the peasantry. An abuse of rhythmic editing is that employed in the coverage of ABS-CBN News Channel, and later ABS-CBN Sports and Action Channel, of the annual Cheerdance Competition of the University Athletic Association of the Philippines. Viewers have rightly commented that the cutting of video shots for performances in this kind of a show is less about the rhythm of the music than the tempo of the movements and geometry of lines created by the performers, the level of difficulty of the stunts, and the execution of the transitions, which a simple, long, steady full shot of the performances, with minimal cuts to medium or close shots, could provide.

Narrative editing is simply putting together different shots to tell a story. Linear editing is the simplest and most common. It involves the composition of shots or sounds that forward a story in chronological order to achieve temporal and spatial continuity. All genres and formats of local broadcast programs generally follow a chronological sequence of events or activities that are divided into segments. Inverted editing begins at a particular point in the present, leaves this point to flashback a past or jumps to the future through the device of flash forwards, then returns to the present. Inverted editing is generally employed in drama programs and children’s fantasy stories. Parallel editing shows two or more separate actions taking place, generally but not necessarily, in different places or times. The actions either converge at a particular sequence or continue their separate movements until a certain pattern of the narrative is produced. The fast-paced parallel cuts in the Mexican telenovela Marimar, 1996, RPN 9, has greatly influenced the extensive use of this editing technique in local telenovelas like Pangako sa ‘Yo (The Promise), 2000, and Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), 2009, both on ABS-CBN.

Editing involves the compression or expansion of time and space using the principle of ellipses. An ellipse can be explicit, such as the use of dissolves of the same object, place or image in a different time or setting. An ellipse can be implicit, which is a parallel cut of the same object, place or image in a different time or setting but with other audio-visual elements altered to imply the change. The opening sequence of Katipunan, a drama series about the life of national hero Andres Bonifacio, 2013, GMA, written by Ian Victoriano and directed by King Marc Baco, is an excellent example of the use of implicit ellipses, such as light and darkness, innocence and violence, and body movements of sprightliness and fear, which are assembled from scenes of various times and spaces into a montage to simultaneously create parallelism, synchronism, and anti-theses, which are types of editing treatment seen in works by Soviet filmmakers Sergei Eisenstein and Vsevolid Pudovkin (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966). The melancholic tone of the hero’s narration and the naiveté of a young woman running innocently in the sun-drenched virgin forest are marred and negated by inserted sequences of the massacre of revolting men and women peasants in the dead of night and that of a young woman, the same woman in the opening shots, now in pain, molested, running aimlessly in the dark, desecrated forest, until she reaches the edge of the earth and plunges herself into the deep void. Implicit time-space ellipses are extended to shots of bodies of the massacred peasants that are abruptly cut to the young woman’s body on a boulder, in another place and time, now dead, lying face down, her eyes staring at the camera.

Some programs use expressive editing, labeled by some scholars as Eisenstein’s intellectual montage editing to create a collision of ideas (Beauvais 1990, Casebier 1976, MacCann 1966). Expressive editing juxtaposes nonrelated images, dialogue, and sounds to establish meanings or create feelings that would not have been evoked had these elements not been linked together. The meanings or feelings arise not in the individual shot or sound, but in the fusing together of these elements. Some radio dramas of UP Nating Mahal (University of the Philippines, Our Beloved), 2015, DZUP 1602, employed this approach. An example is the episode “Sinapupunan” (Womb), about a fetus deciding to abort herself or continue the bloody birthing process to face the uncertainties of life in the Third World. Each stage of the process is punctuated by lines from the works of Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Victor Jara, Pablo Neruda, Lu Xun, Otto Rene Castillo, Joi Barrios, Lilia Quindoza-Santiago, Fidel Rillo, and Emmanuel Lacaba, with each excerpt sneaking in and out of the sequences. The final sequence is a montage of multiple tracks of simultaneous sounds of shivering human flesh, splintering bones, bubbling blood of capillaries, the rising vapor of body heat, and the simmering fluid of slimy internal organs, while the uneven soft thuds of a baby’s movement is heard, slowly creeping out of her mother’s womb. Embedded in this multi-layered mix is the guitar music of “Jocelynang Baliuag,” the theme song of the Philippine revolution of 1896. The cacophony of sounds ends in a burst of contracting muscles, a deep sigh, and a triumphant cry of a baby. To punctuate the notion of birthing a just society, the guitar music engulfs all the remaining uncertainties invoked by the sound effects of the drama.

On television, expressive editing was applied by Lupita Concio in Malikmata (Phantasm), 1972, ABC 5, and Lino Brocka in Guni-guni (Imagination), 1979, GMA, correlating an object with an unrelated image to charge the sequences with intimations of the unknown and the macabre. Marcial Sanson’s historical drama The Life of Emilio Aguinaldo, 1975, BBC 2, had parallel cuts of objects, symbols, and human characters set in limbo to impress a sense of ambiguity on the character of the hero. Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s satirical gag show Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89, IBC 13, embedded movie excerpts or real-life news clips on to narratives of current events, both fictional and real, to create incongruity and relatedness. Adolf Alix Jr’s “The Flora and Harry Gasser Story,” an episode in the drama anthology Wagas (Pure) 2014, GMA News TV, about the life of popular newscaster Harry Gasser and his wife, actor Flora Gasser, intelligently assembled or disaggregated sequences to jar the lines that divide Flora’s spoken narrative and private thoughts, the shifting worlds of the dead and the living, and the fluidity of the past and the present in times of mourning. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III,  with notes from Hazel Gulmatico Hernandez and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

text:
Broadcast education refers to formal schooling in a university or college setting often leading to a Bachelor of Arts degree. On the other hand, broadcast training refers to informal, nondegree courses that provide practical broadcast skills. The latter are usually short-term hands-on programs.

 

Until 1966 when the University of the Philippines (UP) began offering the first degree program in Broadcasting in the country, there was no formal schooling for broadcasters, except through a number of subjects in Speech and Drama programs in some universities and colleges and through training on the job. Today the Commission on Higher Education (CHED) has accredited 28 universities and colleges offering a Bachelor of Arts degree in Broadcasting and 302 others offering a general Mass Communication or Media Arts program with Broadcasting either as a major or as a minor. The availability of such formal training in the last few decades has shifted the character of broadcasting’s labor force and, consequently, the programs produced for broadcast. In the first few decades of radio and television, broadcasters took their theater and bodabil experiences to the air and learned the rest while on the job. Once UP began producing its first Broadcasting graduates in the 1970s, the entry of formally trained broadcasters began.

 

 

The UP curriculum for Broadcasting majors includes production courses such as writing for broadcast, directing and producing programs, production design, and performance, as well as subjects in media law and ethics, media theories and research, and now digital media and its various implications. Apart from running its two television and two radio studios, the degree program enjoys the benefit of having its own laboratory radio station, DZUP 1602 on the AM band. As the official radio station of UP, DZUP trains students as well as operates as a full-scale station with a daily programming of 14 hours, with live streaming online. Being the only Center of Excellence in Broadcasting in the country declared by CHED, the UP undergraduate program in Broadcasting serves as the model for similar programs in other universities and colleges, whose faculty also come to UP to take a master of arts program that provides them with advanced courses in Broadcasting.

 

An alternative to formal education in broadcasting are nondegree training programs for aspiring broadcasters. The Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP), the biggest association of broadcasters in the Philippines, conduct regular seminars and workshops for its members, who comprise around 90 percent of the Philippine radio and TV stations and broadcasters in the country. Training areas include news reporting, performance, and media laws. In 2015, the KBP launched the Continuing Education for Broadcasters. The modules cover timely issues such as disaster and crisis reporting, media convergence, and media ethics.

 

Radio and television networks also conduct in-house training and workshops for their employees, notably ABS-CBN, GMA, TV5, Manila Broadcasting Corporation, Bombo Radio, and the Far Eastern Broadcasting Network. Some successful broadcasters have put up training centers, such as the Tanghalang Parisukat Training Center, which conducts free classes for youth from poor families. Organized by radio dramatist Eloisa Cruz-Canlas, the center has classes on radio announcing; acting on radio and television, film, and stage; voice dubbing and singing; musical composition and musical instruments; and production, direction, and scriptwriting for radio and theater.Written by Rosa Maria T. Feliciano

text:
Ethics in the broadcast profession is embodied by professional codes that prescribe the ideal standard behavior for broadcasters. For the broadcast industry, the relevant professional code is the Broadcast Code of the Philippines 2007, as amended, which was promulgated by the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP). Though some major broadcast organizations do not maintain KBP membership, they nonetheless have their own professional codes that, to an extent, echo the Broadcast Code of the Philippines. As such, a practitioner in any broadcast organization will always have a basis for what constitutes an ideal broadcast professional in the field. The Broadcast Code of the Philippines, as well as the respective codes of other broadcast organizations, contain provisions that attempt to address different situations that a practitioner may face. Ranging from provisions tackling on-air decorum, news and public affairs, individual rights, and children’s programming and welfare, professional codes for broadcast exhaustively prescribe the expected traits and courses of action to practice the profession in a responsible, moral, honest, and fair manner (KBP 2007).

 

Normally, broadcast practitioners need only take the provisions of these codes to heart for guidance on how to rightfully practice their profession and guide them in producing content. However, there have been instances not covered by these codes, or situations that may be called grey areas, where thoughtful ethical behavior should have taken over. Classic examples from news programs include the attribution of criminal suspects’ minority religions (i.e., Muslim terrorists but never Christian ones), inclusion of personal opinions in news reports, and robbing interviewees’ of dignity by focusing on their plight of misery. These practices have led to the “standardization” of unethical practices that do not contribute relevant information for the public interest or general welfare. In entertainment, a well-known incident decried by the public as child abuse on-air involved the prolonged ridicule of a minor contestant by a variety show’s host in spite of the obvious distress of the child. In a competing variety program, hosts frequently exchanged offensive barbs by using homophobic language and slurs that shamed game contestants for their physical appearances.

 

 

Critics contend that the above examples, widely used in broadcast media, have led to these practices being accepted as normal behavior, evidenced by the rather common use of offensive slurs and the loss of basic courtesy and respect in everyday life. Various groups have censured certain broadcasters on social media, denouncing the latter’s failure to ennoble society and advance culture, and calling for a review of professional codes and their implementation, with the assumption that ethical issues may be addressed through said codes.

 

What used to be “standard practice” and “normal behavior” among broadcasters may take many years to change. One example is the coverage and portrayal of children in broadcast media. Before the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UN CRC) in 1990, the child’s privacy was not considered an issue. Radio and television coverage did not hide faces and identities of children who had been victims of sexual molestation, rape, incest, physical abuse, criminalization, and other forms of exploitation. Showing the young victims was not perceived to be a violation of the children’s right to privacy. Child rights groups were instrumental in pointing out to broadcasters that mass media is so invasive and widespread that a single news coverage can impair the present situation of the child as well as his/her future. Interviews by broadcasters and the subsequent portrayal of the child may traumatize the child victim even more. Up to the early 1990s, it was unthinkable for TV coverage to show faceless children. Generally, it was perceived that a faceless or concealed character on TV will not hold audience attention and thus be inimical to audience ratings. By late 1990s, child rights groups in the Philippines stepped up its campaign to popularize the ethical standards in the media coverage of children. These groups held dialogues and educational campaigns to build a child-friendly broadcast media. In 1999, the Department of Justice issued its own guidelines on child reporting. Unfortunately, the early years of the campaign resulted in the avoidance of broadcast media to cover children’s issues because of the complicated process of covering children. Finally, 17 years after the UN CRC, the KBP also released a clear-cut guideline in Article 3 “Coverage Involving Children” of the Broadcast Code of the Philippines. The KBP Guidelines have been important in inculcating child sensitivity among members of the broadcast industry. But the roles of civil society and audience opinion are influential in pushing for the adherence of desired ethical standards among broadcasters. Written by Roland Antonio O. Guia Jr and Rosalie S. Matilac

 

 

Sources

Bivins 2004; Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) 2011; Patterson and Wilkins 2014; Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism 2006; Shaw 2005.

text:
Franchising in television involves the licensing of an original program by its creator, who has intellectual property rights over the creation, to other production groups or television stations for commercial exploitation. A version of the franchised concept is then produced with the same or a slightly modified title.

 

This practice is part of the long tradition in the Philippines of importing and adapting foreign television programs through canned shows and their local interpretations and licensed versions. This has impacted not only the overall mix of local programming but also the production concepts, styles, and conventions of locally produced shows. On the other hand, local television shows have also been franchised out of the country, as in the case of the long-running and commercially successful noontime variety show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo), which was first franchised to Indonesian stationSurya Citra Televisi(SCTV)from Jul 2012 until Apr 2014, with the title Eat Bulaga! Indonesia. The program continued in the same year with its new titleThe New Eat Bulaga! Indonesia in ANTV, another Indonesian television network.

 

 

International franchising of successful television programs, mostly from Europe and the US, began in the 1990s, invading Philippine television beginning in the 2000s. The earliest known and popular version of the international franchised program that came into the country was the international hit Who Wants To Be A Millionaire, 2000, which aired on IBC-13. The station also aired the equally successful UK franchise The Weakest Link in the same year. The game show Family Feud had three franchised versions, one in 2001, then in 2008 and finally in 2011. Other game show franchises include Wheel of Fortune aired on ABC 5 in 2001 and again on ABS-CBN in 2008 while the Philippine versions of The Price is Right also aired on ABC 5 in 2001 and ABS-CBN in 2011. The successes of these local game show franchises pale in comparison to the phenomenal successes of the ABS-CBN game program Kapamilya Deal or No Deal, 2006-09, hosted by Kris Aquino, based on the international franchise Deal or No Deal. Another version of said franchise, this time hosted by Luis Manzano aired in 2012, and then again in 2015. The not so popular Pinoy Bingo Night, a franchise of National Bingo Night had a short stint in the station in 2009.

 

Other successful franchised formats that were easily exported and then adapted by Philippine television included the long-running Pinoy Big Brother, a franchise of the international hit, Big Brother, on ABS-CBN. As of 2015, Pinoy Big Brother has been airing for 10 years with 12 regular seasons. Other attempts of franchised reality programming included the two seasons of Pinoy Dream Academy based on an Endemol European franchise that was similar in format to Pinoy Big Brother but featured aspiring singers. A version of the franchised concept is then produced with the same or a slightly modified title.

This practice is part of the long tradition in the Philippines of importing and adapting foreign television programs through canned shows and their local interpretations and licensed versions. This has impacted not only the overall mix of local programming but also the production concepts, styles, and conventions of locally produced shows. On the other hand, local television shows have also been franchised out of the country, as in the case of the long-running and commercially successful noontime variety show Eat Bulaga! The program continued in the same year with its new titleThe New Eat Bulaga! Indonesia in ANTV, another Indonesian television network.

text:
Intellectual property rights comprise the bundle of privileges and protections accorded to persons responsible for the creation, performance, and invention of works in the fields of the arts, sciences, and industry. Generally, these rights arise from the fact that these works are the result of the intellectual and creative process undergone by the person or persons creating, performing, or inventing them. The recognition of these rights encourages creativity and originality, the fruits of which are protected as the property of the creator. Philippine laws on intellectual property encompass the following forms: copyright, trademarks, and patents. Copyright is the form of protection given to artistic and literary works that are originally and intellectually created. A trademark is the protection given to symbols or signs that uniquely distinguishes a product or service as belonging to the owner. A patent pertains to new and technical solutions to human problems, which must also involve an invention that is industrially applicable.

In broadcasting, it is copyright protection that commonly applies. This protects the rights of broadcast organizations, in conjunction with the rights of scriptwriters, directors, performers, and other persons, to have the sole authority to carry out, authorize, or prevent certain acts involving the radio and television programs they air, including: reproduction of the whole or substantial portion of a radio or TV program; dramatization, translation, or other transformation of these programs; and public display or other communication to the public of these works. In addition to copyright, broadcast organizations have exclusive rights to carry out, authorize, or prevent the following: the rebroadcasting of their broadcasts; the recording of their broadcasts for the purpose of communication to the public; and the use of such records for fresh transmission or fresh recording. The protections given to broadcasts ensure that the effort of the people behind them will be respected and preserved. These broadcasts will not be unjustly taken advantage of, and will still fall under the name and control of those who produced them in the first place. In effect, intellectual property rights encourage the creation of a broadcast industry that is original, diverse, and beneficial to the public.

However, in spite of the rules governing intellectual property rights, comments from the public that radio and TV shows are recycled from the past continue to be heard. The explanation lies in the scope of copyright. There are certain types of concepts that are not covered by copyright protection simply because of their nature. Subject matter such as ideas, concepts, principles, discoveries, mere data, news of the day, are unprotected by virtue of the fact that they are already existent in daily life without anyone exercising their intellect to create them. In short, these matters are already there even before any human intervention; in fact, what is left is for persons to interpret them in their own way. Thus, the general idea of a game show, drama program, dating game, variety show, comedy program, or any other show for that matter, are not subject to copyright only because they are mere formats. What is left is for the broadcast industry to fill out these formats in their own unique ways. Of course, outright copying violates intellectual property rights, but the way to go around it is to alter a bit of dialogue, rearrange the order of events, introduce new characters and take away a few ones, and an “original” program is made. With this technicality, originality and diversity take a back seat to profitability, popularity, and beating the deadline.

The concern for intellectual property rights in the present broadcast environment has led to a unique brand of “creativity”: broadcast practitioners are tasked to replicate the success of past programs while maintaining a level of originality that will exonerate them from copyright infringement. The local broadcast landscape is replete with programs that, upon first glance, look and feel alike while apparently creating and sustaining their own momentum through innovations on scriptwriting and production techniques, and use of new actors. Because copyright infringement, a form of plagiarism, is a crime against intellectual property, broadcast practitioners and producers are required to at least imbue their own brand of improvement and novelty to an otherwise similar work. This can be seen by how producers modify Asian, Mexican, English, and American program properties, to cater to Filipino tastes after lawfully procuring the intellectual property rights attached to them. (See Franchising.) This environment under intellectual property protection shows that ingenuity, inventiveness, and cleverness are still encouraged within the broadcast profession out of respect for the intellectual property of others, however indirect it may seem. Written by Roland Antonio O. Guia Jr

Sources

The 1987 Constitution of the Republic of the Philippines; Elidad... 2002.; Francisco... 1999; Intellectual Property Office of the Philippines Website; World Intellectual Property Organization Website.

text:
Labor refers to everyone who provides work in exchange for wages or remuneration, to contribute to the production of programs and the operation of broadcast stations. Because the broadcast industry is labor-intensive, compensation is a major business expense. While stations need to maintain a steady base of workers to keep operations stable, not all workers are hired on a regular basis. Actors, musicians, announcers, and other performers are often hired on a per-project or even per-episode basis. They are called talents, whose employment in effect is contractual. Others, including regular production staff and crew whose services are required on a regular, daily basis, are hired as permanent employees after six months of probation, in compliance with labor laws in the Philippines. However, beginning in the 1990s, broadcast companies have resorted to rampant contractualization not only of those traditionally called talents but also of many middle- to low-ranked employees whose services are necessary on a daily or regular basis. Many are now also called talents, hired based on production projects, and are denied not only permanent appointments but also benefits due regular employees, including retirement benefits.

 

 

Since the nature of the broadcast business requires that many workers work on each program, stations now commonly classify programs as projects and pay the crew based on a pre-determined output. Some programs last only a season or a few months, but other programs may run for more than a year or indefinitely. In both situations, workers are paid on regular intervals and not on a piecemeal basis, a condition which under the Philippine Labor Code is classified as regular employment. However, networks and stations circumvent the law and maintain instead a vast army of talents.

 

Moreover, due to the requirements of production, management prerogative, or the right of employers to determine terms and conditions of employment, has frequently obligated broadcast workers to work beyond regular hours. It is the finished production that is the basis of pay regardless of the number of hours put in to perform the required work. Furthermore, finished productions are subject to replays, for which the production crew receives no supplementary compensation even if the replay brings in additional income for the station.

 

Practices in news and public affairs departments often demand that reporters submit stories not only to the several news and current affairs programs in their main network but also to sister or affiliated networks, stations, or news agencies again with no extra compensation. The multiple obligations limit their ability to develop well researched stories, often resulting in recycled news and feature materials.

 

On the other hand, on-camera performers, particularly those in entertainment programs, such as dramas, sitcoms, and variety shows, are subject to a different set of hiring practices and compensation schemes. New programs typically hire big-name stars who command high talent fees, supported by new talents whose following is yet to be developed. The latter are paid lower fees and are not yet in a position to demand high talent fees. Once the program is established and the erstwhile new talents have developed a following, the big-name stars are let go, reducing the cost of production. The newer upcoming stars do not necessarily receive higher remuneration but may be rewarded with nonmonetary bonuses like trips abroad. Talent agents, previously external to stations and whose job was to scout for and train talents and broker their contracts, are also now internally hired by stations. Everyone is tied to individually negotiated contracts, which contain clauses that prohibit them to work for the competition for as long as two years after their contracts have expired, if not renewed. Contract renewal is not guaranteed. Child performers are subject to similar conditions, except that their working hours are limited and tutorials are provided to make up for possibly lost school hours. This is a recent development provided by the Philippine Labor Code brought about by complaints against child labor conditions.

 

Hiring terms and work conditions in the broadcast industry affect the morale and creativity of everyone involved in the production of programs, and consequently, the quality of the shows produced.

The prevailing labor practices in the broadcast industry have rendered unstable the employment future of many of its workers, which in the long term discourages talented broadcasters from staking their careers in the industry, as a result affecting the quality of programming. Written by Josefina M. C. Santos

text:
Laws and regulations of the Philippine government can significantly affect the kind and quality of programs that may be broadcast. An example is Presidential Decree No 1986, which created the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB). It provides the guidelines for the classification of programs fit for particular age groups, such as General Patronage (“G”), Parental Guidance (“PG”), Strong Parental Guidance (“SPG”), and Disapproved for Airing on Television (“X”). The idea is to ensure that children are not unnecessarily exposed to material that is deemed incompatible to them psychologically and emotionally. These ratings likewise allow parents to monitor the content of what broadcasts their children are exposed to, and guide them accordingly. PD 1986, combined with Republic Act No 8370 or The Children’s Television Act of 1997, protects children’s minds, which are viewed as vulnerable and impressionable, by classifying and formulating programs that are regarded as child-friendly and beneficial to their continued growth and development. Consequently, in producing content, broadcasters are wary of material or subject matter that can affect the rating of their programs. Those who produce programs exclusively for very young children take care that the programs do not contain anything unsuitable to a G rating. On the other hand, those gearing for teenage viewing should keep in mind the criteria relevant to theme, language, nudity, sex, violence, horror, and drugs, considered by the MTRCB for classifying programs under PG or SPG. Nonconsideration of the criteria may lead to the disapproval of a program’s airing under the X classification.

Aside from the protection and care for children, laws are also put in place to preserve the rights of individuals. Since everyone has the right to a good reputation, libel and slander laws were put in place under Articles 353 to 364 of the Revised Penal Code of the Philippines. These provisions define what constitutes defamatory material, and the manner by which they are made in order to constitute the crime of either libel or slander. Needless to say, in the exercise of a free press, the broadcast practitioner should remember the forms of speech and expression that fall outside the protection of the Constitutional Guarantee. To illustrate this, broadcasters and program hosts who make spiteful or hateful accusations and assertions against other persons on air may expect a criminal case filed against them.

Another right that needs protection by law is the right of an individual to be credited or to profit from the products of one’s intellect and industry. Hence, the existence of Republic Act No 8293 or the Intellectual Property Code of the Philippines. This law defines what intellectual property rights are accorded to authors, entrepreneurs, and inventors, creating certain kinds of works. In addition, the law provides for the acts which constitute violation of intellectual property rights, and which acts do not. It also provides for the legal remedies available in the event that intellectual property rights are violated. Those behind a station’s programming should make sure to secure the rights of an original work from its author in case they wish to adapt the same into a program, or use the same in any way, shape, or form, during any of their shows. Also, broadcasters, especially those in commentaries and editorials, should always be wary of paraphrasing or quoting the works of others lest they violate intellectual property rights in instances of misattribution or making none at all. The broadcast practitioner should always bear in mind that as far as intellectual property is concerned, when in doubt, permission from the original author should be secured, and the proper attribution be made. The Doctrine of Fair Use as found in RA 8293 gives leeway to use works and materials for comment, criticism or news reporting, without violating the owner’s intellectual property rights.

Aside from laws and regulations that directly affect the production of broadcasts, there are also those that can indirectly affect the same. Among the practices of broadcast organizations today is one that attempts to go around the provisions of Presidential Decree No. 442, as amended, or the Labor Code of the Philippines. This practice involves the constant renewal of broadcast practitioners as contractual workers, denying them the financial and social benefits accorded regular employees who are essential and necessary for the broadcast organizations. This practice reduces expenses and increases profit for the broadcast organization, but at the expense of the practitioner who is put into a position where one’s skills and talents cannot be maximized. Such a work environment leads to demoralization due to the fact that years, and in some instances decades, worth of service is not recognized because of the denial of employment status that these practitioners are qualified for and deserve. In effect, broadcast practitioners might be tempted to commit unethical acts for increased financial gain; to give minimal effort to the programs they produce, thus denying their employers, and by extension the audience, the products of their full potential; or to be disillusioned with their profession, thereafter leaving their dreams and visions on the table, again to the detriment of the audience.

Another legal development that can affect production is the move to amend the provision in the constitution limiting ownership and operation of media to Filipinos. This limitation was put in place in recognition of mass media’s power to influence and shape society’s opinion and way of thinking. To allow foreigners to take part in this powerful and pervasive profession will likewise allow the direct entry of outside influences that may run counter to Filipino culture, mores, and philosophies; leading to programming that may not be relevant and relatable to our local audiences. Written byRoland Antonio O. Guia Jr

Sources

1987 Consitution of the Republic of the Philippines n.d.; Labor Code of the Philippines n.d.; The Revised Penal Code of the Philippines n.d.; Supreme Court of the Philippines n.d.

text:
Performances in broadcast range from the dramatic to the nondramatic with singing and dancing thrown in between. Dramatic performances consist of acting in soap operas, drama, situational comedies, advertisements, and other dramatic radio and television genres. Nondramatic performances may include hosting a talk, game, variety, DJ (disc jockey), and VJ (video jockey) show; reading the news; presenting a documentary or feature program; and endorsing a product.

In the broadcast talent circles, which include talents, talent managers, talent casters, promoters, and producers, the versatile performer is the ideal: a performer capable of both dramatic and nondramatic performance. An example is German Moreno, whose moniker is Master Showman. Also called Kuya Germs, Moreno acted in several drama series and comedy programs including Niño, 2014, GMA Channel 7. He is also known for hosting the variety shows Superstar, 1971-89, RPN Channel 9, with Nora Aunor and That’s Entertainment!, 1986-96, GMA Channel 7. In these programs, he also sang and danced. Aside from these entertainment programs, Moreno hosted public affairs programs on television including Negosiyete: Mag-Aral sa GMA (Business at Seven: Let’s Learn at GMA), 1990-97, GMA Channel 7.

Versatility also means the ability to cross media and performance platforms such as theater, film, radio, and television. Moving from one medium to another has been evident even during the early days of radio and television. Among those who performed on several platforms in the first decades of radio and television were Jovita Fuentes, Atang dela Rama, Katy dela Cruz, Chichay, Dely Atay-Atayan, Dely Magpayo, Leopoldo Salcedo, Eddie San Jose, Dolphy, Pugo, and Sylvia La Torre. Performers from the stage brought their performance techniques and styles into radio and television. For instance, the traditions and conventions of bodabil were found in blocktime radio programs during the American colonial period and up to the first several years of television. An example of this type of program is Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), ABS-CBN, 1965-71, where bodabil slapstick humor was a staple.

In the last few decades of the 20th century, some of the notable performers on several platforms and genres were Nora Aunor, Vilma Santos, Tessie Tomas, Noel Trinidad, Lea Salonga, Martin Nievera, Charo Santos, Joey de Leon, Judy Ann Santos, Boots Anson-Roa, and Ariel Ureta. The movement from one medium to another continues in the industry, bringing with it the changing styles in performance. In early radio drama, the over-stylized external form of dramatic acting was brought over from theater, particularly the komedya and bodabil. (See “Theater” in Sources and Influences in Philippine Radio and Television.) In the 1970s, the more organic internalized style of acting that became popular in Philippine movies directed by the likes of Ishmael Bernal and Lino Brocka found its way into radio and television drama.

Performance styles are also influenced by other factors. Global trends in radio performance were adopted by local announcers. Having been strongly influenced by American broadcast, the early days of radio announcing followed the American mid-western accent that was the norm in the United States. Filipino disc jockeys tried to sound like their American counterparts. More recently, the roots of the masa programming on FM radio, so called due to its appeal to the masses, as exemplified in the program Tambalang Balasubas at Balahura (A Swindler and a Filthy Tandem) hosted by Nicole Hyala and Cris Tsuper on DZMB 90.7, can be traced to the free-wheeling, risqué, and adult radio programming in the US. Local comedy bar humor and performance style is also evident on masa radio.

Performers change their styles according to the conventions of the medium into which they move. For example, Mike Enriquez used a well-modulated and mellow baritone voice with an Americanized speech pattern while he was a DJ from 1969 on various radio stations, where English was the announcing language. Upon becoming a newscaster for GMA Channel 7 in 1995, Enriquez adopted the frenetic and strident style of live broadcast news by sounding agitated and hurried, foregoing his smooth and relaxed style.

Performance styles are also affected by the training the performer undergoes. Training can come from learning on the job, instructions of directors, and formal schooling. Formal training for broadcast performance, specifically for radio announcing, first appeared in Speech and Drama programs, and later in Mass Communication courses, in universities. (See Education and Training.) Workshops and seminars on performance are also given by organizations like the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) and broadcast networks like ABS-CBN and GMA. Performers like Eloisa Cruz Canlas, popularly known as Lola Sela Bungagera (Loudmouth Grandma Sela), took in young apprentices to hone their talent in voice acting for radio. Performers must also acquire technical skills like using various types of microphones, applying makeup, and camera blocking.

Even with training and talent, breaking into the mainstream broadcast industry is difficult. The star system prefers the established bankable stars, even if they are not well-trained, over new and untested performers with talent and the training in broadcast performance. Such preferences affect the quality of the programs produced in mainstream radio and television. Written by Fernando A. Austria Jr

Source

Protacio 2014.

text:
Production design is the art and craft of creating the look and mood of a narrative material in consonance with the director’s vision of the script or material and in tandem with the cinematography and lighting. It assembles and choreographs visual elements to highlight the emotion and feel of a show.

 

As applied art, in production design the visible elements of line, shape, color, texture, value, and space are employed to produce a unity or variety through the principles of balance, proportion, rhythm, harmony, and emphasis. These elements are imbedded in the materials of production design which come in the form of dress, adornment, functional and decorative objects, spaces, and places that are placed according to the context of period, geography, time frame, and duration of the material.The basic principle in combining these elements is to enrich, not to steal, the scene away from the actors or narrative.

 

 

The relationship of the production designer with key people of a TV production, like the producer and the director, is essentially one of collaboration and mutual dependence.The designer addresses the intents of the director and concretizes them accordingly. He gives the director the material world of the program or story as closely as it is envisioned. The production designer collaborates with the director of photography or videographer, to ensure that the world is recorded appropriately. The production designer relates and communicates the design as accurately and as quantifiably as possible to the producer so that the designgets all the financial and logistical support for it to be realized at the time it is needed.

 

The bulk of design work happens in preproduction, during which research, discussions, brainstorming, drawing, ocular inspections, location hunting, planning, fittings, scheduling, cost estimates, bidding, purchasing, and sourcing of materials happen. This is the phase in which the designer conjures the material and photographable world of the story and operationalizes it according to visual elements and principles as applied to objects, places, spaces, and periods or time. In the production stage, the conceived world is transformed to its material existence and recorded by the camera, subjecting design to the language of the lens and the camera. At this phase, the exigencies that come with the coverage of the designer’s work affect the amount of detail and/or broad view of this world. For this reason, it is important that the director of photography, the director and production designer are on the same page all the time. In postproduction, the role of design mostly comes in the form of consultation and verification because all these concerns must have already been taken up during the preproduction and production phases.

 

The elements and principles for nondramatic and dramatic TV productions are the same. The difference lies in the basis of design. In nondramatic material, the basis of the design is the TV program profile or brief, which outlines its aims and objectives, mood and tone, the profile or persona of the broadcast personality, program format, and the target audience. In a dramatic or fiction material, the basis of design is the narrative. This difference creates a shift in the responsibility of the designer towards the material. In nondramatic material, the designer’s sense towards existing tastes, trends, and sensibilities in industry practice and audiences is more direct. In dramatic material, this sense is more related towards the story or narrative as envisioned by the director, writers, and members of the creative team.In television nowadays, however, the boundary between dramatic and nondramatic materials in production design has been taken down. Dramatic materials may take the elements of nondramatic materials and vice versa.

 

 

The visual look of the structures and decorations may either be realistic or imaginary, or may adhere to a specific art movement, or a combination of any of these depending on what is required by the concept of a show. The look for all variety programs and game shows are mainly decorative.

 

Early Philippine television dramas had designs patterned after the theater proscenium. The set was constructed to fit the TV studio, like in Fr James Reuter’s production of Edmond Rostand’s Cyrano de Bergerac, considered the first TV drama production, aired live in 1953 on ABS-CBN. Similar designs that were theatrical in orientation in terms of production design and aired live from the studio premises were Fr Reuter’s Family Theater, early 1960s; and Obra Maestra, late 1960s, both on ABS-CBN (Rodrigo 2006). The anthology Salamin ng Buhay (Mirror of Life), 1960s, ABS-CBN, was one of the first drama shows that recorded episodes outside the studio to enhance the realism of the narrative (Francisco 2005). The design for the contemporary drama series My Husband’s Lover, 2013, GMA, is realistic as it depicted the look of the everyday lives of its middle-class characters. Mulawin, 2004-05, GMA, a fantasy drama showed the imaginary world of winged humans. Okay Ka, Fairy Ko (You Are Okay, My Fairy), which premiered in 1987, IBC 13, combined both the realistic and the imaginary and moved from the real-life settings to the fantasy kingdom of Enkantasya Magenta, the lead character’s mother-in-law.

 

Most types of programs require production design except for documentaries in which the real look and conditions of the subject or topic have to be documented. Batas Militar (Martial Law), a documentary produced by the Foundation of Worldwide People Power in 1997, used footage showing actual scenes from the martial law era. But in historical documentaries and similar genres where re-enactments are needed, the services of a designer are warranted. Scenes depicting the life of Jose Rizal were designed by Gino Gonzales for the documentary Ang Buhay ni Jose Rizal (The Life of Jose Rizal), 1996, produced by the Bookmark Inc and the History Department of the Ateneo de Manila University. Some documentary, public affairs, and talk programs combine realism and expressionism in the style of the studio set, such as those employed by Review Night, 2001, Cinema One, and Storyline, 2011, ABS-CBN.

 

Computer-generated effects have helped a lot in terms of managing the scope of the production designer’s work especially in set construction, getting the most ideal locations, make-up issues such as aging and prosthetics, and risky and dangerous live effects.These effects should complement, not steal, the artistic and philosophical basis upon which the design is based. The drama serials from ABS-CBN, like the supernatural-adventure series Lobo (Werewolf), 2008, and Juan de la Cruz, 2013; from GMA, such as the fantasy serial Encantadia, 2005, and the epic drama Amaya, 2011-12; and from GMA News TV, the historical drama Ilustrado (The Enlightened), 2014, employed computer-generated effects to recreate make-believe worlds and the Philippines during its pre-colonial and Spanish colonization periods which include elements of architecture, weaponry, jewelry, fashion, and customary practices. In Amaya, an existing hull of a modern boat was redesigned to reconstruct the karakoa, an ancient Filipino warship. Many scenes from these drama series were shot in a so-called sound stage, a studio that houses a green or blue chroma, permanent lighting, and a virtual set system that produces computer-generated moving or still graphics of environments over which moving actors and objects are placed.

 

New technologies have made possible various alternatives to design the look of a show. A virtual set system fits a computer-generated colossal set into a small studio. People, cameras, lighting, and computer graphics of places, events, and other visual elements move together in real time of three-dimensional spaces. In this setup, set designs are no longer built physically, but in software. Designs for background environments, particularly those that are complex, huge, and expensive, are built in a software, transformed digitally, and embedded onto the actual studio images of actors and other visual elements. The virtual set technology has been used in the creation of the new opening billboards for TV5’s news programs and for creative storytelling segments in some children’s shows on various broadcast networks (Unitel 2011). Written by Leo Abaya, Fernando A. Austria Jr, and Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Paul Richard Infante and Amor Olaguer

 

 

Sources

Abaya and Infante 2015; Francisco 2005; Rodrigo 2006; Unitel Website 2011.
