text:
A most critical aspect of production for broadcast is production management, defined simply as proper fiscal management. Rendering a concept into a radio or television show necessitates the execution of numerous details in several phases of production, although the process is much simpler, has less requirements and details, and thus less costly for radio than television. Management of a show is the key to its success as much as good storytelling.The producer is in charge of handling and managing the production budget once it is raised or allocated. S/he is the organizer, the trouble shooter, and post production supervisor in the three phases of production. The greatest challenge for any producer is to strike a balance between the aesthetic demands and the financial requirements of any project.

 

In the preproduction phase, the producer supervises the script development until a director is brought on board to prepare the script for production. It is during this period that the producer makes sure that the scriptwriter has polished the script to perfection or near perfection. Any necessary change in the script, which may require an adjustment in the production budget, must be done at this time. The producer breaks down the script during the preproduction phase to see the consequences of its every aspect. A complete breakdown of the scenes helps the producer see clearly the practical challenges of the project. A script breakdown is also the guide in planning the shooting schedule, which affects the efficient use of the budget. Based on the script, the producer determines the approximate budget, the cast and crew, the locations, the requirements of the art department like costume, sets, make-up, and props, and the target audience. Part of the process of creating the budget is negotiating for the fees of the cast and the crew members, hiring key support people, securing locations, and the construction of sets. The budget should also include the setup of auditions and rehearsals for the actors.

 

 

During the production phase, the producer sets the start of the shooting period. From the beginning of the shoot, the producer keeps a daily watch on both the budget and the part of the script that is being shot, but at the same time must be supportive of the director and the crew by creating a comfortable work environment. Arrangements for the locations, transportation, equipment, and food must be confirmed and reconfirmed to avoid problems on the shooting day itself. Each shooting day presents unique challenges. The producer must be able to deal with each problem as it arises. The problems must not interfere with the schedule or the set’s momentum. Every second counts once the camera starts to grind. Unlike the preproduction phase, the production period no longer has the luxury of time. The producer must act as the troubleshooter during this period.

The relationship between producer and director is crucial. The producer must support the director’s work while the director must also understand the producer’s responsibility. Although the director is the authority figure on the set, s/he answers to the producer.If the director’s decision affects the budget, the practical challenges must first be consulted with the producer before a decision is made.

 

 

In the postproduction phase, the producer sees to it that the budget for editing, scoring, titling, and other postproduction needs is secured and that additional requirements can be covered with any money left. It is not uncommon for projects to go over budget and usually it is postproduction that is seriously affected. The producer must also see to it that the budget for contingency is not exhausted at this point. Otherwise it may mean holding up the postproduction process because the budget has been depleted. Written by Amor Olaguer

Otherwise it may mean holding up the postproduction process because the budget has been depleted. Written by Amor Olaguer

text:
Programming for radio and television refers to both the act of choosing and ordering programs and the outcome of this act, which is a pre-determined program schedule. The schedule is usually organized into daily and weekly grids, in some cases for a longer period of time, such as a month or a quarter, with positions of programs like newscasts presumed to be more or less stable over an indefinite period of time. The basic principle is to schedule programs so that they reach the maximum number of target audiences. A common programming strategy is to match the schedule with listener and viewer habits. For example, after World War II, audience research suggested that housewives, the target of the early soap operas, comprised the bulk of radio listeners during the day. Thus, dramas were aired accordingly, with advertising spots of mostly household and consumer goods also placed at these hours. The early evening hours, on the other, hand, were believed to have the largest audience size, with all the members of the family presumed to be home. These hours came to be known as primetime, at which programs with the broadest appeal are scheduled. While audience habits and the demands of living in the late 20th and early 21st centuries have shifted, with programming adjusting to the shifts, and while audience segmentation has become finer, with audiences using multiple media platforms, the principle of programming remains the same.

From the beginning of broadcasting in the Philippines, which was in the 1920s during the American colonial period, programming on radio has followed the American radio programming structure, which was 15-minute programs of music, variety, and the less common news and talk shows. After World War II, both radio and television programming continued to be influenced by the American model. On radio, dramas and news remained at 15 minutes but variety shows and musicals expanded to one hour. In television, the importation of many canned shows from the United States to fill in broadcast time determined local programming structure. Sitcoms (situational comedies) and news programs ran for thirty minutes while drama series and documentaries ran for an hour. Locally-produced programs then conformed to this configuration.

In the 1950s, popular canned US programs filled the local television airwaves, but local producers began experimenting with the live variety shows Pista ng Caltex (Caltex Fiesta) and, migrated from radio, Darigold Jamboree, United American Tiki-Tiki Show, Ang Inyong Lingkod, Tia Dely (At Your Service, Aunt Dely), and the popular amateur singing contest Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage). While the 1960s continued the trend of mixed canned and local programming, local television began to produce more shows that gained popularity among Filipino audiences. Among these were live musical-variety programs such as the sponsored Lucky Strike Show, An Evening with Pilita featuring singer and actor Pilita Corrales, Buhay Artista (Actor’s Life) with Dolphy and Panchito, and the Nida-Nestor Show with Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa. The latter part of the decade saw the emergence of the drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye).

The 1970s were again dominated by American canned programming as some local television producers dropped out, shifted to another medium, or reconfigured programs to conform to the media restrictions imposed by martial law. However, this was also the period of the phenomenally successful sitcom John en Marsha (John and Marsha) and musical variety show Superstar. Also popular were the soap operas Flordeluna and Anna Liza airing on pre-primetime. Notable of the period were the noontime variety programs Student Canteen and Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!). This noontime variety programming trend remains in effect as formats of the same program prevail in current programming. Eat Bulaga, on the air since 1979, is the longest running television program in the country.

In the early 1980s, stations continued to be tentative about creating new programs. However, this careful stance led to the production of cultural programs that were considered also a safe bet, such as the classical music programs Concert at the Park and Paco Park Presents, and the Filipino music show Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing for You). With more contemporary musical formats were Martin and Pops Twogether and Ryan Ryan Musikahan (Music with Ryan). Drama programs also flourished with notable television counterparts of the soap operas Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) and Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home) and the drama anthologies Lovingly Yours, Helen hosted by Helen Vela and Eddie Ilarde’s Kahapon Lamang (Just Yesterday). The 1980s also saw more children’s programming with Batibot (Small but Strong) setting the model for educational children’s shows and similar programs like Pen Pen de Sarapen (children’s rhyme) and Uncle Bob’s Lucky Seven Club. Comedy programs were also popular with the gag programs TODAS (acronym for Television’s Outrageously Delightful All-Star Show) and Champoy (name of a sweet-and-salty dried fruit) starring Noel Trinidad and Subas Herrero.

Programming developments immediately after the EDSA revolt in 1986 led to a drastic change in programming, particularly in news and current affairs. News programs stretched to one hour while primetime programs like drama series, anthologies and sitcoms extended to an hour and a half. Euphoria following the ouster of Marcos produced vibrant news and public affairs talk programs while post-EDSA sentiments were sharply evident in all other programs. Among the public affairs programs that emerged during the period were The Probe Team hosted by Cheche Lazaro and Public Forum hosted by UP professor Randy David. Also notable were the parodies and satires Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Watch Out for the Next Episode), Mongolian Barbecue, and Sic O’Clock News.

For a decade this programming held up, until 1996 when the unknown telenovela Marimar, a canned soap from Mexico, captivated audiences. It aired on RPN Channel 9, then considered a small player. In four months after the initial airing of the program, Marimar was number one in ratings. This led to the adjustments of then industry number one ABS-CBN of its primetime programming, shortening the newscast TV Patrol from an hour to thirty minutes, and moving its top-rating soap opera Mara Clara to pre-primetime. This development completely shifted Philippine primetime programming. Soap operas, which used to occupy nonprimetime slots, are now in primetime. Stripping, the primetime strategy of putting programs on a daily basis instead of only once a week became the primary programming strategy. The change brought back importation of canned programs, this time from sources other than the US. Later programming shifts similar to the Marimar phenomenon included the anime wave in the late 1990s to early 2000s with the return of the Japanese cartoons, now dubbed in Filipino, Voltes V and Daimos. The game show battles in the early 2000s with programs Who Wants To Be A Millionaire and The Weakest Link led to the steady influx of franchised programs, beginning in turn the trend of local franchises including Pinoy Big Brother, Survivor Philippines, Pilipinas Got Talent, and The Voice. Asian imports followed suit in the new millennium when ABS-CBN aired the cult hit Meteor Garden, ushering in the importation of more canned programs from Korea and Taiwan.

These trends show that local programming continues to be shaped by foreign programming trends, Filipino reactions and accommodations of such trends, as well as homegrown Filipino productions.

Written by Jane O. Vinculado

text:
Scriptwriting is the process of conceptualizing and writing the copy to be used by narrators, performers, directors, and editors in radio and television programs. The person who writes this text is the scriptwriter. Other people who may be involved in the scriptwriting process are the producer, director, script supervisor, and brainstormer. The latter is a person who discusses and throws ideas into a discussion group tasked to develop a program.

Radio scriptwriting. The main elements of radio scriptwriting are voice and dialogue, sound effects, and music. The radio scriptwriter is always conscious of the microphone and indicates the speaker’s proximity to the equipment. There are specific writing guidelines for every program type—whether variety, quiz, talk, counseling, or drama. The latter has several genres such as comedy, satire, melodrama, action, adventure, fantasy, and horror, each with particular conventions and techniques (De Leon 1983, 1-24).

The discipline to meticulously write radio scripts was well established before World War II. Program producers and directors were often also the scriptwriters. Among the more memorable programs for which scripting was key were Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok (The Thrifty Madam Juana), an early model of the drama and advice program, produced, written, and hosted by Lina Flor and Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), a precursor of the situation comedy that satirized Filipino manners, customs, politics, and government, produced by Horacio de la Costa and written by Narciso Pimentel and Jesus Paredes. Both aired beginning in 1938 but were interrupted by war (Enriquez 2008). After World War II, theater artists pioneered in radio scriptwriting for mass-oriented programs using the local language. In 1947, Epifanio Gar. Matute collaborated with director Narciso Pimentel to reprise the pre-war KZRM program and produce the satirical scripts of the long-running radio show Kuwentong Kutsero, which then first aired over DZPI produced by Dramatic Philippines. The stories revolved around the idiosyncrasies and entanglements of a kalesa (horse-drawn rig) driver named Teban and the members of his family. Kuwentong Kutsero’s scripts contributed much to the success of the program with its timely tirades on corrupt politicians and funny comments on social issues. The show articulated the sentiments of the masses through folk and pop humor. Owing to its mass appeal, Kuwentong Kutsero was translated into theater, television, and film. Another theater artist, Conde Ubaldo, wrote and directed the comedy-drama Kuwentong Kapitbahay (Neighborhood Stories) also in 1947 over DZRH. It was made into a movie with the same title in 1952 using the storyline of a barrio lass who is admired and chased by an American soldier, a common experience after World War II. There are other radio scriptwriters who succeeded in romantic comedy, like Virgilio “Beer” Flores who wrote Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer) for DZFM and Sebya Mahal Kita (I Love You, Sebya) for DZXL. Both series were made into films (Matute 1997, vii-ix; Dolor 2010; Soriano 1981, 32).

The first 30-minute drama is the educational program entitled Counsel for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency from a concept by Manila Mayor Manuel de la Fuente and Olympia Ubaldo. It was hosted and directed by Rosalino Flores over KZRH. Literary writers ventured successfully into radio scriptwriting. Liwayway Arceo broke into the world of broadcast with her 15-minute serial melodrama Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of Home). It became a big hit when it first aired over DZMB in Aug 1949 and continued until 1958. Soon, other drama programs were produced. Carolina Flores-Trinidad aka Lina Flor wrote Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) and Dr. Ramon Selga. Genoveva Edroza-Matute created Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love). Other literary writers from print media who became radio scriptwriters for drama were Fausto Galauran and Susana de Guzman. These top-rating drama shows were supported by big advertisers like the Philippine Manufacturing Company, later known as Procter & Gamble PMC. With the success of daytime drama programs, other companies like Colgate Palmolive also sponsored these programs with high listenership. To capture nighttime listeners, producers ventured into action, horror, and adventure. Scriptwriters were Clodualdo del Mundo for Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), Mabini Centeno for Tatlong Limbas (Three Crime Busters), Froilan Villegas for Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Horror), and Abraham Cruz and Ric Aquino for Konsiyerto ng Kamatayan (Concert of Death) (Soriano 1981, 32).

In 1953, the long-running advice program hosted by Dely Magpayo, Kasaysayan sa mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (Stories in the Letters to Tiya Dely), over DZRH hit the airwaves. The counseling program required collaborative effort between its host and writer. Dely Magpayo would read a heap of letters every day and choose the ones to be written for dramatization by scriptwriter Lydia Collantes-Villegas. Magpayo reviewed the drama script before she gave her on-air advice (Lo 2008).

Radio scriptwriting became a lucrative career during the “golden age of radio drama” in the 1950s up to the 1960s. Successful radio scriptwriters at the time were Milo Castelo, Paterno Cosme, Loida Flores-Viriña, Johnny Legarda, Eddie Naval, Aning Bagabaldo, Jose Miranda Cruz, Joe “Jingle” Reyes, Max Roman Garcia, Ramona Pablo, Marina Feleo-Gonzales, Jimmy Navarro, and Madia-as Digdigan Buenaflor. Radio writers gravitated to film writing when many of the best-loved drama series were bought by film producers. Some radio programs that became films were Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), Student Canteen, Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), Lagalag (Wanderer), Lola Basyang (Grandma Basyang), and Gulong ng Palad. A testament to the drawing power of radio was the tendency of famous movie stars to host their own radio shows. For example, Sampaguita Pictures commissioned Genoveva Edroza-Matute to write the radio scripts for Gloria Romero’s drama program, Ang Inyong Lingkod, Gloria Romero (At Your Service, Gloria Romero), 1959-60, DZRH, sponsored by Coca-Cola. Romero was already the “queen” of Philippine movies, yet Sampaguita Pictures saw the opportunity to strengthen her position through radio. Edroza-Matute wrote each episode based on a Filipino proverb. Its lead female character, played by Romero, is the epitome of goodness, humility, and decency. Male voice actors opposite Romero were famous movie stars like Jose Mari, Romeo Vazquez, Luis Gonzales, Juancho Gutierrez, and Dolphy.

The dominance of the radio drama in the airwaves during this time may be partially attributed to effective scriptwriting. Most radio scriptwriters then were either degree holders in art and literature or were already known for their creative writing ability. These were the writers who conducted research, studied their characters in relation to plot and theme, and knew the difference between the conventions of a short story or short drama from that of a serialized novel or drama series. They were disciplined, making sequence treatments before proceeding to actual writing. Another reason for the success of radio dramas in the 1950s and the 1960s was the fact that radio scriptwriters were also producers and directors who knew the other aspects of the medium. For example, Fundador Soriano was producer, director, and writer of Eddie Ilarde’s Kahapon Lamang (Only Yesterday) over DZXL, which was a big hit.

In the succeeding decades, many scriptwriters continued to make their mark in the radio broadcast industry. The next generation of radio writers included Noel de Leon, Julie Fe-Navarro, Reynaldo Duque, Virgilio Vitug, Salvador Royales, Zenaida Soriano, Gina Marissa Tagasa, Lucy Quinto, Gil Soriano, and Cris Dalus. Mario O’Hara honed his skills as a radio drama writer before he became a film and television writer, director, and actor.

From the 1960s to the 1970s, music programs on radio had a wide and loyal following. The scripts for the music programs gave the song titles, their composers and lyricists, and often also their theme and content; anecdotes about the compositions and their inspiration; and poetry about love and emotions that matched the sentiments in the songs and the listeners’ penchant for romance (Enriquez, 2015).

The popularity of radio began to decline in the early 1980s with the dominance of television. Veteran radio writers reckon that its downhill turn was also due to the deterioration of radio scriptwriting and the unimproved quality of radio productions. Producers hired amateur writers to cut production cost. Radio stations demanded that writers produce stories at a faster rate. In 1981, with an exchange rate of seven pesos to a dollar, anecdotal evidence has it that DZRH and DZXL paid 25 pesos for a script that ran for 30 minutes while DWWW paid 30 pesos. To increase their earnings, writers produced eight to nine scripts a day, resulting in the proliferation of predictable, rehashed, and unresearched stories lacking in depth and devoid of absorbing plots, well-developed characterization, and engaging dialogues (Carballo 2009; Soriano 1981, 34-35).

Television scriptwriting. The kinds of television writing vary according to the types of TV programs, such as melodrama, fantasy, horror, reality, documentary, magazine, situation-comedy, gag, talk, musical variety, and quiz show. The scriptwriter is in charge of making the copy which serves as the blueprint to guide production planning, director’s treatment, lighting design, and production design. An ideal scriptwriter is both innovative and mindful of the commercial demands of the TV medium. S/he must write a script that is doable according to budget yet able to sustain audience interest and earn good audience ratings.

Sitcom writing was developed with the pervasive influence and popularity of the Dolphy and Nida Blanca tandem in the family sitcom John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-90, RPN-9. Touted as one of the most highly-rated sitcoms in Philippine TV history, the concept and script of Ading Fernando may be credited for its huge success. Fernando used the comic talent and charisma of Dolphy as John Puruntong, the “Filipino Everyman” who is the husband of Marsha, the daughter of a filthy-rich woman named Delilah Jones, played by Fernando’s real-life sister Dely Atay-atayan. Fernando was the most prolific comedy writer-director at the time who also created Duplex on RPN 9, Chicks to Chicks on IBC 13, and Apartment 153-A on ABS-CBN (Ramos 2012; IMDb John en Marsha 2015).

From the 1970s to the 1990s, sitcom writing prospered with shows that experimented with all sorts of characters and settings. Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977-90, IBC 13, was about the delinquent students of Wanbol University, led by the comic trio Tito, Vic, and Joey, and scripted by Bibeth Orteza. Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-97, first broadcast over GMA 7, was also written by Orteza who developed the characters of a repair man named Enteng Kabisote and his fairy wife, Faye. Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1994-2003, ABS-CBN was about the adventures of a poor family living along the railroad tracks written by Loida Viriña, Jose Bartolome, Divino Reyes, and Herman Salvador from the story concept of Roy Vera Cruz. Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, ABS-CBN, scripted by writer-director Joey Reyes, parodied Philippine politics.

Another type of comedy writing is the gag show. Joey de Leon, a talented gag writer, found himself on camera with T.O.D.A.S. (Television’s Outrageously Delightful All-Star Show), 1977-89, a gag show with a motley cast that included Val Sotto, Richie D’ Horsie, Maribeth Bichara, Frieda Fonda, Spanky Rigor, and Jimmy Santos. An effective gag script allows improvisation and ensemble acting among its performers. This is exhibited in trendsetting gag shows like Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, ABC 5, with Dan Salamante and Al Tantay as writers. The script template of Bubble Gang, premiered in 1995 on GMA Network, was patterned after Tropang Trumpo (IMDb Tropang Trumpo 2015; TODAS IMDb 2015).

Writing for the TV drama is one of the most developed fields in TV scriptwriting. Komiks, theater, and literature are the main sources and influences in TV drama scriptwriting. This is best exemplified by the drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1967-72, ABC 5. The show’s writers and creative consultants are competent artists such as Elwood Perez, Mauro Avena, Tony Perez, Joey Gosiengfiao, Ninotchka Rosca, Sr Maria Angela Barrios, and Lino Brocka. Brocka was later named National Artist (Matignas 2012, 21-44). Unfortunately, the growing influence of Balintataw in local television was aborted by the declaration of martial law. At the height of martial rule in the 1970s, government-controlled TV networks produced well-written drama series by Jose Mari Lee. These were Alindog (Allure), 1976-89, a drama anthology featuring Alma Moreno essaying various lives of women in Filipino society; Ulila (Forsaken) top billed by Rosa Rosal, 1976-80; and Peping Ang Munting Anghel (Peping the Little Angel), 1976-79, featuring child actor Romnick Sarmenta as Peping, a favorite character in the durable radio and TV soap opera, Gulong ng Palad (Video 48 2009).

After Marcos’s ouster in 1986, which signaled a new era in media production, television writing became a good source of income for writers until the 1990s even though TV writing still could not provide a secure living since TV shows come and go. Writers then were mostly freelancers. Nevertheless, it has been the goal of many aspiring writers to enter television because of the handsome pay it gives relative to writing for print or radio. But entering television also means that the writer is willing to compromise individual aesthetic preferences in favor of the commercial interests of the producer or the network. Mainstream TV is a free medium supported by advertising and big business. The broadcast outputs in such a setup serve the demands of the business. TV is a fleeting medium and writers are less recognized in this setup, given the daily grind of TV production and the fast turnover of shows.

Theater writers easily switch to the TV medium given their skill in building dramatic conflict with the use of colorful characters and dialogue. Television gained from the creative inputs of playwrights like Liza Magtoto, Rody Vera, Rene Villanueva, Ronnie Tumbokon, Floy Quintos, and Jun Lana. Komiks has always been a source of both stories and writers for television, as exemplified by Pablo S. Gomez, Carlo Caparas, Vincent Kua, RJ Nuevas, and Gilda Olvidado. Meanwhile, fictionists and prose writers like Fanny Garcia, Lualhati Bautista, and Suzette Doctolero also ventured into television. Amado Lacuesta, Jake Tordesillas, Roy Iglesias, Racquel Villavicencio, and Ricardo Lee were mainly film screenwriters who also switched to broadcast arts, especially when mainstream cinema declined in the 1990s. From radio broadcasting, Loida Viriña and Gina Marissa Tagasa succeeded in television writing.

For many decades since the advent of TV broadcasting, most scriptwriters were self-taught. There was a dearth in scriptwriting courses that trained writers in the art and practice of TV writing. Ricardo Lee started his writing workshop in 1982. Among the participants of Lee’s workshops were Armando Lao, Jeffrey Jeturian, Leo Abaya, Vincent Kua, and Peping Almojuela. Lee developed workshop modules for writing the teleplay as well as for writing the television magazine show. Some of the participants were Ned Trespeces, Dado Lumibao, Jerry Sineneng, Lynda Casimiro, and Richard Reynante. After the EDSA revolt, the weekly drama anthology featuring new stories every week was still the dominant type of drama program (Lee 2015). Armando Lao subsequently developed his teleplay writing workshop in the 1990s based on the traditional three-act format and the three-act restorative format, with focus on effective devices in milieu, plot, and characterization. His workshops eventually developed into modules on the concepts and mechanics of the found story, which is highly influenced by the documentary genre.

The aforementioned workshops helped aspiring TV writers to learn and to master the basics of teleplay writing in the Philippine setting. These learning sessions honed the craft of writers and provided them the venue to raise the level of TV writing by education, training, and sharing of skills and knowledge. Meanwhile, teleplay writing contests, such as the first and only ABS-CBN Scriptwriting Contest in 1990, and the Carlos Palanca Memorial Awards teleplay category sought to promote TV writing through competition. In 2012, Cine Filipino launched its annual competition with a TV series category.

Writing for the documentary and magazine show became popular after the 1986 EDSA revolt with the proliferation of shows that feature socio-political issues, tackle nationalistic themes, and promote Philippine culture. Before and shortly after the EDSA revolt, magazine and public affairs shows were mostly in English, produced by news teams with journalistic background. Loren Legarda’s PEP Talk and Cheche Lazaro’s Probe were considered glossy because they were written in English. The shows that changed the old paradigms were those that were written in Filipino: Sic O’Clock News, 1987-89, and Truth Forum, 1986, both over IBC-13; and Isip Pinoy (Filipino Psyche), 1987, over RPN 9. The latter shows tackled controversial issues such as prostitution, live sex shows aka toro, censorship, violations of human rights, the abolition of the US Bases, and urban poor demolition. Soon, television public affairs shows written in Filipino became the norm.

In the 2000s, economic and technological developments fundamentally affected TV scriptwriting. The new situation pushed the weekly drama anthology to near extinction. The challenging condition was brought about by the intense rivalry among TV networks, the battle for high ratings, the drive for increased profits to cover mounting production expenses, and the rise of new media competing with television. The medium needed new programming that would deliver faithful viewership. The new situation favored shows like reality TV, game show, and the daily soap opera aka teleserye/telenovela. Soap operas in the previous decades were shown in the afternoon, usually after the noontime variety show. By the 2000s, the daily 30-minute melodrama based on the paradigm of the Mexican telenovela dominated not only daytime programming but also evening primetime slots. A telenovela, to be cost-effective, must run for six months.

The dominance of the daily soap opera in TV commercial programming ended the role of the scriptwriter as the sole author of the drama script. To secure creative control over soap opera programs, commercial TV networks contracted dedicated writers tasked to write the daily series which would run for a minimum of three months. With high ratings, a telenovela can run for over a year. Within the airing period, writers dedicate their time to the telenovela on a 24/7 schedule. The writer, who always writes with a group, submits to a hierarchical organization that directs the story, characters, and plot based on TV ratings and feedback from social media. The hierarchy has several levels: on top is the business unit head who acts as the overall producer representing the interests of the network. Under the top business manager is the creative manager or the creative consultant who directs the work of the writers. Assisting the creative manager is the head writer who is responsible for the performance of the senior and junior writers, who are the episode writers. Then under the episode writers are the brainstormers whose role is to throw in ideas or to act as devil’s advocate during scriptwriting and story conferences. At any point in the writing process, the director may also intervene. The complicated setup allows little room for the individuality and personal vision of the scriptwriter. Every episode of the soap opera bears the imprint of all the levels of the business and creative organization. The writer solves problems on a daily basis and may be required to do actual writing and revision on the set. Telenovela writing under such conditions can drive writers, head writers, and creative managers to the point of burnout. On the other hand, those who survive the system emerge as disciplined writers who can write scripts under the most stressful conditions. Despite the untold travails of the telenovela writer, the fact remains that it is a lucrative profession that also provides job security when one is contracted for many years by the TV network (Lee 2015).

The variety show is a TV program that has survived the test of time and ratings. Long-running noontime shows like Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!) that premiered in 1979 require a different kind of scriptwriting. Composed of different portions and segments, the noontime variety show employs a host of writers under a head writer. Writers are assigned to specific portions ranging from comedy skit, game portions, quiz segment, beauty pageant, talent contest, canned videos, to musical portions. Writing for the variety show entails a complex process that includes research, creating new games and gimmicks, writing spiels for the hosts, and writing the guide in the conduct of games and quizzes. Scriptwriting is an important factor in the longevity of variety shows. The role of writers in Eat Bulaga!, which celebrated 35 years in 2014, helps to keep the show afloat amid the challenges of network competition, new trends, intrigues, censorship, fluctuations in ratings, and changing audience preferences (Eat Bulaga 2004).

Regional scriptwriters. Sarsuwela and komedya writers in the Visayas and Mindanao easily turned to radio scriptwriting with the advent of the broadcast industry. This is exemplified by the career of Leyte-born playwright Herculano Borneo Sr. In 1939, the playwright migrated to resettlement areas in Cotabato and in 1951, he moved to Davao City. Borneo became the president of the Mindanao Dramatic Club in Davao City and worked as a part-time radio commentator, which opened doors for his full-length play Luyo sa Dag-um (Behind the Clouds), 1953, serialized in DXAW. He also produced skits for Davao City’s government hour program in 1956 (Dalagan 2001, 31-33).

A Cebuano radio scriptwriter who produced drama shows that became hits on TV is Marcos Navarro Sacol. He created Flordeluna in the 1970s which was turned into a soap opera by RPN 9 starring child star Janice de Belen in 1978. He was also the writer of the radio comedy, Manok ni San Pedro (Saint Peter’s Rooster), which was produced by RPN 9 in 1977. In the 1990s, Sacol wrote and directed the famous Cebuano fantasy telenovela entitled Si Goot Da Wanderpol, Ang Handumanan ni Teban ug Goliat (Goot the Wonderful, As Remembered by Teban and Goliat). The comic telenovela carries the record of being one of the most highly rated shows in Cebu. It is about a goat that excretes coins and the misadventures of two comic characters Teban and Goliat, played by Julian Daan and Alan Nacorda. The two actors broke with convention because their ordinary looks are the antithesis of the mestizo faces typical of soap opera leading men. The huge success of the two-year telenovela turned Daan and Nacorda into celebrities with a mass following in the Visayas and Mindanao. Julian “Teban” Daan, who is also a writer, moved on to become a successful politician in Cebu province. He created the highly-rated radio comedy-drama and counseling program in the 2010s entitled Kun Ako ang Pasultihon (If I Were to Speak) over DYHP RMN network (Tomada 2006, Mindanao Examiner 2012). The various periods of radio and television history demonstrate the significant role of writers and the necessity of good scripts to come up with cost-effective and highly rated programs. Whether writing is done in a solitary manner or with a team, the paramount objective is to generate loyal listeners and viewers. The increasing centralization of the writing process is a trend in the commercial broadcast stations because of the corporate perception that firm control is the key to ensuring advertising and audience support. Broadcast productions that are not in this highly competitive mode, such as blocktimers, can offer more democratic space for writers. However, blocktimers are now a marginalized sector in the broadcast industry.Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

Sources

article.value: Scriptwriting is the process of conceptualizing and writing the copy to be used by narrators, performers, directors, and editors in radio and television programs. The person who writes this text is the scriptwriter. Other people who may be involved in the scriptwriting process are the producer, director, script supervisor, and brainstormer. The latter is a person who discusses and throws ideas into a discussion group tasked to develop a program.

Radio scriptwriting. The main elements of radio scriptwriting are voice and dialogue, sound effects, and music. The radio scriptwriter is always conscious of the microphone and indicates the speaker’s proximity to the equipment. There are specific writing guidelines for every program type—whether variety, quiz, talk, counseling, or drama. The latter has several genres such as comedy, satire, melodrama, action, adventure, fantasy, and horror, each with particular conventions and techniques (De Leon 1983, 1-24).

article.value: The discipline to meticulously write radio scripts was well established before World War II. Program producers and directors were often also the scriptwriters. Among the more memorable programs for which scripting was key were Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok (The Thrifty Madam Juana), an early model of the drama and advice program, produced, written, and hosted by Lina Flor and Kuwentong Kutsero (Tall Tales), a precursor of the situation comedy that satirized Filipino manners, customs, politics, and government, produced by Horacio de la Costa and written by Narciso Pimentel and Jesus Paredes. Both aired beginning in 1938 but were interrupted by war (Enriquez 2008). After World War II, theater artists pioneered in radio scriptwriting for mass-oriented programs using the local language. In 1947, Epifanio Gar. Matute collaborated with director Narciso Pimentel to reprise the pre-war KZRM program and produce the satirical scripts of the long-running radio show Kuwentong Kutsero, which then first aired over DZPI produced by Dramatic Philippines. The stories revolved around the idiosyncrasies and entanglements of a kalesa (horse-drawn rig) driver named Teban and the members of his family. Kuwentong Kutsero’s scripts contributed much to the success of the program with its timely tirades on corrupt politicians and funny comments on social issues. The show articulated the sentiments of the masses through folk and pop humor. Owing to its mass appeal, Kuwentong Kutsero was translated into theater, television, and film. Another theater artist, Conde Ubaldo, wrote and directed the comedy-drama Kuwentong Kapitbahay (Neighborhood Stories) also in 1947 over DZRH. It was made into a movie with the same title in 1952 using the storyline of a barrio lass who is admired and chased by an American soldier, a common experience after World War II. There are other radio scriptwriters who succeeded in romantic comedy, like Virgilio “Beer” Flores who wrote Edong Mapangarap (Edong the Dreamer) for DZFM and Sebya Mahal Kita (I Love You, Sebya) for DZXL. Both series were made into films (Matute 1997, vii-ix; Dolor 2010; Soriano 1981, 32).

The first 30-minute drama is the educational program entitled Counsel for the Prevention of Juvenile Delinquency from a concept by Manila Mayor Manuel de la Fuente and Olympia Ubaldo. It was hosted and directed by Rosalino Flores over KZRH. Literary writers ventured successfully into radio scriptwriting. Liwayway Arceo broke into the world of broadcast with her 15-minute serial melodrama Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of Home). It became a big hit when it first aired over DZMB in Aug 1949 and continued until 1958. Soon, other drama programs were produced. Carolina Flores-Trinidad aka Lina Flor wrote Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) and Dr. Ramon Selga. Genoveva Edroza-Matute created Aklat ng Pag-ibig (Book of Love). Other literary writers from print media who became radio scriptwriters for drama were Fausto Galauran and Susana de Guzman. These top-rating drama shows were supported by big advertisers like the Philippine Manufacturing Company, later known as Procter & Gamble PMC. With the success of daytime drama programs, other companies like Colgate Palmolive also sponsored these programs with high listenership. To capture nighttime listeners, producers ventured into action, horror, and adventure. Scriptwriters were Clodualdo del Mundo for Prinsipe Amante (Prince Amante), Mabini Centeno for Tatlong Limbas (Three Crime Busters), Froilan Villegas for Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Horror), and Abraham Cruz and Ric Aquino for Konsiyerto ng Kamatayan (Concert of Death) (Soriano 1981, 32).

article.value: In 1953, the long-running advice program hosted by Dely Magpayo, Kasaysayan sa mga Liham kay Tiya Dely (Stories in the Letters to Tiya Dely), over DZRH hit the airwaves. The counseling program required collaborative effort between its host and writer. Dely Magpayo would read a heap of letters every day and choose the ones to be written for dramatization by scriptwriter Lydia Collantes-Villegas. Magpayo reviewed the drama script before she gave her on-air advice (Lo 2008).

Radio scriptwriting became a lucrative career during the “golden age of radio drama” in the 1950s up to the 1960s. Successful radio scriptwriters at the time were Milo Castelo, Paterno Cosme, Loida Flores-Viriña, Johnny Legarda, Eddie Naval, Aning Bagabaldo, Jose Miranda Cruz, Joe “Jingle” Reyes, Max Roman Garcia, Ramona Pablo, Marina Feleo-Gonzales, Jimmy Navarro, and Madia-as Digdigan Buenaflor. Radio writers gravitated to film writing when many of the best-loved drama series were bought by film producers. Some radio programs that became films were Kapitan Kidlat (Captain Lightning), Student Canteen, Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), Lagalag (Wanderer), Lola Basyang (Grandma Basyang), and Gulong ng Palad. A testament to the drawing power of radio was the tendency of famous movie stars to host their own radio shows. For example, Sampaguita Pictures commissioned Genoveva Edroza-Matute to write the radio scripts for Gloria Romero’s drama program, Ang Inyong Lingkod, Gloria Romero (At Your Service, Gloria Romero), 1959-60, DZRH, sponsored by Coca-Cola. Romero was already the “queen” of Philippine movies, yet Sampaguita Pictures saw the opportunity to strengthen her position through radio. Edroza-Matute wrote each episode based on a Filipino proverb. Its lead female character, played by Romero, is the epitome of goodness, humility, and decency. Male voice actors opposite Romero were famous movie stars like Jose Mari, Romeo Vazquez, Luis Gonzales, Juancho Gutierrez, and Dolphy.

The dominance of the radio drama in the airwaves during this time may be partially attributed to effective scriptwriting. Most radio scriptwriters then were either degree holders in art and literature or were already known for their creative writing ability. These were the writers who conducted research, studied their characters in relation to plot and theme, and knew the difference between the conventions of a short story or short drama from that of a serialized novel or drama series. They were disciplined, making sequence treatments before proceeding to actual writing. Another reason for the success of radio dramas in the 1950s and the 1960s was the fact that radio scriptwriters were also producers and directors who knew the other aspects of the medium. For example, Fundador Soriano was producer, director, and writer of Eddie Ilarde’s Kahapon Lamang (Only Yesterday) over DZXL, which was a big hit.

In the succeeding decades, many scriptwriters continued to make their mark in the radio broadcast industry. The next generation of radio writers included Noel de Leon, Julie Fe-Navarro, Reynaldo Duque, Virgilio Vitug, Salvador Royales, Zenaida Soriano, Gina Marissa Tagasa, Lucy Quinto, Gil Soriano, and Cris Dalus. Mario O’Hara honed his skills as a radio drama writer before he became a film and television writer, director, and actor.

From the 1960s to the 1970s, music programs on radio had a wide and loyal following. The scripts for the music programs gave the song titles, their composers and lyricists, and often also their theme and content; anecdotes about the compositions and their inspiration; and poetry about love and emotions that matched the sentiments in the songs and the listeners’ penchant for romance (Enriquez, 2015).

The popularity of radio began to decline in the early 1980s with the dominance of television. Veteran radio writers reckon that its downhill turn was also due to the deterioration of radio scriptwriting and the unimproved quality of radio productions. Producers hired amateur writers to cut production cost. Radio stations demanded that writers produce stories at a faster rate. In 1981, with an exchange rate of seven pesos to a dollar, anecdotal evidence has it that DZRH and DZXL paid 25 pesos for a script that ran for 30 minutes while DWWW paid 30 pesos. To increase their earnings, writers produced eight to nine scripts a day, resulting in the proliferation of predictable, rehashed, and unresearched stories lacking in depth and devoid of absorbing plots, well-developed characterization, and engaging dialogues (Carballo 2009; Soriano 1981, 34-35).

Television scriptwriting. The kinds of television writing vary according to the types of TV programs, such as melodrama, fantasy, horror, reality, documentary, magazine, situation-comedy, gag, talk, musical variety, and quiz show. The scriptwriter is in charge of making the copy which serves as the blueprint to guide production planning, director’s treatment, lighting design, and production design. An ideal scriptwriter is both innovative and mindful of the commercial demands of the TV medium. S/he must write a script that is doable according to budget yet able to sustain audience interest and earn good audience ratings.

Sitcom writing was developed with the pervasive influence and popularity of the Dolphy and Nida Blanca tandem in the family sitcom John en Marsha (John and Marsha), 1973-90, RPN-9. Touted as one of the most highly-rated sitcoms in Philippine TV history, the concept and script of Ading Fernando may be credited for its huge success. Fernando used the comic talent and charisma of Dolphy as John Puruntong, the “Filipino Everyman” who is the husband of Marsha, the daughter of a filthy-rich woman named Delilah Jones, played by Fernando’s real-life sister Dely Atay-atayan. Fernando was the most prolific comedy writer-director at the time who also created Duplex on RPN 9, Chicks to Chicks on IBC 13, and Apartment 153-A on ABS-CBN (Ramos 2012; IMDb John en Marsha 2015).

From the 1970s to the 1990s, sitcom writing prospered with shows that experimented with all sorts of characters and settings. Iskul Bukol (School Bumps), 1977-90, IBC 13, was about the delinquent students of Wanbol University, led by the comic trio Tito, Vic, and Joey, and scripted by Bibeth Orteza. Okay Ka, Fairy Ko! (You’re Okay, My Fairy!), 1987-97, first broadcast over GMA 7, was also written by Orteza who developed the characters of a repair man named Enteng Kabisote and his fairy wife, Faye. Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1994-2003, ABS-CBN was about the adventures of a poor family living along the railroad tracks written by Loida Viriña, Jose Bartolome, Divino Reyes, and Herman Salvador from the story concept of Roy Vera Cruz. Abangan ang Susunod na Kabanata (Wait for the Next Chapter), 1991-97, ABS-CBN, scripted by writer-director Joey Reyes, parodied Philippine politics.

Another type of comedy writing is the gag show. Joey de Leon, a talented gag writer, found himself on camera with T.O.D.A.S. (Television’s Outrageously Delightful All-Star Show), 1977-89, a gag show with a motley cast that included Val Sotto, Richie D’ Horsie, Maribeth Bichara, Frieda Fonda, Spanky Rigor, and Jimmy Santos. An effective gag script allows improvisation and ensemble acting among its performers. This is exhibited in trendsetting gag shows like Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, ABC 5, with Dan Salamante and Al Tantay as writers. The script template of Bubble Gang, premiered in 1995 on GMA Network, was patterned after Tropang Trumpo (IMDb Tropang Trumpo 2015; TODAS IMDb 2015).

Writing for the TV drama is one of the most developed fields in TV scriptwriting. Komiks, theater, and literature are the main sources and influences in TV drama scriptwriting. This is best exemplified by the drama anthology Balintataw (The Mind’s Eye), 1967-72, ABC 5. The show’s writers and creative consultants are competent artists such as Elwood Perez, Mauro Avena, Tony Perez, Joey Gosiengfiao, Ninotchka Rosca, Sr Maria Angela Barrios, and Lino Brocka. Brocka was later named National Artist (Matignas 2012, 21-44). Unfortunately, the growing influence of Balintataw in local television was aborted by the declaration of martial law. At the height of martial rule in the 1970s, government-controlled TV networks produced well-written drama series by Jose Mari Lee. These were Alindog (Allure), 1976-89, a drama anthology featuring Alma Moreno essaying various lives of women in Filipino society; Ulila (Forsaken) top billed by Rosa Rosal, 1976-80; and Peping Ang Munting Anghel (Peping the Little Angel), 1976-79, featuring child actor Romnick Sarmenta as Peping, a favorite character in the durable radio and TV soap opera, Gulong ng Palad (Video 48 2009).

After Marcos’s ouster in 1986, which signaled a new era in media production, television writing became a good source of income for writers until the 1990s even though TV writing still could not provide a secure living since TV shows come and go. Writers then were mostly freelancers. Nevertheless, it has been the goal of many aspiring writers to enter television because of the handsome pay it gives relative to writing for print or radio. But entering television also means that the writer is willing to compromise individual aesthetic preferences in favor of the commercial interests of the producer or the network. Mainstream TV is a free medium supported by advertising and big business. The broadcast outputs in such a setup serve the demands of the business. TV is a fleeting medium and writers are less recognized in this setup, given the daily grind of TV production and the fast turnover of shows.

Theater writers easily switch to the TV medium given their skill in building dramatic conflict with the use of colorful characters and dialogue. Television gained from the creative inputs of playwrights like Liza Magtoto, Rody Vera, Rene Villanueva, Ronnie Tumbokon, Floy Quintos, and Jun Lana. Komiks has always been a source of both stories and writers for television, as exemplified by Pablo S. Gomez, Carlo Caparas, Vincent Kua, RJ Nuevas, and Gilda Olvidado. Meanwhile, fictionists and prose writers like Fanny Garcia, Lualhati Bautista, and Suzette Doctolero also ventured into television. Amado Lacuesta, Jake Tordesillas, Roy Iglesias, Racquel Villavicencio, and Ricardo Lee were mainly film screenwriters who also switched to broadcast arts, especially when mainstream cinema declined in the 1990s. From radio broadcasting, Loida Viriña and Gina Marissa Tagasa succeeded in television writing.

For many decades since the advent of TV broadcasting, most scriptwriters were self-taught. There was a dearth in scriptwriting courses that trained writers in the art and practice of TV writing. Lee developed workshop modules for writing the teleplay as well as for writing the television magazine show. After the EDSA revolt, the weekly drama anthology featuring new stories every week was still the dominant type of drama program (Lee 2015). Armando Lao subsequently developed his teleplay writing workshop in the 1990s based on the traditional three-act format and the three-act restorative format, with focus on effective devices in milieu, plot, and characterization. His workshops eventually developed into modules on the concepts and mechanics of the found story, which is highly influenced by the documentary genre.

These learning sessions honed the craft of writers and provided them the venue to raise the level of TV writing by education, training, and sharing of skills and knowledge. text:
Self-regulation in broadcast pertains to the professionalization of practices and ethical standards of the industry by individual and institutional members themselves, including the formulation and enforcement of policies that ensure their competency and integrity. The concept of self-regulation in the Philippine broadcast industry is closely identified with the declaration of martial law in 1972 and the establishment on 27 Apr 1973 of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas (KBP). Recognized by the government, the KBP, in effect, has the authority and power to regulate almost all the broadcast media networks nationwide, especially radio. Broadcast media owners rationalized that having one voice and one common identity would send the message to government that they were capable of regulating their ranks. In reality, and media owners were aware of this, self-regulation equates to “deflecting full government control over the industry” (Feliciano 2007). Under martial law, however, the independence of the KBP was suspect, especially because Teodoro Valencia, its president beginning in Jun 1974, was also the head of the Broadcast Media Council (BMC), a government regulation body created through Presidential Decree 576 on 9 Nov 1974. Valencia was a well-known newspaper columnist, whom critics would label a Marcos apologist. Media owners during martial law, however, were very cautious of government intrusion into the media, especially so when almost all radio and television stations were closed by then Pres Marcos. Freedom of expression and the survival of the broadcast industry as a business enterprise were major concerns. Media owners are business persons, and they have self-interests to protect. The less government interference, the better it is for the public, the practitioners, and the owners.

The KBP during the martial law period saw to it that the BMC regulation of a limit of 13 minutes of advertising per clock-hour of commercial load on radio was strictly observed. Another important self-regulation policy required playing Original Pilipino Music every broadcast hour. Beginning with one song per program hour in 1975, the requirement was brought up to four in 1982. In 1977, the KBP established the announcers’ accreditation program that required all persons who went on air regularly to know basic professional and ethical standards. Beginning in 1981, broadcasters had to pass an accreditation examination to qualify them to go on-air.

Self-regulation has its own complicated, and at times awkward, twists and turns. In what is now known as the Bartolome Case, the Supreme Court in 1987 affirmed the authority of the KBP to enforce its code of conduct among its members. It upheld the KBP decision to ban from the air for life KBP member Rolando Bartolome, a blocktimer in several KBP member stations, due to numerous and repeated violations of the KBP rule prohibiting personal attacks, profanity, and attacks on KBP itself on air. The regulatory functions of the broadcast industry were transferred to the KBP when the BMC was abolished when martial law was officially lifted in Jan 1981. The KBP formed its own body, the KBP Standards Authority, which formulated program and advertising standards.

As a private organization, membership in the KBP is voluntary. Not all broadcast networks are members; some come and go depending on the network’s management. Usually, members leave the organization when the association’s policies run counter to the member’s corporate concerns. One publicized case is that of GMA 7, a major player in the broadcast industry. It left KBP in Sep 2003 and has not returned. About 95 percent of radio and television stations are KBP members.

In 2007, the KBP stopped the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB) from requiring news and public affairs programs to be reviewed prior to airing. As a review agency, MTRCB appraises movies, prerecorded entertainment and public affairs programs, and similar materials before they are aired. With KBP’s intervention, the review of news and public affairs programs was discontinued.

Also in 2007, the KBP advocated the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) to stop the proliferation of small low-power commercial stations that threatened the viability of regular commercial stations. NTC also granted KBP’s petition in 2008 to revoke a rule that compelled stations to hand over recordings of their programs that could be used in complaints against them, unless ordered by the courts.

Policing its members is not an easy task for KBP, despite the fact that the members themselves are the creators of the organization’s policies, code of conduct, and penalty provisions. Violations committed by members put KBP and its self-disciplining function on the spot. Several high-profile cases have compelled KBP to respond to public outcry, which subsequently necessitated revisions on the KBP Broadcast Code. One notable case is the Rizal Park hostage-taking incident on 23 Aug 2010, which involved a suspended police officer and several Chinese tourists, eight of whom were killed. The hostage taker himself was gunned down by police authorities. The event brought to the fore the role and capability of broadcast to handle and cover crises like hostage-taking. As a result of this incident, the KBP initiated a comprehensive set of guidelines in the coverage of crime and crisis situations by broadcast journalists.

Another case is the Janjan macho dance controversy in Willie Revillame’s daily program, Willing Willie, aired on TV5 on 12 Mar 2011. What started as a viral video showing a crying six-year-old boy gyrating to adult sexy music and perceived to have been made fun of by the program host Revillame and the studio audience triggered massive protests among the viewing public and brought the incident to national attention. This became the headline news for several weeks. The passionate and intense reaction from the public forced TV5 to suspend Revillame and reformat the program. The amendments to the KBP Broadcast Code on the media coverage of children also came from the practitioners themselves, media owners, and stakeholders, especially child advocates. Major revisions in the Broadcast Code were made on Article 6 (Crime and Crisis Situations), Article 3 (Coverage Involving Children), Article 11 (Children’s Program and Welfare), and Article 17 (Quiz Shows, Contests, Public Participation Programs, and Promotion).

In advertising, KBP is able to suspend accounts that have liabilities to member stations. Because of this, advertisers make it a point to prioritize payment of their media placements to avoid suspension of their clients’ products on all KBP member stations nationwide. Even a small station in the province can have a major product banned, as long as KBP is informed ahead of time and the necessary documents are presented.

There were, indeed, many instances when KBP’s self-regulating function worked well for the public and the broadcast industry. But a new challenge confronts current self-regulation. With new media platforms competing with the broadcast industry, particularly the Internet, self-regulation will have to respond to the changing dynamics and philosophies of media regulation and the mediation of meanings in a world where media intrusion into the lives of the listening and viewing public has considerably increased.Written by Rosa Maria T. Feliciano

Sources

Feliciano 2007, 2012, 2013; More Than Meets the Eye 1989.

text:
Musical scoring is the process of synchronizing music and sound effects to talk or dialogue on radio and visuals on TV. To do this, the scorer uses existing or prerecorded instrumental music or songs from various sources. On pre-taped programs requiring postproduction work, a musical scorer must also record or dub the audio output to the final master tape. At its most basic, musical scoring is used to signal the start and end of a program, as well as to signal the start and end of segments within the body of a program. A short piece of music or sound effect, called a stinger, is used in the opening and end credits. As the show progresses, other pieces of music and sound effects are played to engage the audience. Other popular conventions include the use of canned laughter and applause, popular music, theme songs, and background music to heighten the emotional impact of scenes.

A musical scorer that works on live radio and TV programs like variety shows and newscasts is called a “spinner.” The term appears to be a local and a literal one, derived from the turntable and open-reel machines that the spinner literally spins forward or backward to operate. The spinner sits in the control booth, along with the audioperson, technical director, and, in the case of television, TV director. During the early years of TV, the spinner of a variety show typically operated two tapecaster machines that played eight-track tapes; two turntables and two open-reel machines patched to a mixing desk operated by the audioperson, who controlled the volume level for the microphones used by the hosts, and also had an eye out for the channel track assigned to the spinner. Except for the playback machines, which have been replaced by computers, and new functionalities that allow the hardware to connect wirelessly to each other, the design of the signal path has remained the same to this day. The spinner would cue one tapecaster machine to play laughter; the other tapecaster to play applause; and the turntables and open-reel machines to play music and other sound effects. A variety show would have many musical numbers, and it was the spinner’s job to cue the tape that would play the minus-one musical accompaniment. For easier recall, sections of the reel would be marked with paper so the spinner only had to pause the “forward” button of the machine to that section of the reel. Scoring for a live TV program not only demanded tremendous technical expertise but also an impeccable sense of timing. It required one to be a technician with a well-developed musical ear. There is only one other field of endeavor in which both qualities are highly valued: radio broadcasting.

Most, if not all, of the pioneering scorers in the Philippines started out in radio as soundmen, voice talents, foley artists or live sound effects producers for radio dramas, or simply assistants who delivered the vinyl LPs and tapes for the program. The equipment on board was the same and therefore familiar: playback machines and mixing desks patched to amplifiers, which in turn are connected to transmitters carrying the sound far and away to every listener tuned in. The workflow was similar as well: watching the action from a control booth, selecting and cueing the music and sound effects to be used throughout the program, operating the playback machines, and ensuring that the volume of the music or effects did not overpower the dialog. Further attesting to the similarity of radio and TV as work environments is the fact that some popular radio shows even had a TV equivalent, as in the case of Ang Inyong Lingkod, Tiya Dely (At Your Service, Aunt Dely), ABS-CBN, from 1959 until the 2000s.

Ruben Cadsawan and Angel Cruz, who later adopted the name Argel Joseph when he became a TV director, scored the first local TV drama, Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato (Mystery at the Stone House), ABS-CBN in 1963, based on the radio drama by Jose Miranda Cruz. In the early years of radio and TV, scoring was done live. At the end of a drama segment going to commercial break, the scorer played bridge music, a piece of suspense music to accompany the cliffhanger. Mainly foreign movie soundtracks were used at this time. The advent of videotape in the early 1960s allowed production teams to record programs and then edit them afterwards for greater quality control. TV networks started building soundstages and postproduction facilities. In 1968, ABS-CBN built the first media facility in the Philippines, the Broadcast Center on Bohol Avenue, Quezon City. It was here that the longest-running TV sitcom in Philippine history, John en Marsha (John and Marsha), was first produced in the early 1970s, also scored by Cruz. There were only a few musical scorers then, including Cadsawan, Clemente Soriano, Rudy Rustia, Jack Fiel, Boy De Guzman, Tats Luna, Jonjo Trinidad, and Junior Velasquez; and later, Boyet Luna, and Tina Velasquez (Cadsawan 2015, Cruz 2015, Fiel 2015, Luna 2015).

Examples of music that enjoyed great success in the Philippines with Cruz’s curation include the funky Quincy Jones’ instrumental Rubber Duckie, for John en Marsha; and the solo piano piece Ballade Pour Adeline, a 1976 instrumental used in the program Lovingly Yours, Helen, which ran from 1980 to 1996. Filipino composers were commissioned by TV executives to produce music for programs. A Filipino adaptation of Francis Lai’s L’Amour D’ Aimer was composed by TV executive Marcial Sanson for the afternoon drama Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) and became a hit song for artist Eugene Villaluz. Popular Filipino songs were also licensed for use as theme music, creating business for music publishers. One example is Constancio de Guzman’s Maalaala Mo Kaya (Will You Remember), used in the popular weekly TV drama of the same title. To keep up with the times, new recordings of the same song were produced, of which a version performed by Dulce became popular.

A musical scorer’s job would not be possible without a music library. From this collection, he customizes a set of musical pieces or “music kit” for a specific TV program. Therefore, a music kit for a drama would differ greatly from that of a comedy or a documentary. Theme music is selected for the opening and closing credits, as well as for special edits like montages within the body of the program. Occasionally, a TV executive, director or celebrity would select and produce the theme music himself, as in the case of Marcial Sanson and Gulong ng Palad, or Vic Sotto and the Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-Boo!) theme. Since the mid-1990s, however, the selection or production of the theme music has formally become part of the TV executive’s job. A musical scorer would also have at his disposal several sets of instrumental pieces evoking different moods: suspenseful, dramatic, light, comic, etc. For newscasts and variety shows, a scorer would have a set of stingers and sound effects ready, to be synchronized to wipes, dissolves, and other graphics announcing various segments within the program. In the days of hardware-based linear editing, music and sound effects could only be dubbed to tape. Mistakes could be edited out but only after much time and effort. As the TV networks shifted to software-based nonlinear editing, it became easier to edit out mistakes as one now had a visual not just of the show but of the music and sound as well. Music and other sounds can now be seen as waveforms, its transients easily shifted on the timeline to sync perfectly with the video (Achacoso 2015).

In the case of fantaserye (fantasy drama), which became popular in the early 2000s, it was the musical scorer’s job to invent the soundscape for the appearances of the engkanto (umbrella term for supernatural beings), diwata (guardian spirit), and various otherworldly beings, among many other special effects. These have been the responsibilities of the musical scorer for most TV networks, except for ABS-CBN, where the task assignments are more specialized. With the current intellectual property regime in place and with music production technology advancing at a dizzying pace, the distinction between musical scorer and composer has become blurred. Since the mid-1990s, when it became possible to fully realize an orchestral piece of music using nothing but a computer, musical scorers have started relying less on recorded music and more on their own original compositions, becoming like musical directors.Written by Pearlsha Abubakar

Sources

Achacoso 2015; Cadsawan 2015; Cruz 2015; Fiel 2015; Luna 2015; Trex 2015; Wikipedia 2015.

text:
Transnational broadcasting, sometimes called overseas or international broadcasting, is not new. Defined as broadcasting beyond national borders, transnational broadcasting of Philippine origin began in the 1930s when radio stations aired both on longwave and shortwave bands. In the first, radio signals covered a limited area, with Manila-based stations reaching only the nearby provinces. The second allowed stations to relay signals not only to the Visayas and Mindanao but also to much of Asia, the United States, and ships at sea. Today a combination of technologies, including satellites and digital technology, has expanded transnational broadcasting of Philippine programming. Moreover, new broadcasting business models as well as the spread of diasporic Filipino audiences around the world have driven the creation of Filipino programming in many countries.

The first model involves the overseas expansion of operation of local networks for the purpose of transmitting signals to target audiences abroad. ABS-CBN and GMA, the two largest networks in the country, extended their operations by establishing The Filipino Channel (TFC) and GMA Pinoy TV, respectively. TFC, based in Redwood City, California, USA, delivers programming by broadcast, cable, pay-per-view, and online. It claims to have three million subscribers worldwide, located mostly in the United States, Canada, Europe, Middle East, Australia, and Japan. Launched in 1994, TFC airs mostly programs from ABS CBN as well as news and public affairs programs produced in the United States for Filipino-American audiences. Using the same model of program delivery is GMA Pinoy TV, launched in 2005, which broadcasts to the United States, Canada, Europe, Middle East, North Africa, Japan, Southeast Asia, Hong Kong, and the Pacific. TFC and GMA Pinoy TV both bring to worldwide audiences dramas, comedies, variety shows, musicals, talk shows and other programs made in the Philippines.

Another mode of exporting Filipino programs is by selling franchises and specific shows to stations in other countries. Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!), which airs locally on GMA Channel 7, is the most significant franchise to date, airing in Indonesia with Indonesian hosts. (See Franchising.) Dubbed in English or in the languages of the countries to which they are exported, teleseryes, on the other hand, are showing in international markets including countries in Asia and Africa. ABS-CBN teleseryes that gained a following abroad include Pangako Sa ‘Yo, titled internationally as The Promise, which aired in Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, Cambodia, and Africa in 2002. Another ABS CBN favorite, Tayong Dalawa (The Two of Us), aired in Singapore and Malaysia in 2010 and later in Brunei and Kenya. Sana Maulit Muli (Can We Start Over Again) was later dubbed in Mandarin and aired in Taiwan in 2008 with the title Chances. Lobo (Werewolf) in 2008 was a fantasy-horror teleserye, aired in Brunei, in Vietnam, and other countries in Asia, Europe and Africa.

The move towards digital broadcasting, backed by law, has significantly increased the use of live streaming of both radio and television signals, tremendously increasing the availability of Philippine programs online, which makes them accessible globally. With simpler technologies and requiring less bandwidth than television, radio stations have been aggressively simulcasting terrestrially and online, effectively transnationalizing most Philippine radio since the beginning of the 21st century. Nevertheless, the presence of growing Filipino populations in several countries has encouraged the establishment of land-based as well as online radio stations in the United States, Europe, and parts of Asia, especially where there are significant numbers of Filipino migrants and contract workers, ensuring the commercial viability of the broadcast operation.

One such station is TAG-FM, broadcasting on 91.1 MHz, the first Filipino format radio station in the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Launched on 25 Mar 2013, TAG-FM is one of two stations owned by the Arabian Radio Network, the largest radio owner in Dubai with nine stations broadcasting in six languages (The National 2013; ARN 2013; Khaleej Times 2013). It broadcasts in Tagalog, hence the name. With an output power of between 12 and 15 kilowatts from its antenna located on the 68-storey Al Mas (Arabic for “the Diamond”) skyscraper, the centerpiece building of 79 towers in the larger Jumeirah Lake Towers development, TAG-FM’s signal reaches the entire UAE landmass and the approximately 650,000 to 900,000 members of the Filipino community in the UAE (Commission on Filipinos Overseas 2012) as well as overseas Filipino workers (OFWs) in neighboring countries near the borders who listen via a traditional radio receiver and throughout the Middle East who tune in via the station’s web stream on the Internet and mobile applications. The on-air staff is recruited from the major broadcasting groups in Manila, including MBC (Manila Broadcasting Company) and ABS CBN. In its first year of operation, TAG-FM won Ahlan Magazine’s “Best Radio Station” award, with an overwhelming vote of over 50,000 from readers, a first in the magazine’s history. The station airs mainly Original Pilipino Music (OPM) and news from the Gulf and from the Philippines.

In Australia, two radio groups air programs for Filipinos: the Filipino Broadcasting Group (FBG), which is part of 92.3 3ZZZ Ethnic Community Radio Station, and the Filipino Language Program under Special Broadcasting Service (SBS). Supported by the Australian government, they are part of Australia’s program to strengthen its multicultural and multilingual society. FBG airs five programs every week, which include community and entertainment news and music. Filipino musical artists based in Australia are featured. Heard via broadcast and online, the FBG launched the first Cebuano-Tagalog-English show in Australia. The Filipino Language Program in SBS, on the other hand, broadcasting in Filipino, is part of an Australian government-funded public broadcasting in 78 languages. It broadcasts daily and is available via streaming, Facebook, and smartphone apps, informing Filipino communities across Australia of news and services. It has also produced radio plays in partnership with Dulaang Bayan ng Melbourne (DBM). It has recorded and aired an original musical on the Philippines, Kalayaan, produced by Harmonico Filipino’s Rollie Limun.

Host to a growing number of Filipino migrants and contract workers, Europe is the base of several Filipino radio stations. In the United Kingdom, Channel Philippines Network (CPN) in 2009 launched Pinoy Radio UK, the first Filipino radio station in Europe via online streaming. Its success led to the launch of Pinoy Nordic on 14 Jun 2012. By 2013 its network included Pinoy Radio España, Pinoy Radio France, Pinoy Radio in Benelux (Belgium, Netherlands, and Luxembourg), Pinoy Radio Italia, Pinoy Radio Germany, and Pinoy Radio Ireland. It plans to establish Pinoy Radios in other European countries, including Austria, Switzerland, and Greece. Common among the programming of the stations are music shows featuring Original Pilipino Music (OPM); talk shows discussing migration and family law, loves and lives of Filipinas and their European partners, the struggles of Filipinos in Europe, and Filipino food and lifestyles; and news and information from the Philippines and the Philippine embassies in Europe. Managed from London by Philippine radio veteran Joseph Sonny Laragan, CPN reaches over 800,000 Filipino migrants in Europe.

With the viability of online broadcasting, Filipino radio stations began to flourish in many countries in the 2000s. However, in the US, Filipino stations had been thriving since the 1960s. KNDI, broadcasting on the AM band at 1270 kHz, is a multicultural radio station specializing in Filipino programming. Based in Honolulu, Hawaii, it is the first AM Filipino radio station in the US, launched on 11 Jul 1960 with the moniker Candy Radio, referring to its all-woman staff headed by Leona Jona. Apart from Tagalog, Ilocano, and English, it broadcasts in other Asian and Pacific languages. Another Honolulu-based station is KPHI, broadcasting both on FM at 96.7 mHz and on AM at 1130 kHz, which launched in 2005. The last three letters of its call letters stand for the Philippines. Like KNDI, it broadcasts in Tagalog, Ilocano, and English. Both stations feature Filipino music, Hawaii-based Filipino-American artists, and dramas in Tagalog and Ilocano.

Closer to home is Hello Asia Pinoy Radio on FM, 102.3 mHz, in Singapore. Also streaming online, it was launched by Asia-Connect (S) Pte Ltd in Aug 2005. It airs OPM and talk shows covering topics that range from Philippine entertainment news, travel tips, legal advice, business and job opportunities, and real estate, to true-to-life stories of Filipino migrants in Singapore. Hello Asia is also heard in Batan in Indonesia and Johor Bahru in Malaysia.

With the continuing spread of Filipino migrants and workers throughout the world, transnational Filipino broadcasting is expected to grow and keep bringing Filipino arts, language, and ways of life to their new or temporary homes, and possibly diffuse Filipino cultures to their host countries.Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez, Maria Angelica D. Abad,and Bradley C. FreemanWith notes from Earvin Charles B. Cabalquintoand Jane O. Vinculado
