article.value: Transnational broadcasting, sometimes called overseas or international broadcasting, is not new. Defined as broadcasting beyond national borders, transnational broadcasting of Philippine origin began in the 1930s when radio stations aired both on longwave and shortwave bands. In the first, radio signals covered a limited area, with Manila-based stations reaching only the nearby provinces. The second allowed stations to relay signals not only to the Visayas and Mindanao but also to much of Asia, the United States, and ships at sea. Today a combination of technologies, including satellites and digital technology, has expanded transnational broadcasting of Philippine programming. Moreover, new broadcasting business models as well as the spread of diasporic Filipino audiences around the world have driven the creation of Filipino programming in many countries.

The first model involves the overseas expansion of operation of local networks for the purpose of transmitting signals to target audiences abroad. ABS-CBN and GMA, the two largest networks in the country, extended their operations by establishing The Filipino Channel (TFC) and GMA Pinoy TV, respectively. TFC, based in Redwood City, California, USA, delivers programming by broadcast, cable, pay-per-view, and online. It claims to have three million subscribers worldwide, located mostly in the United States, Canada, Europe, Middle East, Australia, and Japan. Launched in 1994, TFC airs mostly programs from ABS CBN as well as news and public affairs programs produced in the United States for Filipino-American audiences. Using the same model of program delivery is GMA Pinoy TV, launched in 2005, which broadcasts to the United States, Canada, Europe, Middle East, North Africa, Japan, Southeast Asia, Hong Kong, and the Pacific. TFC and GMA Pinoy TV both bring to worldwide audiences dramas, comedies, variety shows, musicals, talk shows and other programs made in the Philippines.

text:
Videography is the art and science of capturing moving images on television and similar electronic digital media, as opposed to cinematography where the images are imprinted on celluloid film. The artistic component of videography consists of visual composition, camera movement, and the manipulation of light, both artificial and natural, to achieve a specific creative objective. The scientific component includes camera handling, lighting exposure, the use of recording devices, and the operation of other technical equipment used in capturing images such as a camera and lens, a camera control unit (CCU), lighting instruments, reflectors, gobos, and lens filters. These components are divided into the following functions: lighting direction or the design of the illumination of the set and the performers; technical direction or the control of the settings of the several cameras used in the production in order to balance their color temperature (white balance) for accurate color reproduction, match camera filter settings, and aperture openings for exposure; and, camera operation or the manipulation of the camera to compose the images and carry out camera movements.

The personnel in charge of videography for video and television productions vary according to program genre, production budget, and production needs. Usually, in productions with multi-camera setups, whether it airs live with real-time switching from one camera to another or pre-recorded and edited after the shoot, videography is usually divided among the following: the lighting director with the help of a gaffer and other lighting personnel for lighting direction; the technical director for the technical aspects of lighting; and the camera operators for camera handling. In productions with a single camera setup, the videographer sometimes takes on the role of the lighting director, technical director, and camera operator.

In public affairs programs like the morning show Unang Hirit (First Strike), 1999, GMA, which has a multiple camera setup and airs live, the program director acts as the lighting director, giving instructions to lighting personnel and gaffers to execute the lighting effects he or she needs for the program. The program director also provides the camera operators with the coverage and camera angling he needs during the duration of the show. This kind of lighting is usually formulaic with the main objective of illuminating the set and the presenters and performers. In this kind of set up, a technical director assists the program director with the other elements of videography.

For programs that have repetitive segments, like the game show Kapamilya: Deal or No Deal (Of the Family: Deal or No Deal), 2006, ABS-CBN, which is pre-recorded and has a multiple camera setup, a lighting director is hired for the initial shooting. The lighting crew simply replicates the original design in the taping of the succeeding episodes.

In a pre-recorded program with a multiple camera setup like drama productions, a more creative kind of lighting is the convention. In these types of programs, a lighting director, usually a cinematographer from the film industry, with his lighting crew, is hired to design and execute the lighting requirements of the production. Malu L. Sevilla’s fantasy drama Juan de la Cruz, 2013, ABS-CBN, was lit by George Tutanes and his crew. Tutanes’s film credits include Carlos Siguion Reyna’s Kahapon May Dalawang Bata (Yesterday Children), 2000, and Mel Chionglo’s Burlesk King, 1999. Noted film cinematographer Romy Vitug handled the camera for some episodes of the music program Aawitan Kita (I Will Sing for You), 1970-2006, aired on different channels.

News and public affairs programs, such as The Correspondents, 1998, ABS-CBN, Brigada Siete, 1993, GMA, and Probe Team Documentaries, 2004, TV5, are examples of pre-recorded programs that usually use a single camera for image gathering. The coverage team in these kinds of programs is composed of a camera operator, audio person, production management team, and the producer/director/on-camera performer. In this setup, the camera person acts as the videographer, responsible for both the creative and technical aspect of the coverage. In some instances, the producer/director/on-camera talent would suggest a camera angle for the coverage. In low budget independent and alternative productions, usually for online broadcast, the videography is done by the producer/director: it usually is a one-person team. Recent documentaries, such as Reel Time and Front Row, which both premiered in 2011 on GMA News TV Channel 11, have adopted some aspects of the cinéma verité tradition in capturing and framing images for the video camera.

With the emergence and accessibility of new video technology with higher resolutions and the ability to capture images in low light conditions, techniques used in both the cinema and theater have been adopted by videographers allowing for more creativity in visual imaging as compared to the flatter/no-shadow lighting formula prior to these advancements in technology. The flatter lighting used in Oras ng Ligaya (Happy Hour), 1962, ABS-CBN, is very different from the depths of images seen in It’s Showtime, 2009, ABS-CBN, where lighting for live concerts that use moving lighting instruments has become a standard for variety shows.

These technologies, like mobile phones with built-in cameras, have also enabled those outside the broadcast industries to create their own video works which are exhibited in online portals like YouTube and in mainstream broadcasts’ participatory segments, similar to “Bayan Mo, Ipatrol Mo” (Monitor Your Country), a segment of the news program TV Patrol, which premiered in 1987 over ABS-CBN. Written byFernando A. Austria JrWith notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources

Limchoa 2014; Saquido 2013; Wikipedia 2015.
